  25. So a lot of this is gonna be a continuation
  26. of things that we’ve talked about in other modules,
  27. including module two where we talked about blockchain.
  28. So we’ll be referencing back to those from time to time.
  29. And one of the key things that we’re gonna be emphasising
  30. is the sources of power.
  31. So, for example, will FinTech innovation
  32. lead to a decentralisation of power,
  33. or maybe a concentration of existing power sources
  34. like governments and banks?
  35. Or will a new concentration of power really be created
  36. in TechFins like Amazon or Tencent,
  37. which owns an app like WeChat, for example?
  38. Okay, we’re gonna start module five with a quick story.
  39. Now, I’ve been living and working within China
  40. for over a decade
  41. and travelled there many times.
  42. Last year, I had the opportunity to go
  43. to a small part of Western China that I’d never been before.
  44. So imagine kind of a rural desert landscape
  45. with kinda dust everywhere.
  46. In the morning I decided to not eat breakfast in the hotel
  47. and instead went out to get something on the street.
  48. Now, I noticed that there was a particular street vendor,
  49. an old woman,
  50. who you could tell she’s been doing this
  51. for a very long time
  52. and she was surrounded by people,
  53. so it was obvious that her food was quite popular.
  54. So, I went over there quite excitedly,
  55. I kinda watched what everybody was doing,
  56. and then when it came to be my turn I ordered some food.
  57. Thankfully I can speak Chinese
  58. and so that part of it was easy from a cultural standpoint.
  59. As I reached into my wallet
  60. and started to pull out some cash,
  61. I could immediately see the concern on her face
  62. when we both had the realisation
  63. that every other single person in that circle
  64. had paid using their phone
  65. and she did not have the ability
  66. to give me change with cash.
  67. So here I was,
  68. probably the person who had most access
  69. to the financial industry,
  70. and yet I was the one
  71. that was completely cut out of the transaction
  72. and out of this marketplace.
  73. Now, I found this experience,
  74. even though I couldn’t get my breakfast
  75. and I was a little upset about that,
  76. I found this experience super cool
  77. because this community in rural Western China
  78. had in a short amount of time
  79. moved almost completely away from cash.
  80. And indeed anyone that’s been to China recently knows
  81. that most communities are the same way,
  82. and the government, for those that have been there
  83. know that they’re actually very supportive of this change.
  84. So, we find this story is gonna be a good summary
  85. not only for the things that we’ve discussed
  86. in modules one through four
  87. but also it’s gonna be a nice transition
  88. to help us start asking some of the bigger questions
  89. that we’re gonna be analysing in modules five and six.
  90. So, before you move on to the next video,
  91. we just wanna ask you, think about the story,
  92. and from a FinTech standpoint
  93. what are some of the observations that you have,
  94. specially about how FinTech is impacting local people,
  95. average people in rural communities or advanced communities
  96. all over the world.

Additional Readings

  • He, D., Leckow, R., Haksar, V., Mancini-Griffoli, T., Jenkinson, N., Kashima, M., Khiaonarong, T., Rochon, C., Tourpe, H. (2017). Fintech and Financial Services: Initial Considerations.  IMF Staff Discussion Note. Retrieved from https://www.imf.org/~/media/Files/Publications/SDN/2017/sdn1705.ashx
  • Chuen, K., & Lee, D. (2017). Decentralization and Distributed Innovation: Fintech, Bitcoin and ICO’s. Stanford Asia-Pacific Innovation Conference. Retrieved from http://dx.doi.org/10.2139/ssrn.3107659
  • Magnuson, W. J., (2017). Regulating Fintech. Vanderbilt Law Review, Forthcoming; Texas A&M University School of Law Legal Studies Research Paper No. 17-55. Retrieved from https://ssrn.com/abstract=3027525

5.1.1 Is FinTech Leading to Inclusion or Exclusion?

  1. – Okay, welcome back.
  2. Now although that was a quick story,
  3. we hope that you had a chance to kind of think about it
  4. because we believe a lot can be observed from it.
  5. Now let’s consider a few of these things.
  6. – Probably the most immediate observation
  7. is something that we’ve already discussed,
  8. the scale and penetration of FinTech innovation
  9. is faster and broader than anything we’ve seen before.
  10. Everyone on the street has a modern smartphone,
  11. and they had all adopted the technology
  12. into their daily routine.
  13. One reason this is true is because FinTech innovation
  14. can lead to efficiencies,
  15. which in turn can help a lot of people.
  16. And as discussed in module two, FinTech innovation
  17. can help cut out the middleman which saves costs.
  18. And for the street vendor using an app payment system means
  19. not needing to handle cash,
  20. which likely means to reduce risk of theft
  21. or for food worker is more sanitary.
  22. And in many cases, using cashless payments,
  23. it’s just faster and more efficient, leads better service.
  24. So basically, using a mobile payment system,
  25. help her business be more efficient
  26. and hopefully more profitable.
  27. – But FinTech innovations can also lead to exclusion.
  28. I probably had the greatest access to traditional finance,
  29. whether cash, credit and other loans,
  30. that anyone on that street thought they had,
  31. yet I was almost completely excluded from the marketplace,
  32. not even able to purchase breakfast.
  33. Like in this example, FinTech can lead to separation
  34. from financial markets, and therefore basic necessities.
  35. Although buying breakfast is a simple transaction,
  36. there are many layers of filtering in the story.
  37. For example, if you are required to pay with the phone,
  38. then guess what, you have to have a phone.
  39. And then you have to have the app WeChat
  40. and then an account on WeChat,
  41. and then money in or credits in that account.
  42. So one of the interesting challenges
  43. in the FinTech industry faces
  44. concerns access to these technologies.
  45. While many are hopeful that FinTech innovations
  46. will lead to better access to finance for the masses,
  47. others are concerned that it could also lead
  48. to increase exclusion from basic services.
  49. And this can be particularly true if governments decide
  50. to intentionally exclude some people from these platforms.
  51. – Now, going back to the example
  52. of the street vendor in China,
  53. we now ask a big question, the big question of the day.
  54. Will these innovations in FinTech
  55. bring the world closer together
  56. through multinational FinTech solution
  57. or will we become more and more isolated from each other?
  58. For example, credit cards have made it easy
  59. to make purchases around the world, no matter where I am.
  60. You know, I feel confident,
  61. I can make necessary payments using your credit card,
  62. though sometimes that means maybe paying high fees.
  63. – But on the other hand, David and I’ve been travelling to
  64. and teaching in China for many years.
  65. And while we love travelling there,
  66. from a FinTech perspective, every year,
  67. it seems more and more insular
  68. and disconnected from the rest of the world
  69. because of this simple paradox,
  70. the better their app ecosystem gets
  71. and the more people in China become interconnected
  72. via these apps, they’re simultaneously distancing themselves
  73. from the rest of the world.
  74. Now, this was made clear in the exercise
  75. with the Chinese street vendor,
  76. and this is happening in other countries too.
  77. Okay, so let me ask you another question.
  78. Do we think that FinTech is bringing the world together
  79. or pushing us further apart?

5.1.2 Money and Currency – Trust and Power

  1. – Another interesting lesson from the street vendor example,
  2. was that value was being transferred,
  3. but was this money in a traditional sense?
  4. It wasn’t physical currency, that’s for sure.
  5. But there was currency backing that transaction,
  6. even if, distantly, on some cloud somewhere.
  7. This is very different than systems of payment
  8. that have existed for thousands of years,
  9. and will likely lead to the next evolution
  10. of not only how we pay, but also our perception of money.
  11. And actually, on that note,
  12. kind of an interesting vignette or an example,
  13. is even in North Korea,
  14. traditionally a country that we think is cut off
  15. from the global financial system,
  16. increasingly many people in North Korea now use cell phones.
  17. And frequently they have top up,
  18. like in other countries in the world, to buy credits.
  19. But now those credits can be transferred
  20. from one user of a cell phone to another
  21. as a form of payment.
  22. And so this is also a different concept of money.
  23. – Now this reminds me about one of my favourite things
  24. about living in Hong Kong, the Octopus Card.
  25. With this little card, I can pay for just about anything.
  26. Transportation, food, and even government services.
  27. And you can see it’s pretty worn here,
  28. I’ve used this card practically every day
  29. since my family moved here in 2007.
  30. And my children almost exclusively use their card
  31. to make purchases.
  32. – While some may say that the shift
  33. to making payments from phone apps or the Octopus Card
  34. is just the next natural iteration in making payments,
  35. much like the credit card
  36. and the handwritten cheque before that,
  37. and that people just get used to
  38. the changes in the way that,
  39. children in Hong Kong are already used to paying
  40. with an octopus card for when they go to the store.
  41. We do need to understand that such changes
  42. can actually have very significant implications for society.
  43. – Now for example, there are personal implications.
  44. As we know, these developments can make it easier
  45. to access and use money,
  46. having your credit card means
  47. you don’t have to carry around thousands of dollars in cash
  48. to make a purchase, for example.
  49. But on the other hand, studies seem to indicate
  50. that people spend more money when using a credit card
  51. than when using cash.
  52. And there’s reason to believe
  53. that people spend even more money
  54. when using an app or a web-based service
  55. than when using a credit card.
  56. It’s believed that the proximity issue
  57. that we discussed previously has a lot to do with this.
  58. This is pretty common sense, right,
  59. holding cash is proximate, and therefore forces us
  60. to think about the work that went into earning the money.
  61. Thus we naturally spend less when we’re holding cash.
  62. – But beyond these personal implications,
  63. as mentioned before,
  64. there are broader societal implications to consider.
  65. Now going back to David Bishop’s experience
  66. with the street vendor in China.
  67. This was a great example of disruption
  68. of the many formidable institutions
  69. that for millennia have controlled not only finance,
  70. but most other aspects of institutional power.
  71. Remember, there were no banks,
  72. whether physical or virtual, in this scenario.
  73. WeChat, called Weixin in China, isn’t a bank
  74. or even a financial institution in the traditional sense.
  75. That’s why refer to them as TechFins:
  76. large technology companies
  77. that because of their size, user base and overall scale,
  78. are starting to move into areas of commerce
  79. and services traditionally controlled by banks.
  80. – But not only were there no banks,
  81. there was also no physical currency.
  82. As I’m sure you’re aware,
  83. banknotes and coins can only be produced
  84. by government-approved organisations.
  85. For example, US dollars are printed
  86. by the Bureau of Engraving and Printing,
  87. and are issued by the Federal Reserve.
  88. And here in Hong Kong, our banknotes
  89. are printed by the Hong Kong Printing Limited,
  90. and issued by three banks.
  91. So here I have three $100 notes.
  92. This one issued by the Bank of China Hong Kong Limited.
  93. This by the Hong Kong and Shanghai
  94. Banking Corporation Limited, more commonly known as HSBC.
  95. And finally this one, issued by Standard Charter Bank.
  96. – Okay, so who cares?
  97. You’ve all probably held and seen foreign currency
  98. at some point in your life,
  99. and know how it can be a pain to exchange currency
  100. when going from country to country.
  101. You’ve also probably had the experience
  102. of shopping in another country,
  103. and trying to convert the cost of something
  104. from one currency to another.
  105. Now, to be honest, although I’ve lived in Hong Kong
  106. for nearly ten years,
  107. I still find myself frequently converting
  108. the price of a good into US dollars
  109. just to help me get a better sense of the cost or value
  110. of that particular item.
  111. Well the reason this matters
  112. is a combination of trust and power.
  113. As we outlined in Module One,
  114. the value of currency is really only sustained
  115. by a broad sense of communal trust.
  116. And by changing the nature of money,
  117. we are potentially altering the foundations of trust,
  118. which can have broad implications across society.
  119. – But also, this is about power.
  120. The ability to print your own currency
  121. is a significant source of power.
  122. Maybe you’ve seen a movie where criminals
  123. try to steal or create ink plates
  124. so that they can print their own money,
  125. and to be honest, when I was a kid,
  126. that was a dream of mine.
  127. As another example, there’s been a lotta discussion
  128. about the power the United States has in the world
  129. because of the outsize influence of the US dollar.
  130. Which is widely considered as the world’s reserve currency.
  131. As an example, right here in Hong Kong
  132. our money is pegged to the US dollar.
  133. Meaning the value of the Hong Kong dollar
  134. rises and falls along with the US dollar.
  135. So think about how much power that involves.
  136. It means that some folks in the US
  137. that maybe have never even been to Hong Kong,
  138. can change the value of our currency here,
  139. which in turn can affect the cost of everyday goods,
  140. housing prices, the value of your personal savings,
  141. company profitability and many many other things.

Additional Readings

  • Hardekopf, B. (2018). Do People Really Spend More With Credit Cards? Forbes. Retrieved from https://www.forbes.com/sites/billhardekopf/2018/07/16/do-people-really-spend-more-with-credit-cards/#79b01d11c19a 
  • Prelec, D. & Simester, D. (2001). Marketing Letters, 12(5). Retrieved from https://doi.org/10.1023/A:1008196717017 (paywall)

5.1.3 Will Governments Accept New Currencies?

  1. – Okay, so returning to street vendor example again.
  2. On that street in China there’s no currency involved,
  3. now is that the goal of FinTech Innovation
  4. to eliminate all physical currency?
  5. Or perhaps even government backed currency altogether?
  6. If the latter, do you think that governments
  7. will just roll over and allow
  8. their control of their currency to be taken away?
  9. – Now in the China street vendor example
  10. although people were paying with the Web App
  11. the transactions were still backed by government
  12. issued currency.
  13. What happens when this is not the case?
  14. Cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin are usually not
  15. government issued, and even government backed currency.
  16. Will governments be willing to allow
  17. the use of theses cryptocurrencies
  18. within their borders?
  19. And possibly even adopt
  20. one of these currencies as one of their own?
  21. – Some nations have already announced
  22. that they would move to cryptocurrency in some form.
  23. For example Venezuela launched
  24. a Petro cryptocurrency to help the country
  25. among international economic sanctions.
  26. But the Marshall Islands is the first country
  27. to launch a legal tender cryptocurrency
  28. meaning their new currency will be
  29. recognised as legal tender, real money.
  30. And will have equal status as their
  31. current currency, you’ve guessed it
  32. which is the US dollar.
  33. We told you, the US dollar, lots of power.
  34. – Even the name of the new Marshallese currency
  35. it’s called ‘Sovereign’ after all,
  36. is a statement about power.
  37. The name was chosen to emphasise
  38. the sovereignty of the country
  39. which has a history of colonisation, nuclear testing
  40. and resulting poverty.
  41. When discussing the controversial cryptocurrency
  42. the president said “This is a historic moment
  43. for our people, finally issuing and using
  44. our own currency, alongside the
  45. US Dollar. It is another step
  46. manifesting our national liberty”.
  47. – This switch will have a lot of implications,
  48. and could be the start
  49. of a new age for money and finance.
  50. Interestingly, the International Monetary Fund, the IMF
  51. warned the Marshall Islands government
  52. about issuing such a cryptocurrency.
  53. They were concerned that the currency
  54. could be manipulated by crime syndicates
  55. and fraudulent business practises.
  56. The types of activities that have often
  57. been tied to cryptocurrencies.
  58. And also that foreign government could
  59. cut financial aid to the Marshall Islands
  60. if they broke from the US Dollar
  61. as their own e-currency.
  62. Okay so let’s stop and consider some important questions.
  63. Do you think that cryptocurrency and other FinTech
  64. solutions will ever be largely adopted
  65. by banks and governments?
  66. Or, will they lead to de-centralised future
  67. where banks and governments are less
  68. influential in these areas?
  69. Will TechFins take over the finance industry?
  70. And, will other countries adopt cryptocurrency
  71. as a legal tender?

Additional Readings

  • Venezuela Starts Pre-Sale of Petro Cryptocurrency (2018). Deutsche Welle. Retrieved from https://www.dw.com/en/venezuela-starts-pre-sale-of-petro-cryptocurrency/a-42655274
  • Sovereign cryptocurrency: Marshall Islands to launch world-first digital legal tender (2018). Deutsche Welle. Retrieved from https://www.dw.com/en/sovereign-cryptocurrency-marshall-islands-to-launch-world-first-digital-legal-tender/a-42810832
  • Young. J. (2018). Why the IMF is Trying to Stop Marshall Islands From Adopting Crypto. CCN. Retrieved from https://www.ccn.com/why-the-imf-is-trying-to-stop-marshall-islands-from-adopting-crypto

5.1.4 Will FinTech Take Control of Financial System?

  1. – Okay so in summary,
  2. FinTech is leading to some really amazing efficiencies
  3. that can help a lot of people
  4. bypass middlemen and save money,
  5. but it can also lead to exclusion within countries
  6. and exacerbate divides between countries.
  7. This is largely because these innovations
  8. are completely changing the very concept of money
  9. which is leading to questions
  10. about trust, proximity and especially power.
  11. – So where does this leave us?
  12. Will banks allow their power
  13. to be receded by decentralised cryptocurrencies,
  14. peer-to-peer lending networks
  15. and other FinTech innovations?
  16. Or will they use these developments
  17. to further consolidate their power over financial products?
  18. – Will governments stand idly by
  19. while their power over currency,
  20. personal identification,
  21. and other traditional government-based power
  22. is taken away by FinTech startups?
  23. – And how will both banks and governments
  24. react to the rise of TechFins,
  25. who seem to be growing daily,
  26. increasing in both power and profits
  27. as they expand further and further into services
  28. traditionally handled by other institutions?
  29. In this module we will explore some of these questions.
  30. But first, let’s talk about what we mean
  31. when we say decentralised,
  32. or democratised.

Additional Readings

  • Zetzsche, D. A., Buckley, R. P., Arner, D. W., & Barberis, J. N. (2017), From FinTech to TechFin: The Regulatory Challenges of Data-Driven Finance. University of Hong Kong Faculty of Law Research Paper No. 2017/007. Retrieved from or http://dx.doi.org/10.2139/ssrn.2959925
  • Marous, J. (2018). The Future of Banking: Fintech or Techfin? Forbes. Retrieved from https://www.forbes.com/sites/jimmarous/2018/08/27/future-of-banking-fintech-or-techfin-technology/#5bbdbbd15f2d
  • Ren, D. (2018). Tightening Regulations Make FinTechs Easy Takeover Targets for Banks Stepping Up Digitalisation Drive. SCMP. Retrieved from https://www.scmp.com/business/companies/article/2159718/tightening-regulations-make-fintechs-easy-takeover-targets-banks

5.2.1 Is FinTech an Evolution or a Revolution?

  1. – Now, if you pay attention to the FinTech space
  2. chances are that you’ve heard words
  3. decentralised and democratised a lot.
  4. FinTech experts of all varieties
  5. love throwing around these terms
  6. but what do they really mean in a FinTech context?
  7. – Well, many see FinTech development
  8. as a natural process of technical advancement,
  9. much like the locomotive surpassing the stagecoach.
  10. Others see FinTech as a direct result of,
  11. and possibly even fighting against,
  12. traditional centres of financial power.
  13. Some believe the power to control banking, currency,
  14. and even our own identity, has been held by the elite few
  15. and that the control of finance
  16. has not been transparent nor democratic.
  17. – Whether as a result of the natural evolution of technology
  18. or as a direct backlash against existing power structures,
  19. the reality is that FinTech is seen by many
  20. as having the potential to completely change,
  21. and possibly even destroy,
  22. existing financial power structures.
  23. And it’s important to understand
  24. both these motivations and possible outcomes.
  25. So do you think that FinTech advancements
  26. are a natural evolution of technology
  27. or a direct result from the mistrust of institutional power?

Additional Readings

  • Wilkins, C. A. (2016). Fintech and the Financial Ecosystem: Evolution or Revolution? Bank of Canada. Retrieved from https://www.bankofcanada.ca/2016/06/fintech-financial-ecosystem-evolution-revolution/

5.2.2 Have We Lost Trust in Financial Institutions?

  1. – As we have discussed many times,
  2. finance is largely built on trust and in the past,
  3. institutions likes banks and governments have served
  4. as the guarantors of trust in the financial world.
  5. But whether as a cause or effect,
  6. trust in institutions has diminished significantly
  7. in many countries over the past decade.
  8. – Now, probably the best recent example
  9. of a cause for distrust in the financial world
  10. is the global financial crisis,
  11. including all the major financial scandals
  12. that were exposed as a result of the crisis.
  13. Now, for most of us,
  14. we had to stand by and powerlessly watch
  15. as the global financial system nearly collapsed.
  16. We had a daily reminder of how flippantly
  17. certain members of the global financial community
  18. pursued profits at the expense of their customers
  19. and how government regulators
  20. were not really sufficiently protecting us.
  21. – Millions of people around the world lost their homes,
  22. their savings and essentially their futures.
  23. In the US alone, it is estimated that American households
  24. lost approximately $20 trillion
  25. in wealth as a result of the financial crisis.
  26. And as a result, it is no surprise that many of these people
  27. began to de-trust the very institutions
  28. that were meant to protect and serve them.
  29. – Now, as a personal example, my wife and I
  30. bought our first house the year I graduated law school
  31. which was around 2005.
  32. Obviously we didn’t know that we were buying
  33. at pretty much the worst time possible
  34. with the financial crisis decimating the real estate market
  35. only two years after we purchased our home.
  36. Now, when the market crashed,
  37. the value of our home dropped by over 30%
  38. and it took a really long time to recover.
  39. Well, my family recently sold our home.
  40. It was about 13 years after we purchased it.
  41. The selling price?
  42. Exactly the same amount
  43. that we purchased it for back in 2005.
  44. So, while we’re grateful
  45. that we didn’t really lose any money.
  46. There was a lost decade were many people around the world
  47. lost most of their net worth
  48. and have struggled to recover ever since.
  49. – Let’s be honest, many large financial institutions
  50. have not done much since the financial crisis
  51. to reduce our concerns.
  52. As noted earlier in this course,
  53. banks such as Wells Fargo and HSBC
  54. have had multiple high profile scandals
  55. that have gutted their customers’ trust.
  56. And it seems, every week there’s some sort of scandal
  57. that comes out that involves the financial institutions.

Additional Readings

  • The Financial Crisis Response In Charts (2012). The Department of The Treasury. Retrieved from https://www.treasury.gov/resource-center/data-chart-center/Documents/20120413_FinancialCrisisResponse.pdf
  • Srivastava, S. (2017). Nine Years On From the Financial Crisis, Banks Are Still Working to Rebuild Trust. CNBC. Retrieved from https://www.cnbc.com/2017/09/19/nine-years-on-from-the-financial-crisis-banks-are-still-working-to-rebuild-trust.html

5.2.3 Can We Trust TechFins?

  1. – Now during the past decade,
  2. as people shunned banks
  3. and traditional holders of power,
  4. they turned instead to the so-called TechFins,
  5. digital platforms like Facebook, Amazon,
  6. Google, and Tencent,
  7. that provide eCommerce, peer-to-peer lending,
  8. communications, and increasingly serve
  9. as the keepers of our digital identity.
  10. – The rise of the gig economy of social media sites
  11. has meant customers now have more control
  12. over nearly every consumer service,
  13. whether hailing a taxi,
  14. deciding where to stay while on holiday,
  15. and even how to pay their bills.
  16. These large digital platforms have transcended
  17. many traditional financial institutions,
  18. not only in terms of customer engagement,
  19. but also in terms of trust.
  20. – But after more than a decade of explosive growth,
  21. the TechFins are themselves now caught up in many scandals
  22. and are seeing their own trustworthiness questioned.
  23. And some contend
  24. that these companies are now so large and powerful
  25. that they’re actually influencing government policy
  26. and even national elections.
  27. So got a question for you.
  28. Do you trust the TechFins like Amazon and Tencent
  29. more than you trust banks?
  30. Do you think that the TechFins should be regulated
  31. like a utility?
  32. And what do you think
  33. about companies like Facebook
  34. entering the crypto payment space?

Additional Readings

  • Tasca, P. (2018). The Hope and Betrayal of Blockchain. The New York Times. Retrieved from https://www.nytimes.com/2018/12/04/opinion/blockchain-bitcoin-technology-revolution.html
  • De Vynck, G., & McLaughlin, D. (2019). Big Tech Is Armed and Waiting to Repel U.S. Antitrust Onslaught. Bloomberg. Retrieved from https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-06-06/big-tech-is-armed-and-waiting-to-repel-u-s-antitrust-onslaught
  • Smith, U., & Smit, L. (2019). Zuckerberg is Right: Third-Party Standards Must Govern Online Speech. VentureBeat. Retrieved from https://venturebeat.com/2019/04/06/zuckerberg-is-right-third-party-standards-must-govern-online-speech/
  • Heskett, J. (2019). What’s the Antidote to Surveillance Capitalism? Harvard Business School Working Knowledge. Retrieved from https://hbswk.hbs.edu/item/what-s-the-antidote-to-surveillance-capitalism?cid=spmailing-25539335-WK
  • Constine, J. (2019). Facebook Plans June 18th Cryptocurrency Debut. Here’s What We Know. TechCrunch. Retrieved from https://techcrunch.com/2019/06/06/facebook-libra-launch/

5.2.4 Should TechFins Be Regulated Like Utility?

  1. Okay, so a lot of these TechFins and stuff
  2. they’re really getting just gigantic
  3. and a lot of them, you know, people have started
  4. to kind of distrust them a little bit.
  5. So one of the major conversations around this space
  6. now is,
  7. you know, should these TechFins,
  8. should they be regulated like a utility, right?
  9. – Yeah.
  10. So, first maybe, I guess describe
  11. what that means to be regulated like a utility,
  12. but then do you think that should,
  13. you know, should that happen?
  14. – Yeah, so I mean I think this is a timely question
  15. to be honest and that will continue to be a big question
  16. as people think about, we have increasingly
  17. an agglomeration or a collection
  18. of power that’s occurring and now-
  19. – They say the Big Five right?
  20. – That’s right, yeah.
  21. – As opposed to money that is collected
  22. by a slight few financially,
  23. now it’s really data that’s being collected
  24. and now all, many of us in the world
  25. who use different services to provide these
  26. large technology companies are embedded
  27. in their ecosystems,
  28. so it’s difficult to potentially extract yourself from that
  29. if you tried.
  30. And so one of the exercises we did
  31. in one of my classes recently,
  32. was for one of these large technology companies
  33. that everybody knows their name of,
  34. we listed out what services that they had.
  35. And this class was at 9:30 in the morning.
  36. And I said, “From the time you woke up this morning
  37. to the time you came to class, how many of you
  38. used the services on the board?”
  39. And we had a list of maybe 15 types of services,
  40. from this one company,
  41. and most of the class had used at least
  42. 80% of the services,
  43. just in that, whatever, from the time
  44. they woke up and the time they got to class
  45. that morning.
  46. And then I asked them the question,
  47. I said, “Imagine trying to take
  48. yourself out of that ecosystem,
  49. i.e. not use any of these products.
  50. Do you think you could?”
  51. And, the–
  52. – You’ll see articles about that,
  53. some journalists on Medium or something say,
  54. “Oooh, I stayed away
  55. – Or like, I’ve tried this for five days
  56. And everybody says, this was, um,
  57. it may be possible
  58. but there’s so much transaction friction
  59. from doing that, you know,
  60. from moving from that to another service,
  61. that nobody would do it.
  62. And that’s a challenge, right,
  63. because that generates so much data
  64. about you individually and us collectively
  65. which is what is fuelling the continued growth.
  66. – Yeah, one of the things that I think
  67. is super-cool to think about
  68. is that within our lifetime, in the lifetime of most people,
  69. certainly, you know, you that are out there watching this,
  70. within our lifetimes there have been no new utilities.
  71. So when we talk about utilities,
  72. for those who are not familiar with this,
  73. this would be services and goods
  74. that are so essential to society, the government
  75. actually has special regulations about them,
  76. and in fact, they often have like
  77. caps on the amount of profit or revenue
  78. they can actually earn.
  79. So for example, the top utilities would be
  80. electricity, water, sewage, sanitation collection,
  81. anything else?
  82. – No, I think those are the main ones
  83. – That’s pretty much it, right?
  84. – And in a lot of places in the world
  85. some of those are actually
  86. government-controlled entities.
  87. Or partially controlled government entities
  88. – Yeah, yeah, or they’ll give them like
  89. a legal monopoly or something, right.
  90. Okay so now imagine this, so what we’re saying
  91. when we say regulated as a utility, what we’re saying is
  92. has Google become so critical to society,
  93. in terms of its search engine,
  94. do we use it so much, is it so critical,
  95. that it should actually be captured as a public good
  96. just like electricity, right.
  97. Now, you have to understand,
  98. electricity was a technical innovation as well, right,
  99. as was transportation, sanitation, water, right,
  100. and at some point the technical innovation
  101. of pumping water into your home
  102. became a public good and therefore a utility.
  103. But it was started by innovators,
  104. started by private companies, right.
  105. So now the question is, have we advanced within this,
  106. social media?
  107. Is Facebook so important to everyday society
  108. that all of us in society have a stake in it?
  109. That’s really the question that we’re asking.
  110. – And so, I think to that point, you know,
  111. if we think about Google or Facebook,
  112. if we think about a single product
  113. and try to make the argument of regulation as a utility
  114. around a single product, probably not.
  115. But if you think of it collectively,
  116. so if we use Facebook as an example,
  117. you know, Facebook as a social media platform
  118. has a lot of users,
  119. but then if you think about its influence beyond that
  120. like in instant messaging,
  121. where there’s the Messenger on Facebook,
  122. there’s WhatsApp which they own,
  123. there’s Instagram which is another part of Facebook.
  124. Those are different messaging platforms
  125. that reaches, that has a far greater reach.
  126. And then, you know, one of the things
  127. apparently that Facebook is debating at the moment
  128. is if they’re going to have their own payment system.
  129. – Right.
  130. – And so if they were to roll that out
  131. across all their users, across all these platforms,
  132. then immediately they would become
  133. one of the largest financial players in the world.
  134. – Immediately.
  135. – Immediately.
  136. And so then at that point, then to the question,
  137. should they be regulated like a utility,
  138. should they be regulated like a financial institution?
  139. I mean, it starts raising a lot of interesting questions.
  140. – Well, and to that point, just very quickly,
  141. because again for those that don’t know
  142. the legal or even economic history of these things,
  143. you need to understand when we say
  144. regulated as a utility,
  145. that probably means breaking up these companies.
  146. Right. So for example, railroad companies.
  147. Telephone companies.
  148. Electric utilities.
  149. What it means is they’re so big, so powerful
  150. and the service they provide is so essential
  151. to all of society that the government actually goes in
  152. and breaks them apart into different companies
  153. so that all of us, there’s more competition
  154. in the marketplace,
  155. and all of us have better access to that core service.
  156. So, in this instance they could go in
  157. and say Messenger is pulled out of Facebook,
  158. Instagram is pulled out of Facebook,
  159. um, you know, WhatsApp is pulled out of Facebook,
  160. and they cannot have any direct contact with each other
  161. as a financial institute.
  162. – And I would say, and that’s right,
  163. if we look at the United States
  164. probably the most recent version of that
  165. that’s not ancient history is probably telephones.
  166. – Yeah, telephones.
  167. They call them the baby bells.
  168. Because they took this massive bell company
  169. and they broke them into
  170. – They had regional bells
  171. – Exactly, yeah.
  172. And then they had to compete with each other.
  173. – And so, yeah, it would be interesting.
  174. I mean right now in the United States
  175. in 2019 in the lead-up to the next Presidential Election
  176. there’s a candidate right now
  177. – Yeah, who’s already saying this
  178. – Who’s already advocating for a break-up of these
  179. based on you know, anti-competition kind of rationale.
  180. It would be interesting to see if, how this develops,
  181. because I think that idea is tapping into
  182. a more pervasive kind of feeling
  183. that increasingly people are having
  184. about the ideas of privacy, identity, data,
  185. who should have what information,
  186. how can I control my identity?
  187. All of these really fundamental questions
  188. that users of technology, that I think people are having.
  189. – And there’s one last thing before we close on this.
  190. What is also means to be regulated as a utility
  191. as I mentioned was, this often means
  192. like caps on profit, right.
  193. So even if you don’t break up Google for example
  194. because maybe you can’t break up Google,
  195. if they’re regulated as a utility that might mean
  196. they’re only able to earn like
  197. 8% profit a year or whatever, right.
  198. Like a lot of electricity companies,
  199. these utilities, they’re actually capped,
  200. so here in Hong Kong the major power producers
  201. are actually capped so they can only make
  202. a certain amount of profit every single year.
  203. It’s not like a typical competitive environment
  204. because the government, you know,
  205. you can only have so many electrical companies,
  206. basically,
  207. so what they say is you can’t charge customers
  208. over a certain amount.
  209. So, what do you think?
  210. Should these big, you know, multi national
  211. or even national FinTech and TechFin companies
  212. be regulated as a utility,
  213. or should we allow them to just compete
  214. on the open market?

Additional Readings

  • Hughes, C. (2019). It’s Time to Break Up Facebook. The New York Times. Retrieved from https://www.nytimes.com/2019/05/09/opinion/sunday/chris-hughes-facebook-zuckerberg.html
  • Clegg, N. (2019). Breaking Up Facebook Is Not the Answer. The New York Times. Retrieved from https://www.nytimes.com/2019/05/11/opinion/facebook-nick-clegg-chris-hughes.html
  • Lima, C. (2019). Zuckerberg Dismisses Calls to Break Up Facebook. Politico. Retrieved from https://www.politico.com/story/2019/05/23/break-up-facebook-zuckerberg-1342353
  • Carbone, C. (2019). Google’s Eric Schmidt: Breaking up Big Tech would be ‘illegal’ and harmful to consumers. Fox News. Retrieved from https://www.foxnews.com/tech/googles-eric-schmidt-breaking-up-illegal-harmful
  • Cornwell, S. (2019). U.S. Presidential Contender Kamala Harris Favors Look at Breaking Up Facebook. Reuters. Retrieved from https://www.reuters.com/article/us-facebook-harris/u-s-presidential-contender-kamala-harris-favors-look-at-breaking-up-facebook-idUSKCN1SI0K5 
  • Bary, E. (2019). If the Government Breaks Up Google, Would it Be Worth More? MarketWatch. Retrieved from https://www.marketwatch.com/story/why-a-google-breakup-would-be-good-for-alphabet-investors-2019-06-11
  • Chen, A. (2019). How to Regulate Big Tech Without Breaking it Up. MIT Technology Review. Retrieved from https://www.technologyreview.com/s/613640/big-tech-monopoly-breakup-amazon-apple-facebook-google-regulation-policy/

5.2.5 Five D’s of FinTech

  1. – So, where does that leave us?
  2. Well, once you tie everything together,
  3. it has led many people to an increased desire
  4. for transparency and control in their lives,
  5. including goods and services.
  6. People are shifting to a machine-driven trust
  7. that doesn’t require third party,
  8. whether a bank, government, or other potential intermediary.
  9. Some have even suggested
  10. that the rise of blockchain and cryptocurrency
  11. is closely related to people’s faith or lack-there-of
  12. in government-backed institutions.
  13. – This desire for more trust, transparency, and control
  14. is summarised by what one commentator described
  15. as the, quote, five Ds of FinTech.
  16. – The first D is democratisation.
  17. From the beginning, many traditional elements of finance
  18. have only been available to the wealthy and elite.
  19. The democratisation of finance
  20. entails bringing such resources to the masses.
  21. For example, wealth management, life insurance,
  22. and the ability to borrow and lend money
  23. are some of the many services
  24. that in the past were largely unavailable to the poor.
  25. But many FinTech innovators are bringing these services
  26. to people throughout the developing world.
  27. (cash register clinks)
  28. – The second D is disaggregation.
  29. Disaggregation is a big word that basically means
  30. to divide or to break apart.
  31. Now, in the past,
  32. financial service have largely been concentrated
  33. by only a handful of entities.
  34. Leaders in FinTech have started to give customers
  35. better and quicker access to information,
  36. thus reducing cost and increasing options.
  37. An example of this would be a website like LendingTree
  38. that shows many different mortgage options
  39. so that customers can shop between different lenders.
  40. – The third D is disintermediation.
  41. Again, this is a really big word,
  42. but basically it means cutting out the middle man.
  43. We’ve already discussed this quite along this course,
  44. but basically many FinTech solutions
  45. hope to save customers money and time
  46. by cutting out the middle man.
  47. Peer-to-peer lending services
  48. and blockchain-based remittance services
  49. are examples of this.
  50. – Okay, so, the fourth D is decentralisation.
  51. And this focuses around the idea
  52. that a lot of FinTech solutions
  53. are not controlled by a single, central entity
  54. but instead give control and power
  55. to many players simultaneously.
  56. So, blockchain-based products
  57. are probably the best example of this.
  58. As discussed, blockchain is a distributed ledger system,
  59. meaning the data is synchronised and shared
  60. across multiple locations simultaneously.
  61. – The fifth and last D is de-biasing.
  62. Many FinTech innovators
  63. hope to remove historical bias from the financial system
  64. and to create a levelled playing field
  65. with transparent information.
  66. The belief is that financial institutions
  67. have been too exclusive and closed off,
  68. and they’re hoping that the use of technology
  69. can make finance easier to understand and accessible.
  70. – Okay, now, in summary,
  71. whether because this is the natural evolution of technology
  72. or the result of a backlash against banks
  73. and other large institutions,
  74. FinTech innovators are really promoting solutions
  75. that provide more transparency, more control,
  76. and more equality for consumers around the world.
  77. They want to enhance financial inclusion
  78. so that products that were previously only available
  79. to the rich and powerful
  80. can be held by everyone.
  81. – But what do you think?
  82. Is this a realistic goal?
  83. Do you think that the institutions
  84. that traditionally hold power
  85. will really allow this to occur?
  86. Or is this future inevitable?
  87. Before we can really answer those questions,
  88. it’s worth taking some time to understand
  89. who traditionally held power,
  90. specifically let’s consider who controls banking,
  91. currency and our very identities.

Additional Readings

  • Kanaskar, M. (2016). The Five D’s of Fintech: Introduction. Max Kanaskar’s Blog. Retrieved from https://maxkanaskar.wordpress.com/2016/03/19/the-five-ds-of-fintech-introduction/
  • Rolph, D. (2017). How Mistrust And Rebellion Are Fueling The Bitcoin Boom. Forbes. Retrieved from https://www.forbes.com/sites/duncanrolph/2017/12/18/how-mistrust-and-rebellion-are-fueling-the-bitcoin-boom/#638fcdd9279c

5.3.1 Who Controls Banking?

  1. – Microsoft founder Bill Gates famously once said,
  2. “banks are dinosaurs, they can be bypassed,”
  3. and that “we need banking but not banks.”
  4. Take a moment and consider those statements.
  5. Do you agree?
  6. Mr. Gates made those comments
  7. in light of the vast advancements in technology
  8. during the 1990s,
  9. knowing that banks needed to adopt new technologies
  10. or find themselves left behind.
  11. Does that sound familiar?
  12. Would it surprise you to hear that Mr. Gates
  13. made these statements back in 1994, nearly 25 years ago?
  14. – Now in some ways, Gates was wrong.
  15. Between 1994 and 2018, bank operating revenue tripled,
  16. earnings quadrupled and equity capital has quintupled.
  17. Now for those who are not in finance,
  18. this simply means that banks have gotten bigger and bigger
  19. and generally more profitable.
  20. But some of his statements
  21. and the concerns they raised among bankers
  22. have clearly begun to happen
  23. if not already being a reality.
  24. For example, an American banker
  25. named William Randle warned that,
  26. “a failure on the part of banks to recognise this threat
  27. to the banking industry from technology
  28. will result in the loss of control of the payment system,
  29. as well as the loss of control
  30. in core customer relationships.”
  31. – Sound familiar?
  32. Some estimate that because of the TechFins
  33. and large digital platforms,
  34. incumbent banks may lose one third
  35. to half of all payment volumes by 2025.
  36. They point to the fact that these established tech giants
  37. already have large user bases,
  38. low online acquisition costs
  39. and big data customer insights,
  40. and they’re increasingly getting internet banking licences.
  41. Some of these TechFins may have preexisting scale
  42. and client reach that is larger
  43. than traditional financial institutions,
  44. think Alibaba, Facebook and Tencent.
  45. And in some parts of the developing world companies
  46. like M-Pesa are allowing people
  47. to largely bypass traditional banks altogether.
  48. – So where does this leave the banks
  49. and what does it entail for the financial system
  50. and banking as a whole?
  51. And where does it leave us as the consumers?

Additional Readings

  • Zack, J. (1995). Is Microsoft’s Bill Gates Right When He Says Banks Are Technology. American Banker. Retrieved from https://www.americanbanker.com/news/is-microsofts-bill-gates-right-when-he-says-banks-are-technology
  • Bank of the Future: The ABCs of Digital Disruption in Finance (2018). Citi GPS: Global Perspectives & Solutions. Retrieved from https://ir.citi.com/CiDxU7p7pAittTmqzfMCS9%2F91IS21vIjJXbn3wjpSEYiTXJ8FvEPRWx8WmmrKNgBSzDi8E2mGOI%3D
  • Rice, X. (2007). Kenya Sets World First With Money Transfers By Mobile. The Guardian. Retrieved from https://www.theguardian.com/money/2007/mar/20/kenya.mobilephones
  • Banks Beware: How People Pay Around The World (2018). CB Insights. Retrieved from https://www.cbinsights.com/research/how-people-pay/

5.3.2 Will Banks Give Up Their Power?

  1. Okay, so Bill Gates said that these banks are dinosaurs,
  2. and they’re gonna supplanted.
  3. So what do you think Dave?
  4. Are they gonna be supplanted by FinTech companies?
  5. – I think it’s interesting, because he said
  6. that people don’t need banks to do banking,
  7. and I think ultimately, that is kind of where
  8. the shift is going.
  9. I can’t think of anybody who enjoys lining up
  10. at a brick and mortar bank, and just waiting in line.
  11. And even the employees that work there,
  12. that’s not a pleasant experience,
  13. and so any kind of friction that exists,
  14. I think one approach that entrepreneurs take,
  15. is trying to minimise that kind of friction,
  16. whatever it may be.
  17. And so I think, going back to Bill Gates’ quote as well,
  18. is that really interesting information about how banks
  19. have become bigger and more profitable,
  20. and larger in scale.
  21. Part of that is, I think a continuation of just,
  22. the wave of efficiencies that we’ve seen
  23. throughout history, right?
  24. As technology evolves, be it from steam power
  25. or electricity, or whatever it is,
  26. then there is eventually some pressure that’s put
  27. on existing cost structures,
  28. and things in theory,
  29. should become more efficient.
  30. And I think as new technology comes into play,
  31. I think many of banks are,
  32. one reason they are absorbing,
  33. or trying to absorb some of those technologies
  34. to reduce cost.
  35. Part of that comes from a cost-efficiency,
  36. laying off people.
  37. Part of that is trying to find technological solutions
  38. to allow them to lay off more people.
  39. And I think that’s led to some of the scale
  40. and profitability that I think
  41. that you were initially referring to.
  42. – Which does get to some of our points about,
  43. the idea that one of the ways
  44. that companies are becoming more efficient,
  45. either through FinTech,
  46. or just technology generally, is by essentially
  47. letting go of people, right?
  48. Which is an ethical question, an overarching question
  49. for this course in and of itself.
  50. And just to highlight the point, the research where
  51. they did show that the growth of the industry,
  52. the financial industry from 1994 to 2018,
  53. did show that a lot of that financial growth was,
  54. I guess, helped by the fact that there are
  55. actually significantly fewer actual bank entities, right?
  56. Meaning, like the brick and mortar shops and things,
  57. right?
  58. – I think a lot of this technological evolution,
  59. there’ll be a lot of stuff we can’t see
  60. as day to day consumers.
  61. But the point that we’ll all be able to see is,
  62. there’ll probably be less and less physical presences.
  63. So going back to this point about all
  64. the great experiences you had lining up
  65. at a traditional bank,
  66. that experience will be,
  67. hopefully less and less.
  68. – And they used FinTech to actually push people
  69. away from that experience.
  70. So a lot of the accounts that you’ll see,
  71. like I have accounts right now, that will actually
  72. charge you, if you go into the bank.
  73. Whereas they’ll let you do online banking,
  74. in unlimited amount, for free.
  75. Generally speaking, right?
  76. They’ll let you go into the bank
  77. a certain number of times before they charge you.
  78. And so over the past decade, they’ve actually
  79. affirmatively been pushing people away
  80. from a business model perspective.
  81. I think the first example that I had from this,
  82. the first non brick and mortar bank
  83. that I worked with
  84. was with something called ING Direct,
  85. where they had this Orange account,
  86. and there was no physical location
  87. anywhere in the world.
  88. At the time, this was quite revolutionary.
  89. They were able to keep a very, very low cost banking,
  90. and therefore give you better interest rates.
  91. And I remember, even before I had moved out of the US,
  92. I was banking through this kind of external system.
  93. But it leads me to another question then.
  94. – But what’s interesting about that is that,
  95. ING Direct was tied to a traditional financial company.
  96. – Correct, that’s exactly my point, right?
  97. So the point that I’m now asking is, okay,
  98. so for those of you that are kind of viewing
  99. FinTech, blockchain, Bitcoin, whatever,
  100. as this decentralising, democratising institution,
  101. or the fact that FinTech is actually gonna pull away
  102. at the sources, the traditional sources of power,
  103. my question for you then, is that kind of a false vision
  104. of the future, and are we instead just seeing
  105. a retrenching of existing power bases,
  106. especially within the financial industry?
  107. And as a quick example, so I think a week or two ago,
  108. JP Morgan recently announced their own kind of foray
  109. into cryptocurrency, right?
  110. There’s so many examples of this,
  111. obviously online banking was not started by non-banks.
  112. Those were banks that did it.
  113. So what do you think?
  114. Yeah, I don’t think those paths are necessarily
  115. mutually exclusive, to be honest.
  116. I think, banks in their current form,
  117. have existing customer bases.
  118. They obviously have technology they can scale.
  119. A lot of the investments that many large commercial
  120. and international kind of investment banks are making,
  121. are into enhancing technology, right?
  122. Their ability to do certain things.
  123. So that could either be in-house development,
  124. or through acquisitions.
  125. So I think that will continue, and as an entrepreneur,
  126. you may have this vision, right, about,
  127. oh we’re gonna produce something.
  128. But ultimately, if someone comes knocking like,
  129. hey we want to acquire this technology
  130. to bolt it on to something we’re doing.
  131. That can be a very attractive proposition
  132. for an entrepreneur, right?
  133. And so I think a lot of the technologies,
  134. will find themselves into established players,
  135. and so part of that will be established players,
  136. being moulded, so to speak,
  137. by this new influx of technology.
  138. But I think to some of the stuff we discussed earlier,
  139. there’s gonna be a whole host of non-traditional
  140. financial players or institutions,
  141. who also kind of get into the game.
  142. And perhaps one example of that is PayPal, right?
  143. – Sure.
  144. – A lot of people look at PayPal as kind of
  145. the first big domino in the sense of trying to get into
  146. this payment space,
  147. that had been particularly dominated
  148. by more mature players, not so savvy with technology,
  149. really didn’t have necessarily a world view
  150. of how they wanted to institute or employ technology
  151. in the work they were doing.
  152. And so, I think we’ll see a bit of that,
  153. or a combination of both.
  154. I don’t think those are mutually exclusive paths.
  155. But increasing, I do think we’ll see, again,
  156. non-financial players, who, based on their user bases,
  157. roll out financial institutions themselves.
  158. So another interesting example from our part in Asia,
  159. is one of the large social messaging platforms in Asia,
  160. is a Korean application called KakaoTalk.
  161. And about a year or two ago,
  162. they rolled out Kakao Bank,
  163. which is effectively online.
  164. There’s a few physical presences,
  165. but almost overwhelmingly,
  166. it’s online only.
  167. And as a result, their cost structure’s vastly different
  168. than a traditional bank.
  169. And so in this particular situation for Kakao Bank,
  170. their online user acquisition,
  171. kind of the growth, was rapid.
  172. And they were able to offer much
  173. more competitive fees,
  174. rates, and other products to customers that otherwise,
  175. would’ve had to only go to a brick and mortar bank.
  176. – Yeah, and so we’re seeing that in other,
  177. and certain a lot of the Chinese apps as well.
  178. Not so much on the cost side,
  179. but from the efficiency standpoint.

Additional Readings

  • Son, H. (2019). JP Morgan is Rolling Out the First US Bank-Backed Cryptocurrency to Transform Payments Business. CNBC News. Retrieved from https://www.cnbc.com/2019/02/13/jp-morgan-is-rolling-out-the-first-us-bank-backed-cryptocurrency-to-transform-payments–.html 
  • Bellens, J. (2018). How a Social Media Firm Created Korea’s Fastest Growing Bank. EY. Retrieved from https://www.ey.com/en_gl/digital/how-social-media-firm-created-south-korea-s-fastest-growing-bank 
  • Kim, B. (2019). Internet Banks Struggling to Stay Afloat. The Korea Times. Retrieved from www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/biz/2019/04/488_266543.html

5.3.3 Should FinTech Replace Banks?

  1. Start of transcript. Skip to the end.
  2. Okay so let’s look then, into the future.
  3. The last question I have is,
  4. specifically on the ethic side of things,
  5. right so if we were,
  6. I want you, for those of you that are out there,
  7. I want you to think of a world, without,
  8. this, kinda traditional banking system.
  9. And there may be some of you,
  10. are kind of salivating at the idea,
  11. that sounds like a great thing,
  12. because again, you hate waiting in line.
  13. But, is it a good thing,
  14. for us to be, so far removed from the banking system?
  15. And so just to give you a bit of context to that,
  16. there are certain institutions within society,
  17. including the medical field,
  18. including the legal field,
  19. where we intentionally require them, for example,
  20. to not incorporate,
  21. to ensure they are a strong
  22. part of these communal systems.
  23. And I’m just curious what you think,
  24. I mean if the banking system is so decentralised,
  25. that you don’t have that corner bank,
  26. that you don’t have someone you can talk to,
  27. to go borrow money from to buy a home.
  28. Right we’ve already talked about AI,
  29. being introduced in this.
  30. If there’s no human component,
  31. do we worry about, ethically speaking,
  32. do we worry about,
  33. the ability for people
  34. to actually access finance,
  35. not just in terms of accessing finance,
  36. but actually like, understanding it,
  37. and really, like I guess,
  38. being in control of their financial future?
  39. – Yeah, so I think that’s a really compelling point,
  40. in the sense that, I think there are a lot of things,
  41. that would go into play here.
  42. One is this kinda education component.
  43. There’s a big push
  44. increasing in many places in the world,
  45. to ensure that, from a young age,
  46. children understand finance.
  47. Not in the sense of like,
  48. Oh let’s go all be Warren Buffet and
  49. invest in stocks, but like,
  50. understanding the purpose of interest, and credit.
  51. And why certain times,
  52. sometimes that can be good,
  53. sometimes that can not be good.
  54. And I think part of that is just,
  55. basic, financial education is important.
  56. Now building on that, to your question.
  57. You know, this is something we will touch on,
  58. throughout the course,
  59. but, kinda the issue of access.
  60. There will be surely be populations,
  61. that will be displaced if they’re not accounted for,
  62. – Yeah.
  63. – in news right.
  64. So either because they can’t,
  65. access technology yet,
  66. or even though their nation or society,
  67. generally accesses the technology for,
  68. because of age or,
  69. other reasons that they can’t.
  70. They’re not as familiar with it,
  71. they don’t feel comfortable with that.
  72. They’ll be, increasingly shut out.
  73. So, that process by it’s very definition,
  74. will need to be transitional,
  75. in order to ensure,
  76. kinda the widest amount of fairness as possible.
  77. But, it is that the ultimate kind of,
  78. end goal of all of this.
  79. I know, to be honest I don’t know.
  80. Like, what is the end state?
  81. What is that, kind of the normative,
  82. end state of all of this?
  83. Where do we really wanna, I don’t think anybody knows.
  84. Right, people just feel like,
  85. “Hey, we’ve had friction in this,
  86. let’s just make it smoother.
  87. Is there a way we could do it faster?”
  88. I mean this is effectively what the motivation is.
  89. I don’t think a lot of people are thinking about,
  90. what are the next order of implications,
  91. if we do this from a cyber perspective.
  92. – I do think that what you’re going to see is,
  93. you’re going to start seeing a lot of what we call:
  94. “pro bono” or “low bono”, meaning like, free services.
  95. Where banks or other nonprofits and
  96. community groups,
  97. are going to form credit unions,
  98. they’re going to form financial institutions,
  99. in order to ensure banking for the poor.
  100. You’re already seeing that, here in Hong Kong.
  101. We’ve talked about foreign domestic workers,
  102. here in Hong Kong,
  103. how 10% of Hong Kong’s working population,
  104. are migrant workers, many of them are underbanked,
  105. and there are multiple sources,
  106. of I guess, traditional banking.
  107. Especially from a credit union standpoint,
  108. where they try to ensure,
  109. they can get access to these things.
  110. Still the penetration is very low,
  111. but I think you’re going to start to see,
  112. as the traditional industry gets,
  113. more and more removed from people on the ground,
  114. especially those that are more poor and disadvantaged,
  115. I think you’re going to start seeing more, and more,
  116. kind of, service providers, on a charitable basis coming.
  117. – And I think the challenge,
  118. with kinda a lot of the stuff we’re discussing,
  119. comes in two ways,
  120. one is: as technology evolves…
  121. How confident are we that kind of these,
  122. stakeholders that are serving, people who are,
  123. will be underbanked,
  124. or not as economically advantaged.
  125. Will they be able to scale up,
  126. in terms of the technology that they need?
  127. You know and a lot of the discussions that I have,
  128. talking to banks, they have no difficulty,
  129. hiring for most roles,
  130. they always have difficulty, hiring for,
  131. in the past was considered IT,
  132. but now, a lot of banks are actually calling them,
  133. they don’t call them “IT” anymore, they call them like,
  134. “engineering”, or “technologist”, or you know,
  135. to make it, have it a different veneer right,
  136. a different polish.
  137. – Well that’s programming, right?
  138. You’ve got the privacy side,
  139. you’ve got the security side, right,
  140. you’ve got, they’re building out new tools,
  141. including the blockchain type stuff, right.
  142. There’s a lot of things.
  143. – Yeah, and so what they found is, a lot of these banks,
  144. particularly in the US, and Europe,
  145. they’re competing directly for the same talent,
  146. that maybe Google, or Facebook is competing for.
  147. And so this is the challenge that they face, so to that–
  148. – Well especially because those graduates
  149. don’t think of going to J.P. Morgan,
  150. they don’t think of going to HSBC–
  151. – Immediately!
  152. – They’re thinking okay yeah,
  153. there’s no like Silicon Valley right,
  154. they’re thinking: Google, they’re going to Facebook,
  155. they’re going to Netflix.
  156. – That’s one question, I think that is,
  157. that’s to be determined.
  158. And the second I think which is more broad,
  159. which I think pervades many aspects of this course,
  160. are the idea of regulation.
  161. So historically we’ve had, financial regulators,
  162. and we’ve had regulators over,
  163. certain aspects of communication industry.
  164. Now, is that going to change
  165. as we have different players that,
  166. start occupying the finance base.
  167. – But we know it will.
  168. The question is, how yeah.
  169. – Yeah and it’s,
  170. so if you had a TechFin,
  171. that came from non-financial industry,
  172. come into to do, something, traditional banking,
  173. maybe non brick-and-mortar, just online.
  174. Will they be doubly regulated?
  175. I mean how will that work?
  176. Particularly when the regulatory regimes,
  177. are probably not consistent, as well as,
  178. global in nature.
  179. And so then you kind of get a lot of interesting,
  180. and kind of frustrating friction that will occur,
  181. and I think that will take a long to, unravel,
  182. as people try to figure that out.
  183. – Yeah, so I think these are a lot of the questions,
  184. that society is going to have to kinda entertain,
  185. and hopefully answer, over time.
  186. One of the things that I often think about is,
  187. should we even consider banks as traditional banks,
  188. even now, or have they really already morphed
  189. into essentially technology firms?
  190. For a lot of the banks that I know,
  191. and a lot of the people that I know work in them,
  192. they actually have as many, or more IT professionals,
  193. as they do actual bankers, and finance professionals.
  194. And so I think, as we continue to move forward,
  195. some of the questions that we need to consider,
  196. are, how we as society want to engage,
  197. on a personal level with these institutions,
  198. and I guess on a more simple question, you know,
  199. do you hate going to your bank as much as we do?
  200. Do you see this as a positive thing,
  201. or a negative thing?
  202. We’re curious.

Additional Readings

  • Beyond Fintech: A Pragmatic Assessment Of Disruptive Potential In Financial Services (2017). World Economic Forum. Retrieved from http://www3.weforum.org/docs/Beyond_Fintech_-_A_Pragmatic_Assessment_of_Disruptive_Potential_in_Financial_Services.pdf
  • Hickson, J. (2018). Fintech is Disrupting Big Banks, But Here’s What It Still Needs to Learn From Them. The Next Web. Retrieved from https://thenextweb.com/contributors/2018/05/20/fintech-is-disrupting-big-banks-but-heres-what-it-still-needs-to-learn-from-them/
  1.  

5.4.1 Who Controls Currency?

  1. – We already discussed control of currency quite a lot
  2. earlier in this module, so we won’t dwell on it
  3. for too long here.
  4. But it’s worth a reminder that for millennia
  5. governments have exclusively controlled their currency.
  6. – But as we’ve already noted, government control of currency
  7. in the traditional sense is loosening somewhat
  8. because of FinTech innovations.
  9. For example, governments usually don’t have control
  10. over crypto-currencies and have been frantically
  11. enacting legislation to help them control the use
  12. of these new products.
  13. – The reality is that physical currency
  14. has a lot of drawbacks.
  15. The use of physical currency is difficult.
  16. It can be heavy, it’s expensive, at times, to produce
  17. and it can even lead to increased crime.
  18. For example, in 2016 the Wall Street Journal showed that
  19. it cost about 1.15 cents to produce one penny.
  20. And nickels, which are worth five cents,
  21. cost seven cents to make.
  22. How crazy is that?
  23. And it’s not just a production cost.
  24. It is estimated that in the US alone
  25. over 60 million dollars worth of coins are lost
  26. out of circulation every year.
  27. Maybe some of that money is hidden in the cushions
  28. of your couch.
  29. – Now as an ironic twist, perhaps the best portrayal
  30. of the inefficiencies of physical money can be seen
  31. by the people who use it
  32. for the purpose of being inefficient.
  33. You may have come across stories about people who bring
  34. trucks or wheelbarrows full of coins to settle fines
  35. as a way to show their frustration
  36. or to punish the recipient of the payment,
  37. knowing that it will take them hours to count
  38. every single coin.
  39. – With some of these challenges in mind, perhaps there are
  40. some benefits in moving towards a more cashless society.
  41. In a similar vein, maybe our definition of money should
  42. evolve by removing currency from the exclusive control
  43. of national governments.
  44. – But will a cashless society block some people from the
  45. financial sector completely?
  46. As you may recall from the China street vendor example
  47. in the beginning of this module, since I didn’t have the
  48. WeChat payment app on my phone, I was unable to
  49. simply purchase breakfast.
  50. And recent stories have shown that some disadvantaged
  51. populations in China, especially some of the elderly
  52. in China, have been largely blocked from participating in
  53. their vast digital economy.
  54. And those that are kept away from these elements
  55. of the digital economy might even be further distanced
  56. when crypto-currencies begin to challenge
  57. fiat currencies around the world.
  58. – With these various developments, trends and changes
  59. occurring around the world today,
  60. what kind of world are we heading towards?
  61. Will governments largely retain control of currencies
  62. or will block chain and crypto currencies not backed
  63. by government one day become the new norm?
  64. What unintended consequences may arise from the push towards
  65. a completely digital financial landscape?

Additional Readings

  • Sparshott, J. (2016). The Penny  Cost More to Make Than It’s Worth, Again. The Wall Street Journal. Retrieved from https://www.wsj.com/articles/the-penny-cost-more-to-make-than-its-worth-again-1482886367
  • Ryan, J. (2016). We Toss $62 Million of Loose Change Every Year. Bloomberg. Retrieved from https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-10-12/trash-piles-yield-treasure-as-sifters-seek-sooty-coins-in-ashes
  • Mullin, K. (2018). China’s Cashless Economy Threatens to Leave Its Elderly—And Their Money—Behind. Quartz. Retrieved from https://qz.com/1435320/chinas-cashless-economy-is-leaving-its-elderly-behind/

5.4.2 Should We Have Physical Currency?

  1. So one question to consider
  2. is a really fundamental one about currency.
  3. Should we have it?
  4. And if so, who should control it?
  5. So what do you think Dave?
  6. – Yeah I mean it’s a great question.
  7. I wouldn’t have thought this, years ago,
  8. that it’d be a relevant question to be honest
  9. but now it’s a legitimate question
  10. and certain governments are really asking this.
  11. You’ve got developed countries,
  12. I think it was Sweden,
  13. announced that they wanted to go to a cashless society,
  14. now they’re kind of pulling back a little bit
  15. and realising they didn’t think it through completely.
  16. You’ve got other places,
  17. we talked about Marshall Islands
  18. maybe having an official currency,
  19. would be crypto or crypto-based.
  20. The reality is, it’s probably a premature question.
  21. The other reality is,
  22. no matter how you and I answer this,
  23. sovereign governments are gonna be deciding
  24. the answer to this question.
  25. So I think maybe the more relevant question to me
  26. is do I think governments will give up
  27. a physical fiat currency?
  28. I think the answer is no.
  29. I certainly thing the US government
  30. is definitely not going to give that up,
  31. it provides them so much influence
  32. and so much power around the world.
  33. Other governments like say China,
  34. they use currency as a way to kind of control
  35. their state-run economy which does make sense.
  36. And so I think this is probably
  37. not going to be a question that is gonna be
  38. realistically considered in most countries any time soon
  39. and I would say it’s quite the opposite in fact,
  40. I would say they’re probably going to be
  41. very opposed to the idea.
  42. And you have I think, the World Bank
  43. when Marshall Islands was
  44. proposing the cryptocurrency
  45. as a potential currency,
  46. they specifically warned them against that
  47. saying it would drive down their donations
  48. and other things
  49. because other countries wouldn’t like that.
  50. – I think you’re right.
  51. I think the idea of influence which you mentioned,
  52. particularly for large economic countries
  53. that have large economic influence,
  54. say like the Unites States,
  55. a large part of that is driven by
  56. the fact that the US Dollar is a widely accepted currency.
  57. So if we think about the ability
  58. for Unites States’ laws and regulations
  59. to permeate the rest of the world
  60. and banks and other parts of the world
  61. having to follow these regulations,
  62. a large part of that is the fact
  63. that they transact in US Dollars
  64. which allows the United States to extend the arm
  65. of regulation beyond its borders.
  66. So for sure, they don’t wanna give that up
  67. and then collectively something like the European Union,
  68. the fact that they’re using Euros
  69. as opposed to individual state currencies now
  70. I think provides them a little bit more, as a block,
  71. some influence versus when they were
  72. disparate countries using their own currencies.
  73. And so the idea of influence I think is right.
  74. I think ultimately what we’ll probably see,
  75. outside of these instances, like the Marshall Islands,
  76. which are kind of small
  77. and somewhat isolated economies,
  78. is I definitely think there’ll be a move towards
  79. kind of hybrid type of systems over time.
  80. Probably in our lifetime.
  81. – Cashless payment systems.
  82. – Probably in our time.
  83. Most of that will likely be backed, I think,
  84. by some level of fiat currency.
  85. And I think the reason we probably
  86. don’t wanna go to a completely,
  87. a system that is completely devoid of any currencies,
  88. inclusion issues which we’ve talked about.
  89. Inevitably if you do that,
  90. then you will exclude people
  91. who for whatever reasons are not able to access
  92. the digital technology.
  93. – Or don’t want to.
  94. – Or don’t want to.
  95. – Some people wanna stay off the grid.
  96. – That’s a challenge.
  97. – Just one thing to add again for those
  98. that are maybe not as commonly
  99. in a developing country,
  100. actually that physical currency
  101. is actually one of the ways
  102. that developing countries control the use
  103. and spending of their currency.
  104. So they don’t let it leave in large quantities.
  105. They don’t allow the free conversion of their currency
  106. because they don’t, for example,
  107. let’s say someone is corrupt and steals a billion dollars
  108. or they make several billion dollars in a real estate deal
  109. and then they immediately pull that out,
  110. they wanna make sure they can control
  111. the use of that currency.
  112. So having a physical currency
  113. is actually a way that, say a country like China,
  114. has kind of controlled their development.
  115. – And managed money supply
  116. and things like that, absolutely.

Additional Readings

  • Savage, M. (2019). Sweden’s Cashless Experiment: Is It Too Much Too Fast? NPR. Retrieved from https://www.npr.org/2019/02/11/691334123/swedens-cashless-experiment-is-it-too-much-too-fast
  • Going Cashless: What Can We Learn From Sweden’s Experience? [email protected]. Retrieved from https://knowledge.wharton.upenn.edu/article/going-cashless-can-learn-swedens-experience/
  • Alderman, L. (2018). Sweden’s Push to Get Rid of Cash Has Some Saying, ‘Not So Fast’. The New York Times. Retrieved from https://www.nytimes.com/2018/11/21/business/sweden-cashless-society.html
  • Baraniuk, C. (2018). Marshall Islands Warned Against Adopting Digital Currency. BBC News. Retrieved from https://www.bbc.com/news/amp/technology-45485685
  • Krishnan, D. (2018). What Happened after India Eliminated Cash. Strategy+Business. Retrieved from https://www.strategy-business.com/article/What-Happened-after-India-Eliminated-Cash
  • Detrixhe, J. (2019). A Cashless Society is Dangerously Disruptive for the Poor, Elderly, and Homeless. Quartz. Retrieved from https://qz.com/1516563/cashless-societies-are-harmful-for-the-poor-elderly-and-homeless/

5.5.1 Who Controls Identity?

  1. – Okay, so, if somebody asks you to identify yourself,
  2. how would you do it?
  3. Imagine that you’re driving a little too quickly
  4. and you got pulled over by the police,
  5. or you’re travelling from one country to another
  6. and crossing through immigration,
  7. how do you prove that you are in fact you?
  8. – So, I’m not sure if you were following me this weekend,
  9. (David B. laughs)
  10. ’cause this is eerily reminiscent of something that happened
  11. this weekend. – Were you travelling?
  12. – I was driving this weekend
  13. and got pulled over by the police and got this ticket
  14. which is in my pocket
  15. because I have to go pay this ticket later today.
  16. – Did they ask you for ID?
  17. – They did ask me for ID.
  18. I produced the ID that we have in Hong Kong
  19. and issued my driver’s licence
  20. for them to confirm who I was.
  21. And that’s normally how we would do it,
  22. right? – Yeah.
  23. – I mean, based on what we’re talking about.
  24. We are issued, wherever we live in the world,
  25. some form of government ID.
  26. And in a lot of situations,
  27. multiple forms of government ID.
  28. Identity card, passport, driver’s licence.
  29. – This happened to me too.
  30. This weekend, for a better reason, (laughs)
  31. I was in Southern China,
  32. dealing with some stuff up there in Shenzhen,
  33. and same thing.
  34. You cross over the border,
  35. not it’s actually quite advanced,
  36. anyone that’s crossed the border
  37. between Shenzhen and Hong Kong, you know,
  38. there’s biometrics, they take your fingerprints,
  39. they take a facial scan,
  40. they look at your identity documents still.
  41. It’s actually very regulated.
  42. And interestingly enough,
  43. if anyone has ever Googled me,
  44. you’ll see that my hair or facial hair often changes,
  45. so they always sit there and stare at the passport
  46. trying to identify– – Make sure it’s you.
  47. – Yeah, make sure it’s me.
  48. Like, who is this person in front of me?
  49. But you’re right,
  50. this is what happens to people on a daily basis
  51. in some instances.
  52. – Like us, you probably already have
  53. an official government-issued ID.
  54. But you may be surprised to learn
  55. that according to the World Bank,
  56. over 1.1 billion people around the world
  57. lack any officially recognised proof of their existence.
  58. In fact, this is so prevalent and critical
  59. that United Nations’ Sustainable Development Goals 16.9
  60. is a goal that hopes to ensure everyone around the world
  61. has access to a legal form of identity.
  62. That sounds crazy, right?
  63. It means that one out of six or seven people
  64. do not have any form of official ID.
  65. – Without any forms of identification,
  66. it can be challenging
  67. to access institutions and opportunities
  68. that many of us take for granted,
  69. such as health care, social protection,
  70. education and finance,
  71. not to mention travel,
  72. driving, voting, employment, et cetera.
  73. Think about opening a bank account.
  74. Without any official documents
  75. to prove that you are you,
  76. chances are that you’ll not be allowed to open an account.
  77. And then again a bank account may be another pre-requisite
  78. for a lot of other things,
  79. such as getting a job, securing a longterm place to live.
  80. Overall, people without official ID
  81. risk being marginalised and excluded from society.
