  82. – [David L.] And in the case of large refugee crisis,
  83. this can turn into a global political concern.
  84. According to the United Nations,
  85. it is estimated
  86. that 80% of the roughly 65 million refugees in the world
  87. do not have any form of official documentation
  88. to prove their identity.
  89. And while there are sadly many examples to consider,
  90. let’s briefly look at one recent example.
  91. The Syrian refugee crisis.
  92. – [David B.] Since the Syrian Civil War started in 2011,
  93. more than five million people have fled their country,
  94. often having to leave their belongings behind,
  95. including their official identity documents.
  96. In fact, there’ve been reports saying
  97. that 70% of the refugees lack basic identity documents.
  98. – [David L.] To address this issue and provide aid,
  99. the World Food Programme operated by the United Nations
  100. piloted a project called Building Blocks
  101. in the Syrian refugee camp Zaatari in Jordan,
  102. where they began utilising biometrics and blockchain
  103. to facilitate aid and to identify individuals.
  104. To be eligible to receive assistance,
  105. refugees have to record their biometrics
  106. which is then stored on the UN database
  107. and they are allocated an account
  108. on the ethereal blockchain.
  109. – [David B.] Purchases are then made
  110. through scanning their iris in their eyes at local shops,
  111. which confirms their identity and facilitates payment.
  112. No cash, card, or mobile is needed
  113. for the transaction to take place.
  114. – So, why should people like you and us,
  115. who already have government-issued IDs,
  116. you have your driver’s licence, maybe a passport,
  117. why should you even care about this?
  118. How will this impact you?
  119. The reality is that governments in most parts of the world
  120. are developing more and more of this technology
  121. into the concept of managing and controlling identity.
  122. This is an important question for all of us to consider
  123. as we think about the impact
  124. such technology will have on all of us.
  125. – Okay, so, what do you think?
  126. Do you think that moving forward
  127. these non-government-issued IDs
  128. will become the new norm?
  129. Or do you think this is more of an exceptional situation
  130. and that this type of change
  131. the pace of change won’t happen so quickly?
  132. And do you think that governments may accept
  133. outside, private, NGO-created identification systems
  134. or are they always gonna wanna control and create
  135. their own ID systems?

Additional Readings

  • 1.1 Billion ‘Invisible’ People without ID are Priority for new High Level Advisory Council on Identification for Development. World Bank. Retrieved from https://www.worldbank.org/en/news/press-release/2017/10/12/11-billion-invisible-people-without-id-are-priority-for-new-high-level-advisory-council-on-identification-for-development
  • Santiso, C. (2018). Will Blockchain Disrupt Government Corruption? Stanford Social Innovation Review. Retrieved from https://ssir.org/articles/entry/will_blockchain_disrupt_government_corruption# 
  • Aburass, S. (2017). Syrian Refugees’ Documentation Crisis. Norwegian Refugee Council. Retrieved from https://www.nrc.no/news/2017/january/syrian-refugees-documentation-crisis/ 
  • Blockchain for Zero Hunger. (2019). World Food Programme. Retrieved from https://innovation.wfp.org/project/building-blocks
  • Juskalian, R. (2018). Inside the Jordan Refugee Camp That Runs on Blockchain. MIT Technology Review. Retrieved from https://www.technologyreview.com/s/610806/inside-the-jordan-refugee-camp-that-runs-on-blockchain/

5.5.2 What Is the Future of IDs?

  1. Obviously, the situation in Syria
  2. is quite compelling,
  3. and raises a lot of interesting questions
  4. that, perhaps, from one person’s perspective,
  5. who’s sitting at home, in a non-war torn situation,
  6. thinks that, well, that’s really sad for them,
  7. but how does that impact me?
  8. But, a lot of those technologies that they’re using,
  9. I think, do have broader ramifications,
  10. so maybe that’s something we need to take a second
  11. to discuss,
  12. and maybe unpack a little bit.
  13. – Yeah, so on the one hand,
  14. for those, for example, that are familiar with
  15. the refugee crisis
  16. as it spilled out of Europe, right.
  17. So we’re both American, as an example,
  18. a big part of the presidential debate
  19. from the last election
  20. revolved around Syrian refugees, and other refugees,
  21. and so there was a lot of acrimony,
  22. maybe even some fear that was stoked
  23. about how do we know who these people are?
  24. Is it possible there’s terrorists that are using this system
  25. to get into another country?
  26. And a lot of it boiled down to this idea of identity.
  27. So I think, these questions,
  28. very realistically, do permeate borders,
  29. but I think, to a point that you made earlier,
  30. it’s not just that this is an isolated experience
  31. in Syria, or as it impacts, places outside of Syria,
  32. but more specifically, these types of technologies,
  33. the biometrics in particular, are really permeating
  34. both national and private ID systems
  35. for everyone across the globe.
  36. Right?
  37. So I mean, you’ve crossed the border recently, I’m sure,
  38. like, are you seeing more and more biometrics
  39. being used at borders,
  40. to kind of control who is coming in
  41. and who is coming out?
  42. – Well yeah, sure, I think, it’s not just
  43. at the border, right?
  44. I mean, that’s probably
  45. the situation, the context where we see it the most,
  46. where we’re most cognizant of it.
  47. But, you know, every day I see my students
  48. use biometrics when they log into
  49. their computers or phones.
  50. – Yeah, thumbprint.
  51. – Increasingly, biometrics,
  52. as a component of identity
  53. will just increase over time.
  54. And, how we want to employ that,
  55. or how we want to control that will be important.
  56. Because, we’ve already moved just from fingerprint,
  57. now we have
  58. many new technologies now
  59. that do facial recognition too.
  60. – Yeah.
  61. – Right, and so, the underlying technology
  62. of that is biometric by nature.
  63. And so, how do we want to control that,
  64. particularly when
  65. that could lead to some unintended consequences
  66. with respect to who owns data,
  67. who’s monitoring who,
  68. who’s controlling that, how is that being stored,
  69. and, kind of the questions that pop out
  70. when you open that box.
  71. – So, some of you may have heard some stories
  72. relating to these types of biometric IDs,
  73. including using, say, Apple as an example,
  74. facial recognition software, et cetera.
  75. I think,
  76. there’s an interesting dichotomy.
  77. We talk about culture lag a lot.
  78. Some people are terrified
  79. of these new identification systems.
  80. They want to hold onto the passport,
  81. they want a physical representation.
  82. Other people are very very quick to kind of shift over,
  83. they say they’re more accurate,
  84. or safer, or whatever.
  85. One of the things that we saw with,
  86. just using Apple as an example is that,
  87. using facial recognition in your software,
  88. there was actually bias
  89. in the initial programmes for that,
  90. where, Asian faces, for example,
  91. were not identifiable, and so there was this kind of,
  92. people with different faces,
  93. could unlock somebody else’s phone,
  94. because the algorithm couldn’t recognise their faces
  95. being separate, right?
  96. So there’s the issue with
  97. bad data in gets a bad result, we know that.
  98. But then, even if there’s a small failure percentage,
  99. let’s say just one or two or three percent, right?
  100. Among refugees in Syria, for example,
  101. that would have represented hundreds of thousands
  102. of people,
  103. or across the globe, it’s the same thing.
  104. So if you have a bad password,
  105. you change the password, right?
  106. But if you have, the fingerprint doesn’t match up,
  107. how do you go through
  108. and actually change that process?
  109. Like, are we seeing, within the financial industry,
  110. or in terms of the technology,
  111. how are they addressing
  112. these types of very real, kind of human,
  113. or cultural challenges,
  114. as these technologies are developing?
  115. – Yeah, I think part of,
  116. at least, what I’ve seen,
  117. and what I’ve experienced, is,
  118. at least now, even with biometric data,
  119. and even, generally, statistically speaking,
  120. fairly low failure rates, relatively speaking.
  121. It’s usually a combination, right?
  122. So there’s biometric data, plus, something else
  123. that collectively creates your identity profile.
  124. I think that will continue to be the standard,
  125. so to speak, right now,
  126. as more and more companies,
  127. and even governments and nation states
  128. employ this technology.
  129. The combination of it kind of creates
  130. a bit of redundancy,
  131. just in case you do face those,
  132. either technology sided issues,
  133. where the programming is a bit deficient,
  134. or not up to spec yet,
  135. or, a situation where
  136. certain aspects of identity have changed.
  137. And we know certain aspects of
  138. biometric data can change.
  139. Or, fingerprints change, and things like that.
  140. And so,
  141. the redundant aspect of having
  142. multiple forms of identity
  143. on top of each other to create the full identity picture,
  144. I think that’s probably gonna be the approach
  145. that people take,
  146. and I think, other forms of biometric data,
  147. they get more and more advanced,
  148. will also be employed as well.
  149. – Mm.

Additional Readings

  • Pandya, J. (2019). Hacking Our Identity: The Emerging Threats From Biometric Technology. Forbes. Retrieved from https://www.forbes.com/sites/cognitiveworld/2019/03/09/hacking-our-identity-the-emerging-threats-from-biometric-technology/#177961785682
  • National Research Council (2010). Biometric Recognition: Challenges and Opportunities. Washington, DC: The National Academies Press. https://doi.org/10.17226/12720. 
  • Indrajit, S. (2017). The Cybersecurity Risks of Using Biometric Data to Issue Refugee Aid. The Henry M. Jackson School of International Studies. Retrieved from https://jsis.washington.edu/news/cybersecurity-risks-using-biometric-data-issue-refugee-aid/
  • Aitken, R. (2018). Blockchain To The Rescue Creating A ‘New Future’ For Digital Identities. Forbes. Retrieved from https://www.forbes.com/sites/rogeraitken/2018/01/07/blockchain-to-the-rescue-creating-a-new-future-for-digital-identities/#674acdac5492
  • White, O., Madgavkar, A., Manyika, J., Mahajan, D., Bughin, J., McCarthy, M., Sperling, O. (2019). Digital Identification: A Key to Inclusive Growth. McKinsey Global Institute. Retrieved from https://www.mckinsey.com/business-functions/digital-mckinsey/our-insights/Digital-identification-A-key-to-inclusive-growth

5.5.3 Will Governments Give Up Control Over Our Identities?

  1. Okay, so the underlying question that we’re talking about
  2. in this entire module is whether or not FinTech
  3. can create a more decentralised system
  4. that would allow, in this particular instance,
  5. an external, maybe private organisation
  6. like a UN body,
  7. to create a globally recognised
  8. or cross-border kind of recognised ID system,
  9. or whether the entrenched powers
  10. within city governments,
  11. they’re going to want to kind of double down,
  12. and utilise this own technology for their own
  13. kind of internal systems, right.
  14. So I think the underlying question
  15. that a lot of people, myself included, think about is
  16. from a national ID standpoint,
  17. is the utilisation of these FinTech technologies
  18. about speed and efficiency,
  19. or is it about more security,
  20. I guess more lack of privacy
  21. and kind of controlling people.
  22. Now before he gets into this question, again,
  23. just use Hong Kong as an example,
  24. one of my other favourite things about living in
  25. Hong Kong other than the Octopus card
  26. which I showed you earlier,
  27. is that the Hong Kong ID system that we have
  28. is a chip integrated system and it makes it very quick,
  29. very easy to go in and out of the airport.
  30. And so as I travel, Hong Kong is probably
  31. the simplest border that I’ve ever crossed personally,
  32. and it makes going in and out very, very simple.
  33. For years, I saw that as a great advantage,
  34. but I do wonder, would I think the same thing
  35. as these biometrics are being introduced more broadly
  36. for a government maybe that I trust a little bit less,
  37. let’s say, right.
  38. What do you think?
  39. – Well, I think, you know, before we jump into that,
  40. taking a step back.
  41. I think it’s quite clear that that will be the case.
  42. That the–
  43. – Meaning, they’re gonna be integrating more and more.
  44. – More and more, right.
  45. So, you know, sometimes when you travel,
  46. you go to a country where they maybe not use that,
  47. it’s very traditional.
  48. Passport, look at the picture, stamp, and go through.
  49. I would say increasing many of the countries
  50. that I’ve been to in the last few years,
  51. though however, even if they were so-called
  52. developing countries,
  53. have incorporated some level of biometrics,
  54. even if it’s just a fingerprint scan
  55. into this identity portfolio, so to speak,
  56. that they’re constructing.
  57. And that would just continue unabated.
  58. That is the tie that’s coming in,
  59. that’s not gonna roll back out anytime soon.
  60. – Yeah.
  61. – Now I think to the broader question then of,
  62. how should that be controlled or regulated.
  63. You know, that’s really difficult to say
  64. because I think to your point, you know,
  65. there are definitely certainly countries out there
  66. that may use it solely for an efficiency standpoint.
  67. It’s just quicker to process people
  68. through immigration this way.
  69. – Right.
  70. – But I would say most countries will use it
  71. for a variety of different needs as things arise.
  72. Because once that data is there,
  73. it’s the rare organisation that can
  74. put in the brakes themselves to say,
  75. “Okay, we just wanna use data for this purpose
  76. and this purpose alone.”
  77. I think it’s unrealistic and probably a bit naive
  78. for us to think that data will not be used
  79. for other purposes.
  80. – Yeah.
  81. – Despite what anybody may say at the moment.
  82. – Yeah, and getting back from a regulatory standpoint,
  83. one of the things that we talked about before,
  84. if you recall, is who then is liable
  85. if privacy is breached, if the data gets out.
  86. One of the challenges with this in terms
  87. of the ID standpoint is that you have
  88. a national government that, you know, for example
  89. has a hack or breaches data.
  90. It’s often very difficult as the person
  91. who had your privacy invaded to then have
  92. any type of redress, right.
  93. They’re typically sovereign entities
  94. and so it’s difficult to go through.
  95. Okay, so for you, all the participants out there,
  96. what do you think?
  97. Do you think that at some point,
  98. maybe in the next 10 or 20 years,
  99. there will be kind of a globally accepted
  100. non-government issued identification,
  101. or do you think that governments are gonna
  102. utilise this technology and double down
  103. and use it to kinda control their own borders even more.

Additional Readings

  • Identity in a Digital World: A New Chapter in the Social Contract (2018). World Economic Forum. Retrieved from http://www3.weforum.org/docs/WEF_INSIGHT_REPORT_Digital%20Identity.pdf
  • Goel, V. (2018). ‘Big Brother’ in India Requires Fingerprint Scans for Food, Phones and Finances. The New York Times. Retrieved from https://www.nytimes.com/2018/04/07/technology/india-id-aadhaar.html
  • Goel, V. (2018). India’s Top Court Limits Sweep of Biometric ID Program. The New York Times. Retrieved from https://www.nytimes.com/2018/09/26/technology/india-id-aadhaar-supreme-court.html
  • Sullivan, K., & Sands, G. (2019). Feds Say Photos of Travelers Compromised in Data Breach. CNN. Retrieved from https://edition.cnn.com/2019/06/10/politics/customs-and-border-protection-images-travelers-data-breach/index.html

5.6.1 Inclusion vs. Exclusion

  1. – Okay, so far in this module
  2. we’ve talked about power and control,
  3. in particular control over banking, currency,
  4. and our identities.
  5. We’ve also outlined how scandals and problems
  6. have caused governments
  7. and traditional financial institutions
  8. to lose consumer trust,
  9. further pushing FinTech innovation.
  10. – And we know that FinTech innovators
  11. are pushing for democratisation of finance,
  12. which largely centres on bringing financial products
  13. to the poor and disadvantaged.
  14. Through disaggregation,
  15. people are getting more information about financial products
  16. such as life insurance and mortgages
  17. so that they’re making more informed and efficient decisions
  18. to the increased opportunities that they now have.
  19. – And through disintermediation and decentralisation,
  20. FinTech is both cutting out the middle man
  21. who normally controlled financial transactions
  22. and giving control to multiple players simultaneously,
  23. respectively.
  24. Finally, by de-biasing finance,
  25. finance is hopefully removing traditional biases
  26. like race or gender
  27. from the process
  28. and making finance easier to understand and access.
  29. – The aggregation of these five principles
  30. is commonly summarised by one word.
  31. Inclusion.
  32. The drive towards greater financial inclusion
  33. is one of the key elements that makes FinTech so compelling
  34. and is making system-wide impact possible.
  35. For example,
  36. there are currently
  37. approximately 2 billion people in the world
  38. who are unbanked.
  39. Well, the World Bank has a goal
  40. to ensure they all have access to banking by 2020.
  41. And while that may still seem like a crazy, audacious goal,
  42. because of finance innovations it’s possible.
  43. – [David B.] According to the World Bank,
  44. “Financial inclusion means that,” quote,
  45. “individuals and businesses have access
  46. “to useful and affordable financial products and services
  47. “that meet their needs,
  48. “transactions, payments, savings, credit, and insurance,
  49. “delivered in a responsible and sustainable way.”
  50. Close quote.
  51. – Overall, FinTech has the potential
  52. to benefit undeserved communities and individuals
  53. through a large array of features,
  54. like cross-border remittances,
  55. payment technologies
  56. using digital know-your-customer processes,
  57. alternative credit scoring,
  58. e-wallets, mobile money, microfinance, crowdfunding,
  59. and more.
  60. And the Global Findex database by the World Bank
  61. has shown how the share of adults holding a bank account
  62. has risen from 51% in 2011
  63. to 69% in 2017.
  64. That’s amazing and exciting
  65. when you consider that having access to banking
  66. is one of the key factors for raising people out of poverty.
  67. – And access to finance increasingly means
  68. access to the Internet and all things digital.
  69. This is perhaps most evident in China,
  70. where 890 million people
  71. are now using mobile phone payment apps
  72. and the transition to a cashless society
  73. has happened rapidly.
  74. These apps have a whole array of services
  75. that you can access with a few clicks on your phone.
  76. But the switch to a digital economy
  77. can also exacerbate exclusion.
  78. For example, in China it has widely been reported
  79. that the elderly are struggling to keep up
  80. with rapid technological advancements.
  81. As a result,
  82. what is supposed to make life easier for these citizens
  83. in some ways has done the opposite,
  84. particularly the 118 million elderly who live alone.
  85. All right, so, what do you think?
  86. Is it better to have an efficient financial system
  87. where everything moves online, everything’s digital,
  88. and it makes things more efficient, more smooth,
  89. and cheaper,
  90. or are we concerned enough about say the elderly or the poor
  91. or those that are disadvantaged
  92. not having access to a system?
  93. So, for example,
  94. should a store be forced
  95. to receive and accept cash payments,
  96. or can we go completely cashless in society?

Additional Readings

  • The Global Findex Database 2017 (2018). The World Bank. Retrieved from https://globalfindex.worldbank.org/#GF-ReportChapters
  • Financial Inclusion. The World Bank. Retrieved from www.worldbank.org/en/topic/financialinclusion/overview#1
  • da Silva, L. A. (2018). Financial Inclusion in the Age of FinTech: A Paradigm Shift. BIS. Retrieved from https://www.bis.org/speeches/sp181106.htm
  • Wang, S. (2019). China’s Technology Revolution is Leaving Its Senior Citizens Behind. CNN. Retrieved from https://edition.cnn.com/2019/03/08/asia/china-senior-technology-struggle-intl/index.html

5.6.2 Should Vendors be Forced to Accept Cash?

  1. Okay so we’ve kinda explained that there’s this paradox,
  2. especially using China as an example, let’s say,
  3. where there’s a push towards kind of a cashless society,
  4. which in many ways is more efficient.
  5. But it also means it’s more difficult
  6. for certain people to access that cashless society, right?
  7. – Yeah.
  8. – So, in the case of,
  9. let’s say, the poor, the elderly,
  10. there’s reports now coming out of China
  11. that some of them are actually having difficulty
  12. accessing the information technology.
  13. – Or this digital,
  14. kind of cashless system.
  15. So what do you think?
  16. Now conversely,
  17. I guess just to lay the table even more completely,
  18. you may not realise that there’s actually
  19. the opposite thing happening
  20. in other more developed parts of the world,
  21. the U.S. as an example.
  22. So, very advanced cities of New York, Philadelphia,
  23. I think Boston in Massachusetts.
  24. They actually have the exact opposite rules.
  25. They actually have laws that say a store,
  26. or a vendor, must accept cash,
  27. and the reasons why they say they must accept cash
  28. is because, if they don’t,
  29. then it would make it difficult
  30. for the poor, let’s say,
  31. to access those commodities.
  32. In fact, those laws stem back all the way to the 1970s,
  33. when credit cards first came around, right?
  34. So you have this kind of dichotomy where
  35. on the one hand it’s more efficient, maybe even safer,
  36. but on the other hand, it kind of excludes people.
  37. What do we do about this?
  38. – Well, me personally, I think
  39. from both a practical perspective,
  40. as well as more of a kind of a normative perspective,
  41. I think it’s difficult to envision a situation
  42. where you go completely cashless in a lot of places.
  43. Partly because of the inclusion,
  44. kind of issues that you raised initiating your question.
  45. But from a practical perspective of,
  46. I don’t think governments are incentivized
  47. to say, hey, we don’t want you to accept,
  48. or we want to make it okay to not accept legal tender.
  49. – Mm.
  50. – To satisfy bills.
  51. – I think that’s a challenge
  52. when it comes to these kind of things.
  53. So, fundamentally I think there’s a government incentive
  54. to encourage cash payments, or at least as an option.
  55. So I don’t think these are necessarily mutually exclusive.
  56. I think as a package they need to be
  57. considered together.
  58. – As an interesting side note,
  59. I mean one of the examples that we provided in this,
  60. is the idea for tourists, for example,
  61. right if I was to go to China, as you and I have,
  62. or if we go to Myanmar, other locations,
  63. just as a tourist, whether you’re rich or not,
  64. you can have difficulty accessing the economy.
  65. I’m curious like, in a cashless society,
  66. how would a tourist access that market?
  67. I don’t really know, is there a solution to that?
  68. – Well, I don’t know either.
  69. I think there are parts, we try to access it.
  70. In countries that have fairly,
  71. financial systems that are fairly consistent
  72. or linked to each other,
  73. we get around that just by using credit cards.
  74. – Sure.
  75. – And so these are, anywhere you go,
  76. it’s pretty much okay.
  77. – And those are those stickers on the back
  78. that show like UnionPay or whatever,
  79. saying they’re like inter, you can.
  80. – You can globally, whatever their network.
  81. I guess the problem is, even in many respects,
  82. China is part of that network.
  83. – Yeah.
  84. – However, you know an example that we had
  85. last year was,
  86. even in a brand new mall,
  87. they wouldn’t take a credit card.
  88. – Yeah, yeah.
  89. – And so, if you start removing payment options,
  90. cash, even card, and go completely digital,
  91. by using basically devices,
  92. then that becomes a problem, right?
  93. – Yeah.
  94. – And then you start cutting off people, perhaps.
  95. And you know from a holistic perspective,
  96. maybe you’re okay to say,
  97. hey, we don’t really care if people like you
  98. who are only here for two or three days
  99. are integrated into the system or not.
  100. That’s a judgement that,
  101. certain financial ecosystems and countries can make.
  102. – Yeah.
  103. – And you know, I don’t think we’re in a place to
  104. tell them to change.
  105. But I think it’s worth a question.
  106. And it’s worth kind of thinking about like we’re doing.
  107. – Yeah, so maybe for all of us,
  108. we’re actually asking the wrong question,
  109. and looking at this from the wrong perspective, right?
  110. Because in reality, we’re asking this question
  111. from the perspective of people that currently use cash
  112. and have used cash.
  113. But if the problem is access to that digital technology
  114. that allows you to have digital payments,
  115. maybe we should be looking at it from the perspective
  116. or asking the question,
  117. if it’s that important, should the government actually
  118. provide a digital device to every single person, right?
  119. So just like the idea of being regarded as a utility,
  120. because it’s so critical,
  121. maybe there’s a government issued smart phone, right?
  122. That everyone would have,
  123. and therefore have access to these economies,
  124. who knows what’s gonna happen in the future.
  125. Clearly that’s not gonna happen now.
  126. But I think that may, at some point,
  127. if it truly is a cashless society,
  128. you’d have to have the technology to catch up to that,
  129. otherwise that culture lag would mean that,
  130. potentially a big large percentage of your population
  131. would not have access to that cashless society.
  132. – And I think if we, in some far of future,
  133. if we actually move to that,
  134. then we’d have to think about occasions
  135. where we would need contingencies.
  136. – Mm.
  137. – Where, in a large natural disaster.
  138. – Sure, oh yeah, yeah, yeah.
  139. – I mean then how would society?
  140. – Which is true for us by the way,
  141. ’cause again, banks are like IT firms essentially.
  142. – That’s right.
  143. – If there’s a big power outage,
  144. or if you couldn’t access the bank money,
  145. which a lot of it is not physical currency,
  146. the same thing can happen.
  147. – But which is why I think in the face of certain,
  148. those kind of disasters,
  149. people will go to a bank and pull cash out
  150. prior to a large hurricane coming,
  151. go stock up on food.
  152. – Yeah.
  153. – And we’ll kind of do these as a precaution measure,
  154. and kind of in an extreme sense,
  155. there are still people in the world
  156. who still stockpile a little gold at home
  157. just in case they need to try to escape
  158. or something happens and.
  159. You know, I’ve run into people who live in
  160. fairly developed places that still.
  161. – Yeah gold coins.
  162. – Yeah have little gold bars, gold coins,
  163. different things that they can use
  164. in case of a contingency situation.
  165. I think we’d have to account for that as a society
  166. before we kind of move down that path.
  167. – Yeah, great.

Additional Readings

  • Newcomb, A. (2019). Philadelphia Becomes the First Major U.S. City to Ban Cashless Stores and Restaurants. Fortune. Retrieved from www.fortune.com/2019/03/07/philadelphia-cashless-cash-ban-law-credit-card-debit/
  • San Francisco to Ban Cashless Stores, Saying Refusing Cash Harms the Poor (2019). CBS News. Retrieved from https://www.cbsnews.com/news/san-francisco-to-ban-cashless-stores-saying-refusing-cash-harms-the-poor/
  • Tims, A. (2012). Why Cash is No Longer King. The Guardian. Retrieved from https://www.theguardian.com/money/blog/2012/jul/05/cash-no-longer-king-penalties
  • Ren, D. (2018). China’s Central Bank Cracks Down on Merchants Who Refuse to Take Cash. SCMP. Retrieved from https://www.scmp.com/business/companies/article/2160703/china-takes-action-against-merchants-who-refuse-cash-e-payment

5.7.1 Global Impact of FinTech

  1. – Now, in this module, we’ve primarily considered
  2. the disruptive nature of FinTech
  3. at the individual and national level.
  4. But we wanted to end the module with a quick discussion
  5. about the implications at the global level.
  6. – So, let’s revisit again the example
  7. of David Bishop visiting the street vendor in China
  8. to try to find his breakfast,
  9. this time from a more technical standpoint.
  10. The peer-to-peer payment system utilised by the vendor
  11. and the costumers that day
  12. was significantly more advanced
  13. than what is typically utilised
  14. somewhere like in Hong Kong,
  15. even though Hong Kong is generally considered
  16. a global financial centre.
  17. If you think about it from a FinTech standpoint,
  18. China and other developing nations
  19. have in many ways been able to leapfrog
  20. the legacy infrastructure seen in developed countries.
  21. – This is partly due to the fact that developing countries
  22. do not have as large of a financial and cultural stake
  23. in traditional finance infrastructure,
  24. so they’ve been able to move past the developed world
  25. in some ways.
  26. For someone who has never used
  27. a peer-to-peer mobile finance application, for example,
  28. doing so may seem insecure and scary.
  29. But for someone who has only known banking
  30. on their smartphones,
  31. writing and sending a cheque may seem
  32. not only archaic and slow but even more insecure
  33. than using the peer-to-peer transfer system.
  34. – Many developing countries who are now working
  35. to improve their financial infrastructure
  36. will completely leapfrog much of the physical infrastructure
  37. that defines the finance industry
  38. in most of the developed world.
  39. For example, many customers in Africa and Asia
  40. will maybe never use an ATM
  41. nor will they ever step foot
  42. inside a physical brick and mortar bank.
  43. – [David B.] Now, as a personal example,
  44. over the 12 years that I’ve lived in Hong Kong,
  45. many businesses in the US have been reluctant
  46. to receive wired transfers from my overseas bank,
  47. preferring instead for me to send a cheque to them.
  48. Now, I protest,
  49. explaining that doing so would be extremely slow,
  50. very expensive,
  51. and more susceptible to fraud or theft.
  52. But because this is their legacy payment system,
  53. they stick with what they know and trust.
  54. – As a result,
  55. some of the most advanced economies in the world
  56. are actually the slowest to adopt FinTech innovations,
  57. lagging behind many countries in Asia and Africa
  58. in regards to FinTech.
  59. – In the context of identity, for example,
  60. countries such as Kenya, Bangladesh, and Guinea,
  61. who though lacked these legacy identity systems,
  62. are building digital identification systems,
  63. and many other government services
  64. are going from basically non-existent
  65. straight to digital payment or record systems.
  66. For example, last week I was in Myanmar
  67. and was incredibly impressed by a startup there
  68. called Koe Koe Tech.
  69. As many of you know,
  70. the country of Myanmar was only opened to the outside world
  71. in 2012.
  72. And as a result they have an enthusiastic
  73. but underdeveloped government sector
  74. that in many ways lags behind the rest of the world.
  75. But Koe Koe Tech and other companies like it
  76. are helping to digitise the Myanmar government systems.
  77. As a result, they may end up with a more advanced
  78. digital government payment and record-keeping system
  79. than advanced countries like the US
  80. which are now burdened by ageing technical infrastructure.
  81. – [David L.] It’s important to remember
  82. that while much of the world
  83. is talking about the Fourth Industrial Revolution,
  84. some of the world is still struggling
  85. with implementation of technologies
  86. that came about around the time
  87. of the First Industrial Revolution.
  88. Using Myanmar again as an example,
  89. seven years ago Myanmar had
  90. a nearly non-existent formal banking sector,
  91. but in just six years
  92. they’ve attained 80% smartphone penetration
  93. and have seen millions
  94. get access to mobile financial services.
  95. This is quite remarkable
  96. if you consider that over 30% of Myanmar’s population
  97. lives below the national poverty line as of 2015.
  98. And hopefully with further advancements in FinTech,
  99. the amount of poverty will continue to shrink
  100. and access to financial services will continue to climb.
  101. – Similarly, in 2016,
  102. 33 million Kenyans owned mobile phones
  103. but 26.7 million
  104. had registered mobile transfer service accounts.
  105. It’s amazing.
  106. This was made possible because traditional banking systems
  107. were not accessible to low-wage earners
  108. and banks were not accessible in remote areas.
  109. So throughout Kenya they’re cutting out ATMs,
  110. reducing them by about 30% so far
  111. and only leaving around 2,000 ATMs in the entire country.
  112. This is a place where, according to UNICEF,
  113. access to basic quality services
  114. such as health care, education, clean water, and sanitation
  115. are often a luxury for some people.
  116. Now, their access to mobile banking though
  117. is really remarkable and a great sign of things to come.
  118. So, what do you think?
  119. Do you think that developing countries
  120. have an advantage of some sorts
  121. from a financial infrastructure standpoint?

Additional Readings

  • Singh, R. (2018). Banking Sector Reforms in Myanmar. ASEAN Briefing. Retrieved from https://www.aseanbriefing.com/news/2018/03/21/banking-sector-reforms-myanmar.html 
  • Xiapeng, W., & Mengo, B. (2017). Banks Signal the End of ATMs in Kenya. Xinhua News. Retrieved from www.xinhuanet.com/english/2017-08/05/c_136500697.htm
  • The State of Identification Systems in Africa: A Synthesis of Country Assessments. World Bank. Retrieved from http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/156111493234231522/pdf/114628-WP-68p-TheStateofIdentificationSystemsinAfricaASynthesisofIDDAssessments-PUBLIC.pdf

5.7.2 Will Developing Countries Leapfrog in FinTech?

  1. So, the next question maybe we want to think about is,
  2. do we think developing countries,
  3. due to the lack of infrastructure,
  4. does that give them some sort of advantage
  5. in rolling out or accepting
  6. some of these new technologies
  7. that we’ve been discussing?
  8. So what do you think, Dave?
  9. – Yeah, so this I think is one of the most
  10. interesting questions because here you have
  11. this paradox where the things that
  12. perhaps in the past would have held back
  13. a developing country like physical infrastructure,
  14. bridges, roads, locomotives, whatever.
  15. Now, from a FinTech perspective,
  16. or just the financial infrastructure,
  17. it may actually turn into
  18. some sort of an advantage, right?
  19. Now so I’m a big fan of the NBA, right?
  20. So I like basketball.
  21. And if you think of it like a team perspective,
  22. you often have like ageing superstars
  23. where there’s a lot of money put into their contracts
  24. and as they get older and they become less effective,
  25. it ends up like weighing down the team
  26. because there’s a cap on how much they can spend,
  27. right?
  28. And so as a result of that,
  29. it’s like these teams that have a group of young stars,
  30. people say they actually have a better future,
  31. because they’re able to capitalise on those stars
  32. for a longer period of time, right?
  33. It’s kind of like that from like
  34. a macro-economic perspective,
  35. now again,
  36. this is not to say there are not challenges, right?
  37. This is not to say like, you know,
  38. say Kenya or one of these places we use as an example,
  39. they certainly would be willing to change places
  40. with say the US for certain aspects of this,
  41. but it is super interesting to think
  42. that the infrastructure they’re putting in now,
  43. theoretically could help them develop and advance
  44. at a quicker rate than we’ve ever seen before.
  45. – And I think maybe it’s important to clarify too,
  46. I think generally I think everybody agrees
  47. that developing countries should have,
  48. broadly have good infrastructure, roads.
  49. – Yeah, of course, of course.
  50. – And those kinds of things.
  51. But I think specifically what we’re talking about
  52. is the type of infrastructure directly related
  53. to the adoption of technology.
  54. – Just making payments, yeah adoption of technology.
  55. And of course there has to be
  56. governance behind it and stuff.
  57. – And so I think kind of one of the key intersections
  58. of this thinking about this comes down
  59. to countries that have rolled out basically phone lines,
  60. data lines versus countries that haven’t, right.
  61. And that is part of infrastructure,
  62. but it’s very interesting to think about,
  63. you know, there are companies in the world
  64. who focus on hey, how can we deliver
  65. similar types of service without
  66. having to build a wire, put wire down
  67. or put up large towers where we’re stringing wire across,
  68. you know these kinds of things.
  69. And I think that’s interesting, right.
  70. And so a lot of developing countries
  71. in Southeast Asia, Africa, are kind of thinking about
  72. how can we deliver basic internet
  73. without having to put in all the infrastructure
  74. that initially a lot of quote unquote
  75. developed countries now did 20 or 30 years ago.
  76. Which now we rely on as kind of the internet
  77. network that we have.
  78. – Or when they do put in the physical infrastructure,
  79. it’s at a much, much higher speed.
  80. So in a lot of developing countries,
  81. their internet rates,
  82. the speeds are actually quite a lot faster,
  83. because you’ll have an internet service provider in,
  84. let’s say, in the U.S.,
  85. that has spent a lot of money
  86. on that physical infrastructure,
  87. and they’re essentially like a monopolistic entity there.
  88. They don’t wanna go out and rip out
  89. those old cables and put in newer, faster ones.
  90. They just wanna kind of milk it as long as they can.
  91. And so you have these slow internet speeds
  92. in throughout the U.S., let’s say,
  93. versus a country that just got internet
  94. for the first time, it’s immediately faster.
  95. – Yeah, and I think that really brings us
  96. to the crux of the question about,
  97. is that somehow an advantage in some ways,
  98. because, maybe because a family somewhere
  99. that maybe is, doesn’t have access,
  100. has historically hasn’t had access
  101. to some of this technology.
  102. Now instead of having to wait for a phone line to be
  103. put in,
  104. that they can use to have a landline for, you know,
  105. a landline for internet, all these things.
  106. Now, instead of doing all that,
  107. everything is through their phone
  108. off a, you know, kind of a signal,
  109. yet increasing in 4G, 5G, these kind of
  110. advances in technology.
  111. And those signals allowing them
  112. to have internet speeds as fast as,
  113. and as high-quality as if you were just using
  114. a desktop computer at home.
  115. – Yeah.
  116. – Connected to a wired internet line.
  117. – Yeah.
  118. So, the example that I used with Koe Koe Tech
  119. when I was in Myanmar last week,
  120. I was super, super impressed with this startup
  121. because here you had a Burmese American lawyer,
  122. went back, started a company,
  123. and he’s essentially trying to digitise
  124. their entire government services, right.
  125. So tax payments, utilities payments, right.
  126. Those are things that even here in Hong Kong,
  127. we’re still paying physically by check,
  128. by paper, by fax, whatever.
  129. And it was so cool to see that he had this
  130. team of developers that were essentially
  131. digitising the entire process.
  132. Now, make no mistake, it’s still slow.
  133. It’s still inefficient, they’re just getting started.
  134. But the reality is, if those get in place,
  135. I mean, these are the types of legacy systems
  136. that are costing the U.S. government
  137. trillions of dollars essentially
  138. in non-digitized medical records,
  139. non-digitized tax records, et cetera.
  140. – Yep.

Additional Readings

  • EY FinTech Adoption Index 2017: The Rapid Emergence of FinTech. EY. Retrieved from https://www.ey.com/Publication/vwLUAssets/ey-fintech-adoption-index-2017/$FILE/ey-fintech-adoption-index-2017.pdf
  • FinTech in Sub-Saharan African Countries: A Game Changer? (2019). The International Monetary Fund. Retrieved from https://www.imf.org/~/media/Files/Publications/DP/2019/FTSSACEA.ashx
  • The Leapfrog Model: What Technology Can Do For Africa. The Economist. Retrieved from https://www.economist.com/special-report/2017/11/10/what-technology-can-do-for-africa
  • Visser, S. (2016). The Complex Impact of Fintech and Legacy Systems on Banking. IBM. Retrieved from https://www.ibm.com/blogs/insights-on-business/banking/complex-impact-fintech-legacy-systems-banking/

Module 5 Conclusion

  1. – Okay so throughout this module five,
  2. we’ve kind of used the same analogy of me going into China,
  3. trying to buy breakfast from a woman
  4. on the street selling breakfast,
  5. and showing how difficult it was to kind of access that.
  6. So this is kind of an example that we’ve shown over
  7. and over to talk about the decentralised,
  8. democratised, expansive nature of Fintech solutions.
  9. And how they’re kind of changing the world.
  10. Some at a rapid pace, some at a less rapid pace.
  11. We’ve talked about how, you know, in developing economies,
  12. sometimes they’re leap-frogging technologies
  13. that exist in developed countries,
  14. and we also talked about how some of the legacy systems
  15. on both the financial institution side,
  16. say big banks, et cetera, and now more recently
  17. on the TechFin side are changing,
  18. and we have to from a government regulatory standpoint,
  19. perhaps rethink the way that we really classify
  20. or even regulate these big companies.
  21. – At the heart of a lot of these new technologies
  22. and these advances in FinTech that we’ve been discussing,
  23. is the importance of using the concepts, the models,
  24. these five D’s and other principles that we’ve talked
  25. about in this module to assess new technologies.
  26. How they’re going to impact you individually
  27. as well as all of us collectively,
  28. to really understand is this going to lead us
  29. to a better place, or is it just going
  30. to lead to another kind of concentration of power
  31. and influence, just in a different form.
  32. – So in the next module, we’re going
  33. to explore some of these topics even further
  34. and really dig into some specific examples
  35. of how people are kind of utilising this technology
  36. for good and maybe some of the negative,
  37. unintended consequences that occur when we don’t think
  38. about the application of these technologies.

Module 5 Roundup

  1. – Welcome back for our week five roundup.
  2. It’s amazing how fast the time has gone.
  3. We really can’t believe
  4. we only have just one week left in the course,
  5. and we’ve been told the student participation for the course
  6. has been really high
  7. compared to some other online courses,
  8. so we genuinely appreciate
  9. so many of you are taking this learning journey seriously,
  10. both at an individual level
  11. but also your willingness to participate
  12. in thinking about some really serious questions
  13. that impact all of our futures.
  14. – Now, as we near almost 6,000 students
  15. registered for the course,
  16. we’ve been humbled by your positive feedback.
  17. If you feel like this course
  18. has been a good experience for you,
  19. please do share within your networks
  20. as we think it’s important as many people as possible
  21. think and debate these issues.
  22. Just recently,
  23. the United States announced
  24. that it would commence antitrust investigations
  25. against some large technology companies
  26. such as Amazon, Google, and Facebook,
  27. partly related to data privacy and overall size concerns.
  28. So we are already observing the real world implications
  29. of the concepts that we’ve covered in our course.
  30. – And as you know,
  31. in module five we discussed what we referred to
  32. as the decentralised future.
  33. Basically we were trying to grapple
  34. with understanding how the future might look
  35. and how best we digital citizens can participate
  36. in crafting that future.
  37. Now, from the comments in the course forum,
  38. it seems like many of you
  39. have been thinking about similar questions,
  40. so we wanna jump into a few of your comments.
  41. – So, Dave, let’s start with our first question,
  42. which relates to one of the first principles
  43. related to the module,
  44. which is, do we think, or do you think that FinTech,
  45. do you think it’ll bring the world together
  46. or drive it further apart?
  47. Where do you stand on that?
  48. – Okay, so, regardless of where I stand,
  49. first I just wanted to point out.
  50. I thought it was cool
  51. when reading through some of the comments
  52. that you as the course participants
  53. looked at this question very differently.
  54. So, some of you said
  55. that it’s gonna bring the world closer together
  56. because it makes it easier to, for example,
  57. purchase things online with digital payments,
  58. and basically saying I can contact anyone
  59. and do almost anything from inside my own home.
  60. That was kind of the digital connection.
  61. Whereas others of you said
  62. that by virtue of that digital connection
  63. it is inherently driving the world further apart
  64. because you’re not actually seeing people.
  65. You’re not going to the store,
  66. you’re not going out and writing letters to people
  67. and what.
  68. So I thought that in and of itself
  69. was a very interesting kind of dichotomy or paradox
  70. in the way they looked at it.
  71. And I think both are accurate
  72. and neither one is necessarily good or bad
  73. but both do come with I think
  74. positive and negative aspects to it.
  75. So, there were some specific comments.
  76. So, Ying2658 said
  77. that “FinTech brings distant people together
  78. but pushes further for people around us.”
  79. I think what Ying was saying is that
  80. it can connect people from around the world
  81. but the people that are close to us
  82. are in some circumstances actually pushed further away.
  83. Or as the way that some have said it
  84. is that we are actually looking at our digital friends
  85. at the exclusion of our actual in-person friends.
  86. Have you seen something like that?
  87. – I think the first part about how we’re more connected
  88. to communities that are farther away,
  89. I think that was the original,
  90. what people thought were the benefits of globalisation.
  91. So if we look back and look at people like Thomas Friedman
  92. who’s a New York Times columnist
  93. and wrote The World Is Flat,
  94. he wrote this book that was a best-seller
  95. I think maybe 15-20 years ago.
  96. This is basically what he’s talking about,
  97. where we used to be,
  98. our relationships were heavily constrained
  99. by the people we could meet physically
  100. and now that’s not the case
  101. and we see that.
  102. And I think that aspect certainly is occurring.
  103. I do think on the flip side
  104. whereas the people who are more proximate to us physically,
  105. those relationships may not be as strong,
  106. we’re definitely seeing aspects of that too.
  107. We see that in aspects of people thinking about,
  108. like video game addiction, for example,
  109. and the lack of interaction that occurs in real life
  110. because people are on devices.
  111. So those kind of activities, I guess,
  112. I think are what a lot of people are getting to.
  113. But even everyday occurrences.
  114. So in places like China where there are super apps
  115. where people are getting food delivered,
  116. even coffees delivered,
  117. where normally you might have walked down
  118. your neighbourhood coffee shop or your Starbucks
  119. or whatever
  120. and have some even little interaction
  121. with the cashier, with somebody standing in line.
  122. Even those micro kind of interactions
  123. I guess are falling by the wayside now.
  124. And so I don’t know if that implies
  125. any greater societal problem.
  126. Perhaps.
  127. But it’s certainly something to think about and consider.
  128. – Yeah, and it’s not FinTech specific
  129. but there are a lot of studies that are coming out
  130. showing from a psychological standpoint,
  131. mental health standpoint,
  132. even just general physical health standpoint,
  133. that we are gonna have to adapt.
  134. We’re gonna have to maybe recognise
  135. some of these challenges.
  136. I think, on a very personal level, I’ve got three kids.
  137. You walk home, headphones are in,
  138. and everyone’s doing their own thing.
  139. It’s cool from a certain extent
  140. because I feel like.
  141. – You don’t have to talk to your kids.
  142. – Well, yeah, there we go.
  143. Bonus.
  144. No, but they’re connected with their family
  145. from all over the world,
  146. they live in a global community
  147. so they’re connected with people from all over the world.
  148. But then they’re also learning things
  149. from all over the world.
  150. Like TED or edX
  151. and things that are really bringing people together
  152. from a knowledge standpoint.
  153. But it is interesting how quite often
  154. my 12-year-old daughter will text me from across the room.
  155. Mostly for fun,
  156. I think she’s kinda of messing with me,
  157. but at the same time that is a very real occurrence.
  158. So we have to weight the good with the bad
  159. and from a cultural lag perspective
  160. I think kind of narrow that gap.
  161. So, there was one other aspect of this that came out
  162. in terms of,
  163. there was a comment from JudahFrankel,
  164. Judah Frankel, not sure, Judah Frankel,
  165. and it was a really interesting comment, I think.
  166. Really spot on.
  167. He took the scenario of me being in rural Western China
  168. and trying to purchase breakfast
  169. and saying how, yes, recognising there were perhaps
  170. some impediments and challenges
  171. in terms of using the technology to purchase the breakfast,
  172. but very insightfully also pointed out
  173. that had I just used cash
  174. that also would have had a whole list of challenges,
  175. including the RMB is not convertible
  176. so I would have to be able to go and have a bank account
  177. or some process whereby I could not only pull out currency
  178. but actually convert the currency, et cetera et cetera.
  179. And so his comment was, well, look,
  180. is this really any harder?
  181. And in fact, once you set up that technology,
  182. it gets easier and easier.
  183. And I do think that that was accurate.
  184. Really insightful, even.
  185. And in my comment to him, the written comment,
  186. one of my points was simply that, well,
  187. it’s not that one is necessarily better or worse,
  188. and indeed I think we could all agree
  189. that many aspects of the electronic transactions
  190. are significantly simpler.
  191. Once you know how to do it, once you’re in the ecosystem.
  192. And my point though to him was
  193. that just by virtue of the fact that it is different,
  194. by virtue of the fact that it is new,
  195. that means it’s inherently going to be distant
  196. for some people
  197. and it will make it hard, again,
  198. for perhaps the poor or the elderly,
  199. minorities, migrants, and even tourists.
  200. You could have a wealthy tourist
  201. who’s just not part of that ecosystem
  202. that has difficulty kind of accessing it.
  203. So, from that standpoint, any thoughts on that?
  204. – Yeah, well, I think the entry point I think is important.
  205. So, true,
  206. the conversion and all that stuff that you mentioned
  207. I think would have had happened.
  208. But I’m sure if push came to shove
  209. and this lady really wanted to sell you
  210. whatever she was selling you
  211. and all you had were
  212. US dollars even,
  213. and she was taking cash,
  214. let’s assume she was accepting cash,
  215. if you gave her enough US dollars,
  216. she would
  217. probably give you– – Give her my wedding ring.
  218. – Yeah, she would probably give you the food.
  219. – Do some dishes.
  220. – Right, and so.
  221. I think the idea of entry point
  222. in terms of how we enter the ecosystem is important.
  223. So, the barriers to entry for a cash economy are quite low.
  224. And it’s not even constrained to just,
  225. oh, you have to have that currency.
  226. We were just talking before we started filming
  227. about this situation
  228. I had a visa issue going to Vietnam
  229. and it was so interesting
  230. ’cause when you showed up
  231. at this particular airport in Vietnam,
  232. they were like, “You have to get a picture for your visa.”
  233. But people didn’t have Vietnamese dong or whatever
  234. so they were like, “Oh, you gotta give us $5.”
  235. And people were like, “Well, I don’t have any US dollars.”
  236. “Give to us in whatever currency you have.”
  237. And that was okay because it was cash.
  238. And so I think to your point,
  239. I think that’s right.
  240. I think the barrier to entry is important to think about
  241. because there’s a higher barrier to entry now in China
  242. for someone who’s not in the system.
  243. – Yeah, I would argue that.
  244. – Yeah, right.
  245. Which is my opinion as well.
  246. Whereas in a pure cash economy for example,
  247. or a hybrid where cash is still highly readily accepted,
  248. the barrier to entry is still quite low.
  249. – And the only thing I would add as well,
  250. and I agree with all of that,
  251. is that because the infrastructure’s in place already
  252. and has been for quite a long time,
  253. if you use the example of a tourist,
  254. if they get there,
  255. there are ATMs waiting for you,
  256. there’s currency conversion there kind of waiting for you.
  257. And when you think of the mobile device,
  258. yes, it’s easy to use, doesn’t take very long,
  259. but the reality is for, as you said,
  260. the barrier to entry for a poor person to access cash
  261. versus acquiring and using a mobile phone
  262. is actually quite significant.
  263. And we’re very far from the time
  264. when there will be mobile phones
  265. waiting for us at the airport
  266. like an ATM.
  267. Because it’s not like one machine
  268. can do all that for everyone
  269. like an ATM or a currency conversion kiosk could do.
  270. So, again, great points.
  271. And I’m sure as time goes on
  272. people are going to look at my scenario
  273. and actually look at the cash
  274. as probably the more archaic, time-consuming,
  275. thinking oh my gosh,
  276. they actually had to go through that process?
  277. But for now I think for a lot of us out there
  278. there is a little bit of a barrier to entry
  279. in terms of the technology,
  280. and so we’ll see as that adapts and changes going forward.
  281. Okay, so, the next kind of question
  282. or theme that we wanted to go through
  283. was this concept of cryptocurrency
  284. and particularly in terms of a potential
  285. decentralised future.
  286. Now, we asked,
  287. do you think that banks and potentially even governments
  288. would move more in the crypto direction,
  289. and if they do,
  290. will that lead to a more entrenched
  291. kind of traditional forms of power,
  292. meaning the banks and governments
  293. just use that and get stronger,
  294. or is this going to lead to a more decentralised future
  295. the way the founders and geniuses
  296. behind these cryptocurrency originally envisioned?
  297. So, Dave, what do you think?
  298. – Well, that’s a pretty heavy question
  299. and I don’t think we have the full answer.
  300. – Nobody does.
  301. – And if anything it’s probably
  302. at least three or four different questions
  303. that were encompassed in that.
  304. But I think maybe we start with kind of a recent news event
  305. and then kind of start unpacking it from there.
  306. So, I think as probably most of our participants
  307. have read in the newspaper or magazines
  308. or online blog or whatever
  309. is that Facebook has recently
  310. shared their plans to launch their own stablecoin,
  311. which my understanding is
  312. it will be tied to basically
  313. a basket of different currencies,
  314. and they’re taking basically $10 million investments
  315. from a variety of different types of stakeholders.
  316. Financial companies, other technology companies,
  317. et cetera.
  318. – It is huge, by the way.
  319. – Yeah, which is huge.
  320. Because if they do roll it out
  321. across all the messaging platforms,
  322. you know, Facebook Messenger, WhatsApp, and Instagram,
  323. in theory they should have
  324. the largest payment network in the world.
  325. – And we should point out,
  326. this is happening because of this course.
  327. We pushed the, I’m just kidding.
  328. – So, but yeah, so.
  329. It will be interesting to see how that plays out.
  330. What kind of influence that has
  331. on how governments as well as individuals
  332. perceive these kind of payment systems.
  333. – And how governments will perceive Facebook.
  334. – Yeah, exactly.
  335. So this is a core question
  336. because I think we had mentioned at the beginning,
  337. at the outset of the roundup,
  338. that they are undergoing some scrutiny related to antitrust.
  339. And this alone, this new stablecoin that they’re producing,
  340. alone would not trigger antitrust violations by itself,
  341. but I think in that overall political environment,
  342. again, it’s another red flag
  343. that politicians and regulators will draw on to say,
  344. hey, how should we be treating you, guys?
  345. Should we be treating you like a utility,
  346. which is something I think I’m sure we’re gonna discuss
  347. in a second here,
  348. but should we treat you like a bank?
  349. I mean, if you have a network
  350. that allows a few hundred million people to trade payment–
  351. – Yeah, like leverage requirements or something.
  352. – And the reality is that you can actually hold that value
  353. in some way.
  354. So in the sense that you’re acting like a bank,
  355. should you be subject to similar scrutiny
  356. as a financial institution?
  357. So this raises a lot of questions on the regulatory front.
  358. Maybe large technology companies,
  359. at the high level when they talk about this
  360. they don’t wanna be regulated like–
  361. – Of course not, yeah.
  362. They don’t wanna be regulated as any of those things.
  363. Antitrust, utilities, they don’t want any of those things.
  364. – But if the decision is made of, well, it’s gonna happen,
  365. then you start thinking about the side effects of that.
  366. Does that become a standalone business?
  367. Does that stay part of Facebook and they get regulated?
  368. And even if they did get regulated,
  369. so my question when it comes down to it
  370. when people talk about,
  371. oh it should be regulated like an utility,
  372. it should be regulated like a financial institution.
  373. That’s all fine and let’s say that happens,
  374. but does that automatically mean
  375. that it won’t be as big and influential as it is today?
  376. If anything I feel like
  377. that could potentially give them a licence
  378. to even be bigger and more influential.
  379. – Yeah, because if you think about it,
  380. utilities are traditionally kind of monopolies
  381. or some type of cartel.
  382. You have this limitation on how many utilities you can have.
  383. An interesting side note to that is
  384. utilities are usually very geographically specific.
  385. It’s not like there’s gonna be a world utility
  386. any time soon,
  387. and so what does that even mean?
  388. If you did it from the US context,
  389. would every single country regulate them separately?
  390. Which is probably the likely future.
  391. – At least in the foreseeable future.
  392. – Yeah, yeah.
  393. It’s gonna be super interesting
  394. and I have no idea how they’re gonna deal with this.
  395. I do know that,
  396. as we’ve seen even earlier in the course
  397. I think we may have talked about it,
  398. but Mark Zuckerberg and his entire team
  399. are trying to get out in front of this.
  400. He of course published an op-ed in The Washington Post
  401. about this, saying,
  402. “We know we’re probably gonna have to be regulated more.
  403. “Here’s what we think that should look like.”
  404. You have the COO of Facebook
  405. is reaching out and publicly stating
  406. that regulating it more or, sorry, breaking it up
  407. would be a nightmare for everybody.
  408. They’re really trying to get out there and kind of lobby
  409. not only actually lobbying for the government
  410. but actually lobbying to the public
  411. saying, “This is why you should keep us together.”
  412. There was a great article recently,
  413. I think it was The New York Times,
  414. where it showed the behind the scenes lobbying
  415. that big tech firms mostly from Silicon Valley,
  416. the amount of lobbying pressure
  417. they’re placing on Washington, DC, right now,
  418. chunks of massive amounts of money going in
  419. to I guess drive the dialogue
  420. and push their story, their narrative.
  421. – And the interesting I think dynamic that’s occurring there
  422. is one I think they’ve been preparing for this for a while.
  423. – Oh yeah, oh yeah.
  424. – So in terms of bringing over folks who have some expertise
  425. in antitrust regulatory action and things like that.
  426. But I think the other thing that is really interesting is
  427. at least as far as the US political spectrum goes
  428. most of these technology companies that we’re talking about
  429. tend to be liberal
  430. yet most of the folks who are bringing up this regulation
  431. are also liberal politicians.
  432. And so it’s a very interesting dynamic that is occurring
  433. and it will be interesting to see how it plays out.
  434. – And just to give you a specific example.
  435. I think San Francisco is super interesting in this regard
  436. because you have one of the most liberal cities
  437. in the United States
  438. with one of the highest per-capita income cities in the US
  439. where is largely the home or at least nearby
  440. many of these technology firms
  441. and yet, what do you see?
  442. The State of California recently put in rules
  443. against kind of the gig economy
  444. saying that companies like Uber
  445. are gonna have to treat them like employees.
  446. You have facial recognition being banned
  447. throughout San Francisco.
  448. And so it’s this interesting dichotomy.
  449. In fact, on a more personal level,
  450. you see there’s all these reports
  451. of Apple and other very senior technology executives
  452. that intentionally send their kids
  453. to schools that don’t use digital technology.
  454. So it’s just interesting, this kind of dichotomy.
  455. – And so, I guess more to the broader question, then.
  456. Will governments and central banks
  457. really ever give up this idea of central currency?
  458. I don’t think so.
  459. I mean, a large part of what their fiscal policy,
  460. a large part of monetary policy,
  461. large parts of other types of government policy
  462. that deal with government revenue and things,
  463. all tie into this idea
  464. that they have control over money supply,
  465. they can print money,
  466. they have control over interest rates.
  467. And, again, different countries have different systems
  468. so we’re just talking broadly here.
  469. Would governments ever give that up?
  470. Not willingly.
  471. – Yeah, of course.
  472. – And if we– – Well.
  473. Yeah, yeah.
  474. They’d wanna control,
  475. they would probably allow it
  476. but it’s gonna be defined on their own terms
  477. for their own benefit.
  478. – So, if we use a non-technological example,
  479. in my mind comes the European Union
  480. where as countries join the Union
  481. form an economic perspective
  482. they lost economic sovereignty,
  483. which lead to some problems
  484. for some of the countries in the Union right now.
  485. – Yeah, yeah, yeah.
  486. – And so I think if we apply that
  487. through a technological lens,
  488. then would there be some of the same issues?
  489. Surely, I think.
  490. And so I think governments are hesitant
  491. to potentially walk down that road without knowing.
  492. I don’t think anybody wants to be first.
  493. I don’t think any major economy at least wants to be first.
  494. – And I would say, if there was one,
  495. I was speaking with a guy about this recently,
  496. I could definitely foresee the US pushing this,
  497. specially with large US financial institutions,
  498. in order to ensure the first-mover status
  499. and kind of ensure the US dollar kind of remains
  500. the world’s fiat currency.
  501. Because if you did have a US-backed dollar
  502. crypto going forward,
  503. and especially if it’s broadly adopted,
  504. that could potentially give them a further extension
  505. as the global currency.
  506. – So, I think the next iteration of this in my mind,
  507. or the next step of this towards merging traditional fiat
  508. with a wider-spread use of various forms of crypto
  509. would be some sort of stablecoin.
  510. So what Facebook’s doing with Libra,
  511. stablecoins that maybe a particular institution puts out
  512. that is maybe pegged with US dollar
  513. or a basket of currencies that are heavily traded
  514. like Yen, Euros, whatever,
  515. and then you could see that
  516. actually being like a partial next step
  517. to how countries and economies
  518. try to merge the fiat and cryptocurrency divide.
  519. – Do you think the name that Facebook chose for the crypto
  520. is kind of interesting?
  521. – Yeah.
  522. – Like, Libra, I mean, I’m assuming.
  523. Is it L-I-B-R-E?
  524. – L-I-B-R-A.
  525. – R-A, okay.
  526. So I may be completely off here.
  527. I’m assuming is based on freedom and liberty?
  528. – That was my impression.
  529. – Yeah.
  530. ‘Cause we’ve seen that.
  531. We’ve seen the Marshall Islands currency
  532. when specifically talking about sovereignty.
  533. So it’s interesting that even in the way
  534. that they’re naming these coins,
  535. a lot of them are focusing on this idea
  536. of freedom and democratisation of finance.
  537. Again, I may off on the Facebook thing.
  538. I will find out.
  539. I’m sure someone’s gonna Google this and let us know.
  540. One thing that personally I’d like to see,
  541. we keep talking about a utopian future,
  542. and on this particular topic
  543. I think one of the most interesting ideas,
  544. if we do go into the route of a public utility
  545. and if we do say
  546. that since these really, really large TechFin platforms
  547. I guess by global comparison
  548. only serve a small number of stakeholders.
  549. There’s fewer employees.
  550. They’re really creating massive amounts of wealth
  551. for a small number of people.
  552. Then if you do look at it from what’s known as the UBI,
  553. the universal basic income standpoint,
  554. could you have these massive companies
  555. like Google, Facebook, Amazon, Tencent or whatever,
  556. that are essentially either nationalised
  557. or created like utilities
  558. where part of that wealth is actually pulled off
  559. and then given down to normal people
  560. in countries around the world?
  561. There’s actually a presidential candidate
  562. in the US right now
  563. who’s running in large part based on this concept of UBI,
  564. universal basic income.
  565. And he said part of that funding,
  566. of course he’s not gonna win but it’s an interesting idea,
  567. that part of that funding would come from essentially
  568. taxing these large organisations,
  569. which for the most part don’t pay any federal income tax.
  570. Now, as we wrap up this roundup,
  571. just a quick administrative announcement.
  572. For our verified learners who are pursuing a certificate,
  573. the final assignment is the next module.
  574. In this assignment,
  575. we want you to utilise the framework and knowledge
  576. we have introduced in the course
  577. to analyse a FinTech product or solution of your choice.
  578. We hope this serves as another wonderful opportunity
  579. for you to learn from other excellent peers
  580. from all over the world.
  581. And so accordingly the essay is gonna be peer-assessed.
  582. Each of you will grade two other peers’ work
  583. and also receive two sets of grades and feedback.
  584. And we can’t wait to read your great work
  585. and wish you the best
  586. as you progress to earning your certificate.
  587. – Now, thank you again
  588. for being part of this learning journey.
  589. It’s been a great experience for both of us
  590. and we hope you enjoy the final module.
  591. We look forward to wrapping the course with you next week.

Module 6 Positive Impact of FinTech

6.1.1 Can Technology Be Good or Bad?

  1. In Module 5 we talked about some
  2. of the big-picture, foundational philosophies used by
  3. FinTech innovators to support and justify their work.
  4. For example, we talked about whether FinTech should
  5. aim to create a decentralized, more democratized
  6. finance industry, or whether FinTech innovations
  7. would further entrench traditional sources of
  8. financial power.
  9. In that module we focused on control
  10. and power – particularly who controls banking,
  11. currency, and our identity – with a specific
  12. focus on how to ensure FinTech innovations
  13. provide greater financial inclusion.
  14. We ended the module by considering the speed of
  15. these innovations, particularly in the developing
  16. world, noting that in some less developed
  17. countries FinTech has already advanced considerably
  18. beyond what is available in developed countries.
  19. So now we want to move on to our
  20. last module, and consider some of these innovations
  21. in real-life contexts. But to do that,
  22. first, we want to start with a question: can technology
  23. be good or bad, or is technology always neutral?
  24. Let’s look at this using a specific example.
  25. Take a moment and think about one
  26. specific form of technological advancement:
  27. nuclear power. What are your immediate feelings
  28. about nuclear power?
  29. Is it good, bad, or just neutral?
  30. On the one hand, nuclear power is
  31. among the cleanest, most efficient sources energy
  32. ever discovered or utilized by mankind.
  33. Using material only about the size of a small
  34. cube, like a Rubik’s cube, you could generate
  35. enough electricity to power an entire city
  36. for decades, if not centuries.
  37. France derives about 75% of its electricity from nuclear
  38. power. As a result, France has cleaner and
  39. cheaper electricity than just about any country
  40. in the world. In fact, France even exports
  41. enough excess electricity to generate over
  42. 3 billion Euros per year.
  43. And yet in countries around the world,
  44. nuclear power is one of the least popular
  45. forms of electricity generation.
  46. When I asked the question, some of you may have
  47. immediately thought of disasters like those that
  48. occurred in 2011 in Fukushima, Japan, or in 1986 in
  49. Chernobyl, Ukraine.
  50. Or maybe you didnt even think
  51. about nuclear power in terms of electricity
  52. generation at all.
  53. Maybe you immediately thought about
  54. its even more destructive use: nuclear weapons.
  55. There is no denying the potential
  56. of nuclear power for both good and bad.
  57. But the questions remain: is nuclear power
  58. itself good or bad?
  59. Can technology ever be inherently good or evil?
  60. Or is technology always inherently neutral?
  61. One common debate that has occurred
  62. in countries like the United States around
  63. this question concerns guns.
  64. Typically the question is asked this way: do guns kill
  65. people, or do people kill people? And while this may
  66. seem like a silly debate to many of you, the
  67. underlying philosophical question has been
  68. at the heart of technological advancements
  69. for millenia.
  70. As an example of how long humans
  71. have been asking this question, let’s consider
  72. a term that you may have heard before: Luddite.
  73. Have you heard the term Luddite before?
  74. I remember the first time I called David
  75. a Luddite
  76. the term basically means someone
  77. who is resistant to adopt new technology.
  78. The term Luddite is thrown around a lot in tech circles,
  79. but do you know the origins of that word?
  80. The Luddites were actually a secret oath-based society
  81. from 19th century England.
  82. They were worried that their jobs were going to be
  83. taken by machines, particularly in the textile industry,
  84. and so some believe that the Luddites went around
  85. breaking machines to ensure they wouldn’t take over
  86. their jobs. For many Luddites, the machines themselves
  87. were the enemies.
  88. And damage to machines was so prevalent that in 1812
  89. the British government even created a law that
  90. made machine breaking a capital crime.
  91. Ok, let’s bring this back to the FinTech world.
  92. We have discussed the challenges
  93. and benefits from several FinTech innovations,
  94. such as the blockchain and facial recognition software.
  95. We have discussed multiple cases
  96. where blockchain based technologies have been
  97. used for illegal behavior.
  98. But should that mean that blockchain itself is bad, and
  99. should therefore be made illegal.
  100. Or were the people who utilized the technology for
  101. illegal purposes the real perpetrators?
  102. Or concerning AI, should we be more concerned about
  103. the underlying technology that makes AI possible,
  104. or should we focused our attention on who has the
  105. ability to control the use of the technology?
  106. On that particular question, even Stephen Hawking,
  107. who has famously warned about the dangers of AI,
  108. noted that the short-term concerns about AI depend
  109. more on who controls the technology rather than
  110. the AI technology itself.
  111. So here is the question. To the extent that we have
  112. concerns about FinTech innovations, should we be
  113. more concerned about the technology itself,
  114. or those who control and use the technology?
  115. To the extent you have concerns about AI,
  116. are you more concerned about sentient
  117. AI itself, or the people or companies who
  118. will control the technology?
  119. Whether you believe that technology can be inherently
  120. good or bad, or whether it is inherently amoral and neutral,
  121. there is no denying that technology has initiated
  122. massive social changes over the past two centuries.
  123. The theory of technological determinism considers
  124. how technology has impacted human action,culture,
  125. and thought, and argues that technological
  126. advancements have been the primary source for social change.
  127. One element of technological determinism is
  128. an ideology called technological utopianism,
  129. which is the belief that science and technology
  130. will bring about a utopia where scarcity,
  131. suffering, and even death can be overcome.
  132. As we stated in the very first module of this course,
  133. we currently stand at the precipice of change.
  134. And we as humanity have some really
  135. important decisions to make.
  136. Will we utilize the power inherent in FinTech innovations
  137. to build the type of utopian society that
  138. science fiction has imagined for us,
  139. or will we use these innovations to divide, control,
  140. and disempower?
  141. Although this course may seem somewhat
  142. pessimistic or cynical at times, the reality
  143. is that we are extremely optimistic about
  144. the future.
  145. And we truly believe in the power
  146. of FinTech to bring humanity together.
  147. So for the remainder of this Module,
  148. we are going to consider some of the ways
  149. people are creating FinTech solutions and
  150. building FinTech-based business models solely
  151. for the benefit of society.
  152. Do you believe that technology can usher in a utopian society?
  153. Should businesses have a social responsibility and
