  154. generate some good for society,
  155. or should business only be responsible to generating
  156. profits for shareholders?
  157. Or maximizing shareholders’ values which is commonly
  158. referred to
  159. Should FinTech entrepreneurs consider the social
  160. implications that will come from the use of their technologies?
  161. Utimately, whose responsibility is it to ensure
  162. that technology is being used for the best interest of society?
  163. And that’s something that we should even consider.

Additional Readings

  • Kang, S. (2017). Can Tech Ever Really Be Neutral? World Economic Forum. Retrieved from https://www.weforum.org/agenda/2017/09/can-tech-be-neutral-gnowbe/
  • de Castella, T. (2012). Are you a Luddite? BBC News. Retrieved from  https://www.bbc.com/news/magazine-17770171 
  • Higgins, A. (2018). Stephen Hawking’s Final Warning For Humanity: Ai Is Coming For Us. Vox. Retrieved from https://www.vox.com/future-perfect/2018/10/16/17978596/stephen-hawking-ai-climate-change-robots-future-universe-earth 
  • Chandler, D. (2014). Technological or Media Determinism. Visual Memory. Retrieved from www.visual-memory.co.uk/daniel/Documents/tecdet/tdet08.html 
  • Hurme, P., & Jouhki, J. (2017). We Shape Our Tools, and Thereafter Our Tools Shape Us. Human Technology, 13 (2), 145-148. https://jyx.jyu.fi/bitstream/handle/123456789/56220/1/hurmejouhkihumantechnologyv1322017.pdf 
  • Fink, L. (2019). Larry Fink’s 2019 Letter To CEOs: Purpose & Profit. Retrieved from https://www.blackrock.com/corporate/investor-relations/larry-fink-ceo-letter

6.1.2 Can FinTech Usher in a Utopian Society?

  1. So, that was a lot of questions we just asked you
  2. to consider,
  3. so let’s ask you, Dave.
  4. Let’s start with you, what do you think?
  5. Does technology have the capability or potential
  6. to usher in a new era of utopian society for us?
  7. – I think so.
  8. I think, empirically you could look at the world right now
  9. and certainly over the past 200 years,
  10. really over the past 50 or 60 years,
  11. there’s been more progress in terms of
  12. most empirical measurements for what a
  13. good society would be
  14. than we’ve ever seen before, right?
  15. So FinTech also has the ability to kind of usher
  16. in some of these changes that can make
  17. society even better,
  18. bring us closer together,
  19. hopefully help with issues of scarcity,
  20. financial inclusion,
  21. but I do think that there’s a legitimate question about
  22. can this happen in the existing structure
  23. with the businesses that we have today?
  24. So I guess, to bring it, for those that are out there,
  25. one of the fundamental questions that
  26. people have been asking for decades now is,
  27. do businesses have a social responsibility
  28. and should they be generating some good
  29. for society in some regard,
  30. or is there a responsibility simply to generate profits
  31. for shareholders,
  32. and I think this is kind of an underlying question
  33. that will determine the question of whether
  34. we can use technology
  35. – Utopia.
  36. – to become a utopian society.
  37. So what do you think?
  38. – Yeah, so, I think a lot of people nowadays think,
  39. oh, this is like a new movement,
  40. where like, oh, we have ESG so environment, social,
  41. and governance factors that kind of play
  42. into investors’ mindsets and things like this,
  43. and this is somehow new, and I think what’s important
  44. to point out is, actually the debate around
  45. what the purpose of a company,
  46. what the purpose of business should be
  47. has been going on for at least a century, if not longer,
  48. about, should it be for shareholders
  49. or should you be focused on stakeholders?
  50. Should profit, pursuing a profit solely be the focus
  51. or should there be broader considerations?
  52. I think it’s actually, in my opinion,
  53. it’s actually quite settled now.
  54. Outside of some rare situations,
  55. there’s no legal requirement
  56. to pursue solely profit maximisation,
  57. well, for most companies.
  58. Additionally, I think, you have people,
  59. ostensibly someone like Larry Fink,
  60. who is the CEO of Black Rock,
  61. largest independent asset manager in the world,
  62. who by the very nature of the business that he does
  63. should be solely profit maximising, but actually,
  64. the last few years, if you read these letters
  65. that he writes annually to CEOs,
  66. he’s talking about the broader purpose
  67. that businesses and companies have to society,
  68. beyond just profit maximisation.
  69. – And of course there’s Jamie Dimon, Warren Buffett.
  70. They’ve all signed on to these kind of pledges
  71. to say the short termism, short term maximisation
  72. of share price, is not a good model.
  73. – Yeah.
  74. I think in practise, we’ve moved beyond.
  75. If profit maximisation is solely the sole purpose,
  76. I mean, I think,
  77. there’s a lot of academic discussion about it, but
  78. I think the reality is if you talk to business leaders,
  79. if you talk to people who have thought about the issue,
  80. I think they all will clearly say,
  81. yeah, a company should pursue other things
  82. in addition to profitability.
  83. There should be a little bit more
  84. of a holistic perspective on how we approach this.
  85. So the real rub is in
  86. how do you actually accomplish that, though?
  87. And that’s the rub.
  88. – And not to disagree, but I think,
  89. that is true, I think academically,
  90. intellectually, but there are also very practical realities.
  91. I mean, actual lawsuits
  92. where shareholders did sue successfully.
  93. Company executive directors, whatever companies
  94. who utilise what the shareholders believe
  95. to be their funds,
  96. their profits,
  97. for some inherent social purpose, right?
  98. And so, that is a reality, and so, even
  99. when you and I created this course,
  100. we’ve talked to people in the tech space,
  101. and in asking the question
  102. of who should be responsible for thinking
  103. about the utilisation of these technologies,
  104. should technologists,
  105. should inventors actually be thinking
  106. about the positive and negative implications
  107. that technology, I think the interesting,
  108. and hopefully surprising, response is, then,
  109. that they’re not really thinking about that, right?
  110. – Yeah.
  111. – This is not part of most engineering courses
  112. or engineering programmes.
  113. They typically aren’t required ethics programmes.
  114. I know Stanford has recently created
  115. a computer science ethics programme
  116. that I believe is now required.
  117. – So they’re trying to embed that into the curriculum.
  118. I think those are interesting points.
  119. I think on the lawsuits, there’s obviously a lot
  120. of litigation, and usually, for companies,
  121. usually some sort of shareholder dissent,
  122. and it’s about like we could have made more money
  123. if you had done this, but it’s usually not the pursuit
  124. of profit that was the issue in those cases.
  125. It’s usually there’s some violation of a certain duty.
  126. And again,
  127. there are certain situations where companies,
  128. company directors in particular, are legally obligated
  129. to try to find the highest price possible,
  130. but that’s actually less common than most people think
  131. to be honest.
  132. The interesting point, I think,
  133. when people make new products, like new code,
  134. some new technology, the question about
  135. what would the societal or ethical
  136. or whatever public policy impact of this be,
  137. doesn’t usually come until after the fact.
  138. So the analogy that I think about is once you have
  139. a shiny new sports car, it’s in the garage,
  140. and you think about, can I actually drive this?
  141. Would it be safe if I drove this?
  142. Those kind of questions are actually really important.
  143. The reality is you’re just gonna drive it,
  144. because the temptation is just so high to say, hey,
  145. we just gotta get this out there.
  146. This is so great.
  147. And if you think about in the context–
  148. – Drones would be one of these technologies that,
  149. in this course we talked about where people just like,
  150. just started using them.
  151. – Yeah, and so if we bring that full circle,
  152. if a company has invested so much money, capital,
  153. financial capital, human capital, time capital,
  154. into producing their shiny equivalent
  155. of a shiny sports car,
  156. there’s gonna be a lot of pressure to roll it out, despite,
  157. internally, there may be some enlightened folks
  158. who think,
  159. hey, we need to think about this before we do it, right?
  160. And that’s where the real tension comes in,
  161. because I think everybody at that table will say, oh,
  162. this is an important thing to discuss, but let’s just go out
  163. and either make money or
  164. whatever rationale they want to do,
  165. use to roll out the product,
  166. and this is the real tension,
  167. because if you imagine hundreds upon thousands
  168. of companies who are implementing
  169. these new technologies doing this across the world.
  170. You could end up in a really not so great place, right?

Additional Readings

    • Fintech For Financial Inclusion: A Framework For Digital Financial Transformation. (2018). Alliance for Financial Inclusion. Retrieved from https://www.afi-global.org/publications/2844/FinTech-for-Financial-Inclusion-A-Framework-for-Digital-Financial-Transformation
    • Galen, D., Brand, N., Boucherle, L., Davis, R., Do, N., El-Baz, B., Kumura, I., Wharton, K., & Lee, J. (2018). Blockchain for Social Impact: Moving Beyond the Hype. Retrieved from https://www.gsb.stanford.edu/sites/gsb/files/publication-pdf/study-blockchain-impact-moving-beyond-hype.pdf 
    • Bughin, J., Hazan, E., Allas, T., Hjartar, K., Manyika, J., Sjatil, P. E., & Shigina, I. (2019). Tech For Good: Smoothing Disruption, Improving Well-being. McKinsey Global Institute. Retrieved from https://www.mckinsey.com/~/media/mckinsey/featured%20insights/future%20of%20organizations/tech%20for%20good%20using%20technology%20to%20smooth%20disruption%20and%20improve%20well%20being/tech-for-good-mgi-discussion-paper.ashx

6.1.3 Should FinTech Create “Good” for Society?

  1. – So quick history lesson,
  2. maybe legal lesson for those who are out there,
  3. cause this underlying fundamental question
  4. is really important in the kind of technology space.
  5. So if you go back to late 70’s, early 80’s,
  6. there was this new technology called Betamax right?
  7. This is famous famous U.S Supreme Court case.
  8. With Betamax people all of a sudden had
  9. the ability to record television shows
  10. in their own home right?
  11. So the question at the time was,
  12. the people like Sony and the content creators
  13. that were fighting against this technology,
  14. they said the only valid use of this technology
  15. was violation of copyright right?
  16. You could only use this for a bad purpose
  17. so therefore the Betamax technology
  18. itself should be illegal.
  19. Now conversely those that created the Betamax
  20. they said “No, there’s a lot of different uses
  21. that you can have for this technology.”
  22. Just because there’s one possible bad use
  23. doesn’t mean the entire use is illegal
  24. and in fact, they made the distinction
  25. that it’s the person and the way they use
  26. that technology that determines whether or not
  27. it is ethical and or legal.
  28. So now fast forward to YouTube.
  29. YouTube has been sued many times about
  30. the content that’s on there and so the question is,
  31. is it YouTube’s fault that people are violating
  32. copyright laws or is it the people that are
  33. putting the content on YouTube that
  34. are violating these laws?
  35. Is it the technology or the user?
  36. And so these kind of battles have waged on
  37. in Europe, in China, in the U.S.
  38. The legal systems there have kind of, you know,
  39. analysed this question differently and they’ve
  40. come up with conclusions based on their own
  41. kind of cultural and legal background for that question.
  42. So I then throw that question-
  43. Now with that in mind,
  44. thinking about all these new technologies,
  45. we’ve talked about driverless vehicles,
  46. we’ve talked about facial recognition software,
  47. we’ve talk about all these cool new technologies,
  48. it leads us to this last and underlying question.
  49. Who should be responsible for these technologies?
  50. Assuming technology in and of itself
  51. can’t be inherently bad.
  52. Let’s assume it’s neutral, let’s assume it’s amoral.
  53. Who’s responsibility is it to ensure that
  54. these technologies are being used in proper ways?
  55. Is it the creator and owner of that technology,
  56. like the creator of the Betamax?
  57. Or is it the people – are they the people
  58. that are actually using utilising that technology
  59. say like Silk Road and other people?
  60. – Yeah, I mean I think, that’s obviously
  61. a super difficult question
  62. and frankly we’re not gonna be able to
  63. parse that answer exactly here.
  64. – And just to cut, one of the reasons why
  65. this is such an interesting question now
  66. is because unlike the Betamax,
  67. which the only thing you could do is record like on
  68. a single location in your living room, lets say,
  69. the difference in the technology now is
  70. I mean sentient AI or those types of things.
  71. Once that is out there, once that shiny new car
  72. is on the road,
  73. you can’t pull that back
  74. and has the ability to scale theoretically exponentially.
  75. – Ultimately the short answer is, you know, stakeholders.
  76. If you think about what that encompasses,
  77. you know, that’s users, that’s the creators,
  78. it’s the companies that commercialise it
  79. and it’s government and regulators.
  80. I think the pace of change that you’re eluded to
  81. is gonna be so rapid that we can’t rely
  82. on law and regulation alone.
  83. – Yeah, definitely not.
  84. – And by default, because of that, a lot of
  85. the structures that we might want to put in place
  86. almost would just be placeholders,
  87. because as we kind of continue through this
  88. iteration of new technologies
  89. and they build on each other,
  90. if we just say “Well it’s up to the governments,
  91. it’s up to having new laws, it’s up to creating a different
  92. regulatory structure.”
  93. Those will go a certain way,
  94. but ultimately, you know, I think there’s
  95. other stakeholders that have to be involved,
  96. that have to have greater responsibility
  97. in the context of that and you can create
  98. different incentive structures I think
  99. for people to start thinking about it.
  100. I think you can create from a base level
  101. of basic education, you know, as we were talking
  102. about just a few minutes ago about
  103. as people are developing new technologies,
  104. should we have or should companies develop a
  105. kind of the internal culture of saying
  106. “Okay, what is the impact of this?”
  107. Because you know there is a lot of
  108. fairly well known technology companies including
  109. Google that have various mantras relating
  110. to helping human society.
  111. But in the end if they don’t think about those
  112. core kind of cultural questions at the beginning
  113. of developing new projects,
  114. then it just kind of
  115. potentially mutates into something that they
  116. did not originally intend but it becomes what it is.
  117. – Yeah, so again, going back to
  118. the very beginning of this course,
  119. remember different types of culture
  120. change at different speeds.
  121. This is what we call culture lag
  122. and technology in particular is changing
  123. incredibly quickly and other aspects of
  124. society and our cultures like say law, religion etc.
  125. Are not going to be changing nearly as quickly.
  126. So what that means is, as David said,
  127. we’re not going to be able to rely solely
  128. on legislation, solely on the government
  129. in order to regulate and kind of police these things
  130. and that’s why it’s so much more important
  131. for us to think about the moral implications
  132. of these technologies and for us to rely
  133. on other stakeholders including the consumer, you and I,
  134. and the innovators that are actually bringing
  135. these changes to the marketplace.
  136. So for the remainder of this module
  137. we’re gonna focus primarily on these innovators,
  138. focus on these different business models,
  139. people that are choosing right at the outset
  140. to build business models that not only hopefully
  141. will have profit and sustainability,
  142. but will also do some type of social good,
  143. social benefit within the context
  144. of their actual service and product.

Additional Readings

  • Should The Tech Giants Be Liable For Content? (2018). The Economist. Retrieved from https://www.economist.com/leaders/2018/09/08/should-the-tech-giants-be-liable-for-content (paywall)

6.1.4 Does “Legal” Mean “Ethical” and “Valuable”?

  1. – One of the underlying questions
  2. that we like to explore in class
  3. is around this idea of if something is legal
  4. does it always make it right to do it
  5. or does it make it ethical to do that?
  6. So keeping that in mind
  7. we wanna think about algorithmic trading
  8. or electronic trading
  9. and its utility.
  10. – I’ll come straight out and say
  11. I am not a finance guy
  12. I’m certainly not a technologist
  13. and so I don’t know a lot about this.
  14. But I was speaking to a friend of mine recently.
  15. He’s a programmer, but he’s in finance
  16. very common here in Hong Kong
  17. and he was talking about high-frequency trading
  18. algorithmic trading, right?
  19. These types of hot, new FinTech tools
  20. that have been utilised
  21. really around the world
  22. but especially in a place like Hong Kong.
  23. And so as I was learning more about what he was doing
  24. and specifically how the technology worked
  25. I had a very, I guess I thought, simple question for him.
  26. And my question was do you think
  27. what you do adds value to society?
  28. Right?
  29. And his response was immediate
  30. and he said, “No.”
  31. “If you mean in terms of social value, no.”
  32. Right?
  33. To him it was just a job,
  34. and it was a way to make money.
  35. And so there’s not necessarily
  36. inherently anything wrong with that.
  37. But I think this is an interesting question.
  38. If we use this as an example in the finance space
  39. in the technology space
  40. just because algorithmic
  41. or high-frequency trading is legal
  42. does that mean that we should value it?
  43. And if so does it mean that we should even allow it
  44. in society?
  45. – Yeah, that’s a really interesting question
  46. in a lot of ways.
  47. On one hand what’s happened
  48. perhaps like the last 10 years or so
  49. roughly the last decade is a move for
  50. particular a lot of what’s considered vanilla trading.
  51. So like things that are traded that are pretty standard
  52. like just stocks, normal stocks and bonds,
  53. nothing fancy.
  54. A lot of that has been pushed into these areas
  55. of electronic trading, high-frequency trading
  56. algorithmic trading.
  57. And basically, depending on the strategy
  58. it’s just being done by computers
  59. and machines effectively.
  60. And we find, generally speaking
  61. that that is more efficient.
  62. Right?
  63. And so on that hand you can think
  64. okay, well is that better?
  65. Well in some respects that may
  66. be better for a client, right?
  67. You get better execution, it’s probably faster
  68. it’s less biased.
  69. But in the overall grand scheme of things.
  70. Like, so your buddy that’s creating this
  71. is he adding societal value?
  72. You know I can see where that jump is really difficult.
  73. I think if you take a really big step back
  74. and think of it from a macro perspective
  75. there could be some societal value
  76. in someone creating such programmes.
  77. I mean, for example
  78. most large companies as well as countries in the world
  79. have underfunded pensions for example.
  80. And basically they have obligations
  81. they need to pay out at a certain point
  82. that they won’t be able to because there’s a shortfall.
  83. And as a result what a lot of these places
  84. end up doing is
  85. giving money to other, basically investors
  86. to manage for them to hopefully
  87. make enough money where they can pay out
  88. money to you and me when we retire.
  89. One of the benefits perhaps would be
  90. through more efficient trading
  91. through electronic trading or algorithmic trading
  92. that maybe these people end up getting
  93. slightly better returns which ends up maybe serving
  94. being able to help retirees get their full pension
  95. in 50 years.
  96. That’s really big picture though right?
  97. And that’s kinda multi-step removed
  98. from what your buddy is doing.
  99. And so in the context of that it’s a really difficult
  100. thing to think about, right?
  101. On the flip side of that, this is not uncommon
  102. for a lot of people to think about in general either, right?
  103. So if we think about the person who
  104. works at a fast food restaurant
  105. maybe serving unhealthy food.
  106. When you think about like, is that adding societal value?
  107. – You gotta eat.
  108. – You don’t have to have an algorithmic trade.
  109. – Well that’s right.
  110. But do you need to eat there rather, right?
  111. – So this is like…
  112. – Think it through that.
  113. It just becomes quite interesting.
  114. – This is at the heart of the question
  115. and I think this is really what we’re asking
  116. for you to think about out there.
  117. Okay, so you may have differing degrees of restaurants
  118. and there may be differing degree
  119. in terms of the health of the food
  120. but at the end of the day you have to eat.
  121. Right?
  122. So therefore at least you’re arguing within
  123. a specific confined space
  124. of something that is a core need
  125. and therefore we as society would value that enough
  126. to allow incorporation of that particular type
  127. of business enterprise.
  128. The question that I’m asking is
  129. and I think what we’re trying to get at the heart of
  130. especially from the finance standpoint is
  131. does finance matter?
  132. And if not, if there’s a part of this industry
  133. like algorithmic trading
  134. that doesn’t have some inherent value to society
  135. should that be something that we as society allow
  136. and is that something that we should ascribe value to?
  137. So again, the question that we asked was if
  138. just because it’s legal that doesn’t mean it’s ethical.
  139. Right?
  140. – Or even necessary.
  141. – Or even necessary.
  142. And so, I have this with my students all the time
  143. they’ll say, but Mr. Bishop, it’s not illegal, right?
  144. So who cares?
  145. Mr. Bishop it’s not illegal
  146. so therefore it must be okay.
  147. – Which are not the same thing.
  148. – They’re not the same thing.
  149. And I think it’s a very dangerous kind of mindset
  150. that you do see quite prevalently
  151. in the finance space
  152. that does have me question
  153. whether or not we as society
  154. are valuing finance correctly, accurately
  155. and whether or not from a regulatory standpoint
  156. or from an academic, kinda education standpoint
  157. whether or not we’re setting them up
  158. to view this,
  159. their role and responsibility to society
  160. accurately and effectively.
  161. Right?

Additional Readings

  • Baldelomar, R. (2016). Where Is The Line Between Ethical And Legal? Forbes. Retrieved from https://www.forbes.com/sites/raquelbaldelomar/2016/07/21/where-is-the-line-between-what-is-ethical-and-legal/#7d5617ae250b
  • Pearlstein, S. (2018). Has Automated Trading Hijacked The Stock Market? World Economic Forum. Retrieved from https://www.weforum.org/agenda/2018/02/has-robot-versus-robot-trading-hijacked-the-stock-market

6.1.5 How Can FinTech Create Value for Society?

  1. – The point that I’ll leave with is,
  2. as we’ve discussed throughout this entire course,
  3. finance is critical,
  4. critical for the proper functioning of society.
  5. As we know it.
  6. – Absolutely.
  7. And places where people are free,
  8. where they’re educated,
  9. where, you know, basically the places you’d wanna live,
  10. you’d wanna travel to and you’d wanna go,
  11. those are places that have a highly functioning
  12. financial sector–
  13. – System.
  14. – And so I think it’s imperative for us
  15. to realise that it’s just critical
  16. to do this right, to do it well,
  17. to see this not just be a money-making exercise,
  18. but to actually have some social purpose
  19. to what they’re doing, right?
  20. The history of banks, it’s super important, right.
  21. It’s about trust, it’s about safety,
  22. it’s about stability in society.
  23. And I’m just wondering whether or not
  24. we have gone so far with some of like,
  25. algorithmic trading that it’s beyond–
  26. – Well, and, you know, that to be frank
  27. that’s only going to be the tip of the iceberg.
  28. – Right, exactly.
  29. – And as–
  30. – Meaning algorithmic trading as it is today,
  31. is only the tip of the iceberg.
  32. – Yeah, I mean in terms of where technology
  33. interfaces with traditional financial services,
  34. I mean, it’s already, the change is already
  35. starting to happen.
  36. – Yeah, yeah.
  37. – But, you know, algorithmic trading,
  38. high-frequency trading is, you know,
  39. it’s something that seems sexy because, you know,
  40. it splashes on like, you know,
  41. different newspapers and magazines.
  42. It’s related to financial markets directly.
  43. – Yeah.
  44. – And so, people tend to think of it as, you know,
  45. something very interesting.
  46. But the general idea of what’s happening,
  47. the structural change that those kind of technologies
  48. are making to financial markets and how banks
  49. and financial institutions operate.
  50. That’s just gonna be, you know, an ongoing process
  51. that will actually continue and compound
  52. with speed over time as these new technologies
  53. permeate different functions that happen in banks.
  54. And so the questions that you’re raising
  55. are absolutely correct.
  56. And so on one hand,
  57. you know, and it raises a whole host
  58. of variety of different societal issues, right.
  59. So, right now the financial industry as a whole
  60. is a large employer of a lot of people globally.
  61. – Yeah.
  62. – How is the displacement of this labour
  63. gonna affect employment trades–
  64. – Yeah, we talk about truck divers,
  65. – That’s right.
  66. – the reality is a lot of people in finance themselves
  67. are gonna be displaced, right.
  68. – And so, you know, they’ll increasingly,
  69. if you look at the distribution of employment
  70. at large investment banks, large financial institutions,
  71. increasingly, the percentage of people in technology,
  72. – Yeah.
  73. – is much higher than it was you know,
  74. 10, 15, 20 years ago,
  75. and so, that kind of trend will continue
  76. which is indicative of that a lot of the roles
  77. that people are in increasingly are not necessarily
  78. finance, pure finance roles.
  79. – But more, kinda this hybrid role–
  80. – Certainly that customer facing–
  81. – that your friend is in.
  82. – Yeah.
  83. – And so that’s one huge side of issues
  84. people have to think about.
  85. I think, you know, to the more broader
  86. foundational point,
  87. that is, one of the core parts of our course,
  88. is like, this idea’s broader purpose.
  89. That’s a really interesting discussion
  90. to have in the context of financial institutions.
  91. – Yeah.
  92. – Because by default, they should be
  93. profit maximising, right?
  94. – By just the very nature of what they’re doing,
  95. and that yet, we wanna ask them to be more than that.
  96. – Yeah.
  97. – Which I think is fair.
  98. – Yeah.
  99. – Because I think the great role that they have
  100. of how they are basically the fuel in many respects
  101. of society.
  102. – Yeah.
  103. – And of mobility, of social mobility,
  104. both individually for people like yourself
  105. like you mentioned buying a home
  106. and being able to get a bank loan,
  107. or look at countries that we’ll look at like
  108. Kenya or Myanmar, that rely on larger financial,
  109. at the macro-level, financial institutions
  110. to be able to move up from a developing
  111. closer to a developed nation.
  112. That, the engine, the fuel for that engine
  113. is largely pushed by aspects of finance.
  114. – So I like that, so if you think of law
  115. as kinda the infrastructure for society,
  116. the foundation,
  117. – Yeah.
  118. – finance is largely the fuel.
  119. – Yeah.
  120. – And so if you, okay so, again,
  121. the main concepts we’re talking about in this course,
  122. trust, accountability, right,
  123. the idea that there’s something of higher value,
  124. these are the things that we’re gonna be focusing on
  125. within the entrepreneurs and enterprises
  126. that are utilising FinTech,
  127. hopefully for some broader social purpose.
  128. It’s important to understand that, you know,
  129. there’s no way to know whether or not
  130. these companies we’re gonna use as examples,
  131. are gonna be doing things the right way or wrong way,
  132. if there even is such a thing.
  133. They’re definitely gonna stumble along the way,
  134. but the point is we want to look at ways
  135. that you can kinda build purpose
  136. into your business model,
  137. so that hopefully we can all kinda move
  138. towards a better, more inclusive society.
  139. – And to kinda caps to all that,
  140. like our discussion about Utopia in society, you know,
  141. and we said there’s the structural part of it,
  142. and there’s the other stakeholders,
  143. in the government and laws,
  144. but ultimately this gonna be at the people.
  145. – Yeah.
  146. – And so I think to that point exactly,
  147. the founders, the people who are leading these,
  148. who are starting these organisations,
  149. hopefully, in addition to what they’re trying to do
  150. to make the business profitable,
  151. they also kinda listen to the call of trying to be
  152. more purpose-driven.
  153. – Yeah.
  154. – And I think the combination of that will help us
  155. get to a place where, in an ideal world hopefully,
  156. or closer to an ideal world,
  157. – Yeah, yeah.
  158. – of this utopia we’ve been talking about.
  159. – Exactly.

  • Houser, K. (2019). Investor Sues After an AI’s Automated Trades Cost Him $20 Million: The First-of-its-kind Case Could Shape The Future Of Ai Legislation. Futurism. Retrieved from https://futurism.com/investing-lawsuit-ai-trades-cost-millions

6.2.1 Blockchain Application – BitSpark

  1. Earlier in the course we talked about global
  2. remittances, which is the money sent home by migrant
  3. workers who leave their homes to find work.
  4. We already talked about how important remittances are
  5. to migrant workers here in Hong Kong,
  6. but equally so for the 150 million migrant workers
  7. around the world.
  8. And this is particularly important for the many migrant
  9. workers and their family members who are unbanked.
  10. These transactions are an important
  11. lifeline for families around the world.
  12. They provide money for essential expenses like
  13. food, education, health, and housing.
  14. And while the transaction amounts are often small,
  15. it is estimated that collective global remittances
  16. total over $600 billion annually.
  17. To put that into context, that almost four times
  18. more than the total amount of international
  19. development aid, which the World Bank reported
  20. was at around $162 billion in 2017.
  21. The reality is that for many developing countries,
  22. remittances are a necessary crutch propping up their economies.
  23. But migrant workers are often unbanked
  24. or underbanked, and because of the small individual
  25. dollar value per remittance transaction,
  26. many workers have to use less trustworthy companies
  27. to help them transfer money.
  28. As a result, many are taken advantage of via excessive
  29. fees, and the transfer process is often very
  30. inefficient and time consuming
  31. Seeing both a social need and an
  32. economic opportunity, one company that has
  33. sought to lower such fees and reduce inefficiencies
  34. is Bitspark, a startup established in 2014
  35. and headquartered here in Hong Kong.
  36. The company claims to be the world’s first cash-in,
  37. cash-out blockchain remittance service.
  38. In basic terms, what that means is that they
  39. use cryptocurrency as a medium to transfer
  40. value directly between remittance shops.
  41. Like some of the other blockchain examples
  42. we have talked about earlier in the course,
  43. Bitspark theoretically helps cut out
  44. the middleman, leading to faster transactions
  45. and lower fees for migrant workers.
  46. The company now works with remittance shops
  47. all around the world, including HK,
  48. Malaysia, Ghana, Philippines, Nigeria, Vietnam,
  49. and Pakistan, enabling users to transfer money
  50. quickly without the need for a bank account.
  51. And other companies are following suit.

Additional Readings

  • Record High Remittances to Low- and Middle-Income Countries in 2017. (2018). The World Bank. Retrieved from https://www.worldbank.org/en/news/press-release/2018/04/23/record-high-remittances-to-low-and-middle-income-countries-in-2017 
  • Zaharia, M., & Kim, D. (2018). Bitcoin Start-ups In Asia Take Aim at Remittances Market. Reuters. Retrieved from https://www.reuters.com/article/us-crypto-currencies-remittances/bitcoin-start-ups-in-asia-take-aim-at-remittances-market-idUSKCN1GP117 
  • Gilchrist, K. (2019). This 26-year-old Dropout Is Saving People Big Bucks With Her Blockchain Business – And She Isn’t Betting On Bitcoin. CNBC. Retrieved from https://www.cnbc.com/2018/11/26/this-26-year-old-dropped-out-of-college-and-built-a-multinational-blockchain-business.html

6.2.2 Mobile Payment – Wave Money

  1. Southeast Asia is one of the fastest growing regions
  2. for FinTech.
  3. It’s obviously super diverse in terms of culture and
  4. people, but also levels of economic development.
  5. On one hand, you have one of the most developed,
  6. futuristic countries in the world with Singapore,
  7. but then a number of countries in the region
  8. where the populations are predominantly unbanked
  9. or underbanked.
  10. When I consider FinTech’s potential,
  11. one of the countries that comes to mind is
  12. Myanmar. I first travelled to Myanmar in 2010,
  13. about a year before it started its current
  14. economic liberalization.
  15. At that time, credit cards really didn’t work in the country
  16. and overseas ATM cards were not compatible
  17. with domestic cash machines since Myanmar
  18. was isolated from the global financial system.
  19. It was, and in many ways still is, a very
  20. cash dominant economy.
  21. At the time of my visit, visitors needed to bring in with
  22. them all the cash they needed for their trip,
  23. otherwise it was going to be very difficult to access
  24. cash from overseas sources.
  25. In light of that situation, one of the
  26. FinTech ventures working to create greater
  27. access, financial inclusion, and economic
  28. efficiency in Myanmar is a company called
  29. Wave Money, a mobile financial services provider
  30. that was launched in 2016.
  31. To see Wave Money’s attractiveness,
  32. we just need to look at a simple case, which
  33. is featured on Wave Money’s website.
  34. Imagine you’re a worker that sends
  35. 20,000 kyat, approximately 13 USD, every month
  36. to your parents in a rural village.
  37. Prior to Wave Money, you would need to send your
  38. parents money on the morning bus,
  39. and your parents would receive it once the bus arrived.
  40. This is obviously a tricky proposition.
  41. You or your parents can’t open a bank account
  42. because not only don’t you have enough
  43. for the minimum deposit, since you’ve never used a
  44. bank before, you are not sure how they
  45. operate or whether you can trust them.
  46. As an alternative, through Wave Money
  47. you can send a payment through your mobile
  48. device or a Wave Money agent, and your parents,
  49. even if they don’t have a mobile phone
  50. can receive the cash from a Wave Money agent
  51. in their village without any delay.
  52. In this example, we see lots of potential issues
  53. related to trust, time efficiency, security, accountability,
  54. and a number of other themes that we have covered
  55. during the course. We can also easily see the
  56. tremendous market need for such a solution,
  57. for the segment of the market that needs it the most.
  58. Based on that need, Wave Money has grown rapidly
  59. since it started and is now serving
  60. more than 7 million customers through a network
  61. that is significantly larger than traditional
  62. banks in Myanmar.
  63. Wave Money also launched an
  64. enhanced mobile app, WavePay, to provide more functions.
  65. Reportedly, Wave Money’s payment volume in 2018
  66. was approximately 1.3 billion USD, which is roughly
  67. equivalent to almost 2% of Myanmar’s GDP.
  68. Wave Money’s story, and others like it,
  69. are sources of our optimism for the
  70. great opportunities that FinTech can unlock
  71. for many of the world’s neediest.
  72. The potential for profound change is exciting for us.

Additional Readings

  • Wave Money Aims For Global Recognition. (2019). Finews Asia. Retrieved from https://www.finews.asia/finance/28329-wave-money-myanmar-financial-services-agent-network-global-recognition
  • Hynes, C. (2016). Fintech Holds The Key To Myanmar’s Future. Forbes. Retrieved from https://www.forbes.com/sites/chynes/2016/10/31/fintech-key-myanmar-future/#37979f954880
  • Yaworsky, K. (2017). Fintech in Myanmar: Leapfrogging to Mobile Money? Accion. Retrieved from https://www.accion.org/fintech-in-myanmar-leapfrogging-to-mobile-money/

6.2.3 AI Application – Anti-Human Trafficking

  1. In module 4, you may recall that we discussed the
  2. potential issues and misuse of facial recognition technology.
  3. And, when it comes to facial recognition technology,
  4. it does seem like that a majority of what is covered
  5. in the media focuses on the potential pitfalls
  6. or the potential negative consequences of
  7. this technology.
  8. We keep hearing fears and threats of a rising big brother
  9. surveillance society, about privacy now being a thing of
  10. the past. What we hear less about though are
  11. the positive uses of this technology.
  12. The fact is that artificial intelligence and
  13. facial recognition has some really cool and promising
  14. use cases that are both saving lives and
  15. alleviating a lot of harm.
  16. One brief example that we discussed earlier
  17. deals with immigration.
  18. For those who travel frequently, you know how annoying
  19. it can be to wait in long immigration lines.
  20. But as discussed, many countries are using biometrics,
  21. including facial recognition,
  22. to increase the accuracy of information processes
  23. and simultaneously save us all a bunch of time.
  24. Perhaps an even more impressive example of
  25. how this technology can change the world
  26. revolves around human trafficking and modern slavery.
  27. Every day around the world millions
  28. of people are trapped in modern-day slavery
  29. and sexual exploitation through human trafficking
  30. – and human trafficking has been characterized
  31. by the US Department of Defence and others
  32. as the world’s fastest growing crime.
  33. Now, we often think that trafficking
  34. is just something that happens elsewhere;
  35. outside our city, outside our country
  36. – or something simply taken out of a movie.
  37. But, according to the UN, it happens all around
  38. the world.
  39. Now, these human traffickers often use hotels
  40. to place their victims –
  41. where they can take advantage of the privacy and
  42. anonymity accessible through the hospitality industry.
  43. Inside those hotel rooms, victims are often
  44. photographed and the images uploaded
  45. and advertised on the both the open and
  46. the dark web.
  47. Fortunately, some companies, like Marinus Analytics,
  48. has set out to address
  49. parts of this vast and severe issue.
  50. Now, Marinus Analytics utilizes AI, facial recognition
  51. and machine learning to find useful patterns
  52. among vast amounts of data and turn that into
  53. actionable intelligence for investigators.
  54. Their suite of tools, called Traffic Jam,
  55. helps law enforcement follow up on leads more quickly,
  56. find and identify victims more effectively,
  57. and track down trafficking groups.
  58. And, their facial recognition technology (FaceSearch)
  59. can assess a photo of a victim and
  60. – within a few seconds – find out if this victim
  61. has been advertised online, and if so,
  62. find out where they may be.
  63. Another tool, called Hotels 50K,
  64. created what is essentially a ‘facial recognition
  65. system for hotel rooms’ by training a system
  66. to identify discernible markers among images
  67. of 50,000 hotels around the world.
  68. By doing so, the AI will enable investigators to find
  69. out where an image of a victim was taken.
  70. So that’s not based on the face of individual,
  71. but actually the whole entire room itself.
  72. So what do you think?
  73. Does the positive uses of facial recognition technology
  74. outweight any concerns you may have about privacy?

Additional Readings

  • Global Estimates of Modern Slavery (2017). International Labour Office. Retrieved from https://www.ilo.org/wcmsp5/groups/public/@dgreports/@dcomm/documents/publication/wcms_575479.pdf
  • Responding to the Trafficking of Children and Young People. (2018. United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime. Retrieved from https://www.unodc.org/endht/
  • Fields, J. (2019). Scientists Use Ai To Help Children Sold For Sex In Hotels. Thomson Reuters. Retrieved from news.trust.org/item/20190211114045-fa4qk/
  • Greene, T. (2019). How To Help AI Find Human Trafficking Victims. The Next Web. Retrieved from https://thenextweb.com/apps/2019/02/12/how-to-help-ai-find-human-trafficking-victims/
  • Cameron, L. (2018). Update On The Crime-fighting Ai Tool Called “Dig”: An Interview With Developer Mayank Kejriwal About His Research. IEEE Computer Society. Retrieved from https://www.computer.org/publications/tech-news/research/interview-with-mayank-kejriwal
  • Baraniuk, C. (2019). The New Weapon In The Fight Against Crime. BBC News. Retrieved from www.bbc.com/future/story/20190228-how-ai-is-helping-to-fight-crime

6.2.4 How Can FinTech Build Purpose Into Business?

  1. – All right, so we’ve just provided a number of examples
  2. where companies are trying to infuse social impact
  3. and hopefully, ethics
  4. into their FinTech business models.
  5. Right? So, what are some of your thoughts
  6. on the utilisation of these things,
  7. the positive side of FinTech,
  8. and what do you see as, I guess,
  9. advantages going forward for
  10. impact driven businesses?
  11. – Yeah, so I think the first thing from my perspective
  12. is frequently we like to bucket these things, like, certain
  13. types of business versus for-profit or
  14. traditional types of businesses, and I think we’ve talked
  15. about this before, but you know, effectively, you know
  16. these are just businesses.
  17. – Yeah.
  18. – Right? And we want them to be successful
  19. as a business but, of course within their ethos,
  20. hopefully they’re infused with a sense of purpose,
  21. which I think some of the examples
  22. that we’ve talked about with Bitspark, or Wave
  23. and some of these other ones. We see that, right?
  24. Within, there was an opportunity,
  25. like a market opportunity
  26. but also, there was a good purpose there
  27. that would be beneficial.
  28. And I think, you know, ultimately
  29. as we move forward, and we think about the complexity
  30. of the problems that we’re trying to solve
  31. I think it’s quite clear that government alone is not
  32. the answer for the complex problems that we are facing
  33. as humanity.
  34. – Absolutely.
  35. – Right? So, we, in a very important and profound way,
  36. need a partnership between private sector actors
  37. and government and global citizens, collectively trying
  38. to work on these problems.
  39. And I think, these kind of
  40. some of these real entrepreneurial new businesses
  41. that come out with these great leaders are
  42. thinking about how to do both,
  43. I think, is one of the things that will help
  44. us get to where we want as a collective as humanity.
  45. – Yeah, and I think it’s especially true in places
  46. where perhaps the government sector is not as strong
  47. there isn’t really a social safety net, and as I often tell
  48. my students in many parts of the developing world
  49. what we call social entrepreneurship is just survival.
  50. Yeah, they’re not trying to solve a social problem.
  51. They just see a need and they are trying to fill that need.
  52. So I think that’s really, I think
  53. the hallmark of most successful
  54. entrepreneurship adventures is the idea that you’re
  55. not trying to create a solution
  56. for a problem that doesn’t exist.
  57. You’re just trying to fill a void.
  58. And so in the case of say Wave, in the case of Bitspark,
  59. you have this massive population of migrant workers,
  60. of people in developing countries,
  61. and really, potentially the future
  62. really even in developed world, where they just need
  63. to move money. Right? Or they need access to banking.
  64. They need to be able to save money.
  65. They have to be able to like transfer money back home
  66. to their families. They need to pay bills.
  67. – Yeah, and I think one of the, one of these new ventures
  68. that you’ve looked at in Africa,
  69. M-Pesa is kind of a prime example of this, right?
  70. – Absolutely. Yeah, yeah. So, M-Pesa primarily
  71. originally in Kenya,
  72. but now really expanded across Africa
  73. and really all over the world is provided mobile banking
  74. and payment transfers,
  75. not even using smartphones, right?
  76. These are just kind of the old school Nokia style phones
  77. and they’ve given people the opportunity to leave
  78. the countryside,
  79. maybe work in the more urban environment
  80. where there are more opportunities for jobs, but then
  81. still be able to provide for their family, their parents
  82. their children back home by sending them money.
  83. – Yeah, I think that will be one of the great trends
  84. of FinTech, so you know it’s not as glitzy necessarily,
  85. but this idea of providing things that maybe seem
  86. so elementary basic to us is going to be a real value add
  87. for a lot of these communities
  88. to increase labor utilization,
  89. increase time efficiency,
  90. a whole host of other things that will increase,
  91. hopefully, just kind of the quality of
  92. life for many of these folks.
  93. – Yeah, but then on the flip side, not only is it basic
  94. or elementary to us, the reality is developing economies
  95. are learning from this, right? So as we’ve said earlier
  96. some of these technologies
  97. are way ahead of what even you
  98. and I would have here in Hong Kong,
  99. which is, you know, the so-called financial centre, right?
  100. You and I don’t transfer money using our phone
  101. very often, right? And those tools are
  102. actually quite new here,
  103. where as M-Pesa has already been
  104. used for many, many years.
  105. And I like the idea
  106. so I tend to come across,
  107. and perhaps even in this course
  108. as someone who is scared of
  109. some of these technologies
  110. especially facial recognition, and kind of the Big Brother
  111. conspiracy theory stuff,
  112. but it is very exciting as someone
  113. who is in the human trafficking
  114. kind of anti-slavery space.
  115. It is very exciting to think that you could use something
  116. like facial recognition to identify victims of trafficking
  117. to identify people that are kind of
  118. forced into prostitution or labour,
  119. and then even notify authorities
  120. and have them kind of go in and help people.
  121. – Yeah

Additional Readings

  • DaSilva, A. (2018). The Quest for Purpose. Stanford Social Innovation Review. Retrieved from https://ssir.org/articles/entry/the_quest_for_purpose#
  • Monks, K. (2017). M-pesa: Kenya’s Mobile Money Success Story Turns 10. CNN. Retrieved from https://edition.cnn.com/2017/02/21/africa/mpesa-10th-anniversary/index.html
