6.2.5 What Kind of FinTech Do We Want?

  1. – So I think these new technologies
  2. will solve some really critical problems that we face,
  3. so like that stuff you were mentioning about
  4. human trafficking and things like that.
  5. One other problem that I think
  6. these technologies will help us
  7. start addressing in a more hopefully efficient way
  8. are things related to health–
  9. – Yeah.
  10. – either through devices, internet of things,
  11. type of things, through consolidation
  12. and storage and access of medical records and data
  13. and how that interplays with live medical information
  14. we can get from our bodies.
  15. So I think there’s a whole host of potential applications
  16. that can really be unlocked
  17. through some of these technologies
  18. through different applications of them.
  19. – Yeah so I’ve been doing work recently
  20. with a very large insurance company.
  21. And they have a number of different products
  22. across Asia,
  23. but including health insurance.
  24. So a lot of people don’t really think about
  25. health insurance as a financial product,
  26. but it is.
  27. – Sure.
  28. – any kind of insurance.
  29. – Yeah I’m sorry, not just health insurance
  30. but really like life insurance et cetera.
  31. Insurance is a really critical financial service
  32. that is not really, in the past,
  33. has not been accessible to huge amounts of the world.
  34. And again, you’ve got two-thirds
  35. of the world’s population here in Asia,
  36. a lot of them developing, just coming up.
  37. And many of them don’t have access
  38. to these forms of health insurance, life insurance.
  39. – I guess in a comprehensive sense.
  40. – Exactly.
  41. And so what you’re seeing now is,
  42. in the InsurTech space, they’re actually investing
  43. in things like the internet of things,
  44. like wearables and stuff, where if you get
  45. a health insurance or life insurance policy,
  46. you wear the device.
  47. So again, we’ve shown examples
  48. of how that’s a negative thing of being tracked.
  49. But the reality is, they can identify
  50. and go towards a preventative medicine structure,
  51. a business model, where they actually know.
  52. Are you taking enough steps?
  53. Are you active enough?
  54. Are you getting enough sleep?
  55. And these types of preventative measures
  56. can really bring down healthcare costs,
  57. so in the U.S.–
  58. – In the long run.
  59. – Yeah I mean, U.S. is paying over what,
  60. two and a half trillion, 2.6 trillion dollars,
  61. something like that, towards healthcare.
  62. It’s really just obscene.
  63. And so this can hopefully help to prevent
  64. these healthcare problems
  65. from occurring in the first place
  66. which not only reduces costs for governments,
  67. for companies, for individuals, for families,
  68. but more importantly, can help provide people
  69. a healthier, happier life.
  70. – And I think that’s important.
  71. I think that’s a great point.
  72. I think it’s important for at least two reasons.
  73. On one hand, unfortunately, there are a lot of
  74. countries as they develop,
  75. they kind of take on this U.S. style–
  76. – Yes.
  77. – Western style of diet.
  78. – What he’s saying is they become fat.
  79. – Well that’s not what I’m saying,
  80. but in terms of lack of activity,
  81. lack of regular exercise and those kind of things.
  82. So this is, as a preventive measure, this is important
  83. ’cause there will be increasing more populations
  84. that are dealing with very similar types of health issues.
  85. And then, one thing we always talk about,
  86. in this course–
  87. – Even mental health by the way.
  88. – And mental health as well.
  89. One thing we talk about between ourselves,
  90. in the context of this course even,
  91. is this idea of finding balance too.
  92. Because some of this medical data,
  93. in some sense, it’s a double-edged sword.
  94. Because it’s good for on the preventive side,
  95. but insurance companies are,
  96. like we said, financial companies.
  97. They are subject to certain pressures as well.
  98. So you can easily envision a situation
  99. where an insurance company would
  100. use that information and say,
  101. “Okay this person is probably gonna be a risk,
  102. so let’s not insure them.”
  103. And then, you start isolating people
  104. who actually need the health insurance
  105. the most probably but can’t access it.
  106. So it’ll be a very interesting, dynamic kind of landscape
  107. to see how this develops.
  108. – So again, great point.
  109. And it really ties into everything that we’re talking about.
  110. So again, you have to have a balance between,
  111. in this example, say like health insurance
  112. where we want to democratise it.
  113. We want to insure that everyone has access
  114. to affordable health insurance.
  115. But then, that also would require a regulatory framework
  116. and a legal structure that allows
  117. for access for everyone.
  118. It doesn’t cut people off for pre-existing conditions
  119. or for gender or pregnancy
  120. and all these other real life examples.
  121. So as we move forward as a society,
  122. as companies, as individuals, whatever,
  123. we have to think about
  124. the positive and negative ramifications of these things
  125. because there’s so many cool things happening,
  126. so many innovations.
  127. All we’re asking is that we just take a moment.
  128. We stop, we just ask.
  129. Okay we’ve got the how.
  130. Let’s ask the why.
  131. And let’s try to think about why we’re doing these things
  132. and the potential negative ramifications of them.
  133. And as we do that,
  134. I think we’ll find that everyone,
  135. and really society as a whole, is better off.

Additional Readings

  • Miyashita, M., & Brady, M. (2019). The Health Care Benefits of Combining Wearables and AI. Harvard Business Review. Retrieved from https://hbr.org/2019/05/the-health-care-benefits-of-combining-wearables-and-ai
  • Karsten, J., & West, D. M. (2018). Wearable Device Data And Ai Can Reduce Health Care Costs And Paperwork. Brookings. Retrieved from https://www.brookings.edu/blog/techtank/2018/10/18/wearable-device-data-and-ai-can-reduce-health-care-costs-and-paperwork/
  • WIschhover, C. (2018). A Life Insurance Company Wants To Track Your Fitness Data. Vox. Retrieved from https://www.vox.com/the-goods/2018/9/20/17883720/fitbit-john-hancock-interactive-life-insurance

Course Conclusion: An Inclusive Approach for the Collective Future (Caption will be displayed when you start playing the video.) 0:00 / 0:00Press UP to enter the speed menu then use the UP and DOWN arrow keys to navigate the different speeds, then press ENTER to change to the selected speed.Speed 1.0xClick on this button to mute or unmute this video or press UP or DOWN buttons to increase or decrease volume level.Maximum Volume.Video transcript St

  1. So, let’s wrap up this module and tie all the major elements of the course together.
  2. Some experts out there argue that the technological innovations that are coming,
  3. and the pace of innovation, will unleash changes
  4. changes on humanity that we are not prepared for.
  5. Indeed, throughout this course we have explored a number of possible challenges and pitfalls
  6. that could come about because of certain FinTech advancements and business models.
  7. These challenges include bias, job displacement, a distancing of proximate and intimate human relationships,
  8. increased inequality, loss of privacy, cyber security threats, and more.
  9. Maybe after hearing us discuss all these different challenges and potential problems
  10. you may now be of the opinion that our prospects are bleak,
  11. and that there is nothing that we can do
  12. to stop the eventual arrival of a dark, dystopian future.
  13. But the reality is that both David and I are extremely optimistic about the future, and
  14. our hope for FinTech and FinTech innovations has a lot to do with that.
  15. As mentioned earlier in the course, the reality is that the world today is empirically better
  16. in almost every measurable category than it was even just 30 or 40 years ago.
  17. And from where we stand, the future looks to eat be even better.
  18. But it is also true that the challenges we face today,
  19. whether in the FinTech space or otherwise, are not the kind of problems that can be solved
  20. by the decisions or actions of just a small group of people.
  21. The problems are entirely too complex, think of climate change, the future of work
  22. and the potential challenge brought about by AI, blockchain, and other FinTech innovations.
  23. This requires an intelligent conversation among a broad swath of society.
  24. We are all impacted by these things, and therefore all need to educate ourselves,
  25. think deeply and broadly about the implications, and patiently and intelligently discuss what we want for our society.
  26. So we leave this course where we started: with the choice.
  27. Do we want a utopian future where restore scarcity is a thing of the past,
  28. where basic finance tools are accessible to all, and inequality is reduced,
  29. where bias is removed from financial decisions, and
  30. accountability is transparent and fair?
  31. If we want these things, FinTech is likely going to be a huge piece of the puzzle necessary to get us there.
  32. So looking back,
  33. what are the underlying ethics concepts that we all need to keep in mind with considering an ethical FinTech landscape?
  34. The first is trust.
  35. As we covered in Module 1, trust is the bedrock principle
  36. upon which the financial industry has been built for over a millennia.
  37. People need to trust that their financial institution will protect them and their money,
  38. will always hold their customers needs above their own selfish interests and
  39. is a reliable partner for all aspects of financial transactions
  40. Unfortunately, some financial institutions have breached customer trust
  41. which not only harms their own business, but also has broad implications for all society.
  42. So FinTech innovators including the large TechFins
  43. need to ensure that the tools they are building are trustworthy and safe
  44. and that their business models do not abuse customer relationships by selling data
  45. maintaining a lack of security protocols and other inappropriate practices
  46. that have unfortunately got some technology companies into trouble recently.
  47. As Klaus Schwab, founder of the World Economic Forum said
  48. In a world where nothing is constant anymore, trust becomes one of the most valuable attributes.
  49. Trust can only be earned and maintained if decision makers are embedded within a community,
  50. and taking decisions always in the common interest and not in pursuit of individual objectives.
  51. The second underlying ethics concept that we discussed several times relates to this idea of proximity.
  52. Now proximity is defined as a nearness in space-time or relationship,
  53. And in this course, we typically use it to denote how connected an action is to its outcome.
  54. So for example, in the Trolley Problem example from earlier
  55. the situation where we are asked to pull a lever to divert the trolley is less
  56. proximate than the situation were asked to directly push someone in front of the trolley.
  57. In the first example the mere fact that we were asked to pull a lever
  58. put some cognitive dissonance between the action of actually pulling the lever
  59. and the eventual outcome of someone getting hurt.
  60. But when we’re asked to push someone directly,
  61. the action of pushing and the outcome of the person getting hurt are
  62. physically and emotionally connected.
  63. You may not realize it but our brain reacts differently based on how proximate a situation is.
  64. The more proximate a situation is, the more we can emotionally connect to it,
  65. and therefore we’re more likely to choose to behave morally and ethically.
  66. In non proximate situations, we are more likely to behave unethically
  67. because we do not feel a connection to the harm
  68. This has many implications in FinTech ethics.
  69. For a simple example as we shared earlier,
  70. people tend to spend more when using credit cards rather than cash
  71. because credit cards seem more distant.
  72. But when they hold that cash in their hand
  73. we tend to connect it with the hard work that went into actually earning that money.
  74. Well from a proximity standpoint
  75. the reality is that FinTech is driving people further and further away from personal emotional connections.
  76. When we purchase something online, we don’t have an opportunity to look someone in the eye and speak to them.
  77. And while that may be more efficient and possibly cheaper,
  78. that distance is changing the way of how we interact in society.
  79. Now for a really clear example of this in a non FinTech space,
  80. just take a minute to read the comments from any news story or video.
  81. People on the Internet are mean!
  82. Much meaner than they are in real life
  83. Now why?
  84. Well in part because commenters don’t have to look the person in the eye and deal with the real
  85. emotional fallout of hurting their feelings.
  86. Is there a way that FinTech innovators can increase efficiency and reduce cost
  87. while also increasing our emotional connection to the broader community?
  88. Should this even be a goal?
  89. Well, all we know is that a less proximate world would almost certainly lead to a relatively bleak outlook for humanity.
  90. So we hope that connectivity and a sense of community are not sacrificed as we seek enhanced efficiency.
  91. Now the third underlying ethics concept that we discussed throughout the course is accountability.
  92. In a FinTech dominated world,
  93. who will be accountable for decisions and actions that machines and algorithms make?
  94. It’s pretty clear at this point that legal systems around the world are not well prepared for
  95. ascribing responsibility for things like injuries from autonomous driving vehicles,
  96. potential bias and decisions relating to financial products and mortgages,
  97. and breaches of privacy and other utilizations of FinTech.
  98. When you remove humans from the equation,
  99. sometimes you make a process fairer and less biased or at least less reliant
  100. on our flawed decision-making processes and humans subjectivity
  101. But it also means that you no longer have a person to point to
  102. or potentially blame when something does go wrong.
  103. Are we ready for that type of future?
  104. Now our hope is that a comprehensive approach is taken
  105. by innovators, regulators, corporate players, and even among us, the consumers
  106. to ensure that all stakeholders’ voices are heard
  107. and the finance industry continues to be more transparent and representative rather than more closed off.
  108. The fourth underlying ethics concept was privacy.
  109. We’ve already talked about this a lot,
  110. and this is one of the ethics concepts that many of you hear about on a regular basis.
  111. But that doesn’t reduce the importance of this issue and the need for our
  112. society to continue to consider the importance of privacy in our lives.
  113. Indeed this will be one of the great debates of our generation.
  114. Now study was done observing how ethical principles were valued among different generations
  115. and the researchers discovered that in almost every single category the current millennial generation
  116. valued the same ethical concepts as more mature generations.
  117. The one category that showed a significant difference was privacy.
  118. The reality is that young people today are growing up in a world without privacy at least
  119. privacy in the sense of what it meant when we were younger.
  120. And this is having a significant impact on how people view or value privacy in their lives
  121. And who knows? Maybe ultimately that’s a good thing.
  122. Our point is merely that we have to consider the ultimate long term ramifications of these changes while we still can.
  123. And financial institutions and technology innovators need to really ensure that
  124. they maintain client trust by building business models that value customer privacy rather than
  125. simply profiting off of our personal information
  126. Finally the fifth underlying concept was cultural lag.
  127. If you recall, cultural lag is the idea that some aspects of culture, particularly technology,
  128. change and adapt much faster than other aspects of culture like religion and law,
  129. and many of the most significant social problems that exist are caused and perpetuated because of this gap.
  130. We gave several examples of this including how smartphones were adopted almost overnight,
  131. but it took nearly a decade for people to realize the negative impacts that smartphones were having on their lives.
  132. It’s critical for FinTech innovators to really consider the implications
  133. of how their technologies will impact people not only in the present but also into the future
  134. For example, one of the biggest challenges that will be faced over the next century
  135. will be ensuring that the millions of people whose jobs are eliminated by FinTech innovations,
  136. the drivers, cashiers, and yes, even some finance professionals,
  137. lawyers, accountants and even doctors, are able to be retrained and reintegrated into the workforce.
  138. This means that we also need to reconsider the way that we are educating ourselves and our children.
  139. As one commentator pointed out, our current education system is preparing our children for the future of work incorrectly.
  140. He stated that we are scared that human jobs are going to be replaced by robots,
  141. but we’re still teaching kids to think like machines.
  142. We hope that you have enjoyed this journey together,
  143. and that we have given you something to think about to consider and ponder
  144. about the present as well as the future.
  145. We are really excited about the future and truly believe that FinTech has the potential for significant global impact.
  146. But for that to happen, together we need to forge a future that works for everyone
  147. and we will do that by putting people first.
  148. Again, as Klaus Schwab said: “FinTech tools our tools made by people for people”.
  149. Once again, we stand at a precipice, but we do so together.
  150. So together let’s take the steps necessary to
  151. take the utopian society that we see in the movies and make it a reality.
  152. ~End of Course~
  153. ~Thank you all!~

Additional Readings

  • Baron, E. (2019). We’re Not Prepared For The Promise Of Artificial Intelligence, Experts Warn. The Mercury News. Retrieved from https://www.mercurynews.com/2019/03/18/were-not-prepared-for-the-promise-of-artificial-intelligence-experts-warn/
  • Schwab, K. (2016). The Fourth Industrial Revolution. New York: Crown Business.
  • Bishop, D. L., Lee, D., Ferrel, O. C., Fraedrich, J., & Ferrell, L. (2019). Business Ethics: Ethical Decision Making and Cases, An Asia Edition, 1st Edition. Cengage Learning Asia. https://www.cengageasia.com/TitleDetails/isbn/9789814780803

Course Roundup

  1. – What a fascinating learning experience it’s been for us
  2. not just these past six weeks
  3. but really for most of the last 12 months.
  4. Most of you don’t know this
  5. but we’ve been preparing for this course in some way
  6. since last summer.
  7. So, as we finish the last module,
  8. it’s truly bittersweet for us.
  9. – Along the way we’ve been guided by the wonderful
  10. Technology-Enriched Learning Initiative team, TELI,
  11. here at the University of Hong Kong,
  12. captained by Andrea Qi.
  13. The TELI team has been instrumental
  14. in filming and editing the content we’re working on,
  15. crafting wonderful animations,
  16. and just overall helping us appear
  17. much more professional and polished
  18. than we actually are in real life.
  19. – Yeah.
  20. And we really also wanna express our gratitude
  21. to our super excellent research assistant John Pedersen
  22. from Norway, our Norwegian friend,
  23. who’s really helped in so many ways
  24. and contributed in this entire learning journey
  25. and this entire process.
  26. John’s work has been invaluable
  27. and he’s supported us in so many ways for the past year.
  28. – Now, most importantly,
  29. we want to thank each of you
  30. for participating in this learning journey.
  31. We hope you continue the journey
  32. of exploring these important issues
  33. even after the formal end of the course.
  34. To contribute to that process
  35. we’ll periodically upload or publish new content
  36. throughout the year,
  37. so look forward to engage in further then.
  38. – Yeah, and now, with all that said,
  39. let’s jump into some of the interesting questions
  40. and comments that you’ve had
  41. as this final roundup for the last module
  42. that explores kind of the positive impact of FinTech.
  43. All right so, this week we had a lot of interesting comments
  44. about kind of the good and bad.
  45. So, the proper utilisation of technology
  46. and kind of the purpose of the company.
  47. So, we talked about whether technology can be good or bad
  48. or whether it’s always neutral.
  49. We talked about whether as a technologist or innovator
  50. they should be thinking about
  51. the negative potential ramifications
  52. or utilisation of the technology.
  53. And we also talked about the overall purpose of a company,
  54. whether they do have a social purpose
  55. or whether it’s just the traditional shareholder model
  56. where it’s
  57. to make money– – Make as much money.
  58. – Yeah, make as much money as they can.
  59. And I thought it was interesting
  60. because recently Tim Cook, the CEO of Apple,
  61. he actually gave the commencement address
  62. at Stanford’s graduation.
  63. And so he said, quote,
  64. “Whether you like it or not,
  65. “what you build and what you create define who you are.
  66. “It feels a bit crazy that anyone should have to say this
  67. “but if you build a chaos factory,
  68. “you can’t dodge responsibility for the chaos.”
  69. End quote.
  70. And so, Tim, he didn’t say the name specifically
  71. but he strongly inferred Facebook, for example,
  72. with Cambridge Analytica,
  73. he kind of mentioned without saying it Theranos
  74. and their blog diagnostics scandal.
  75. So, what do you think of this quote?
  76. I thought it was interesting ’cause it’s coming from Apple,
  77. one of the most valuable companies in the world,
  78. a huge name.
  79. Obviously right there in Cupertino, California,
  80. near Stanford campus.
  81. What do you think?
  82. – So, I think his approach,
  83. the way described I guess this philosophy
  84. that you basically have to be responsible for what you make,
  85. I think for a lot of entrepreneurs and innovators
  86. in Silicon Valley
  87. I think that is somewhat of a fresh approach.
  88. I’m certain there are people who think that.
  89. Certainly.
  90. – And when they’re young
  91. I think a lot of them want to believe that.
  92. – That’s right.
  93. And I’ve heard enough talks
  94. and met enough entrepreneurs to know
  95. that absolutely most of them
  96. have their heart in the right place,
  97. but how does that evolve?
  98. To me I think about it in two ways.
  99. One is once you start taking external money
  100. there is pressure–
  101. – VCs and stuff. – Yeah.
  102. There is pressure to basically have
  103. some sort of liquidity event,
  104. kind of monetize that investment
  105. even though it may be a few years down the road.
  106. So, that’s one that creates pressure.
  107. But two, I think there’s a general just mindset
  108. amongst many entrepreneurs that, hey,
  109. my responsibility is just to create something cool.
  110. If there are negative ramifications of that,
  111. that’s the responsibility of regulators
  112. and law makers and government
  113. to kind of tell us what’s okay and what’s not okay.
  114. – And the user, yeah. – And the user.
  115. But ultimately I think,
  116. and I’ve heard a few people talk about this,
  117. ultimately it does come down
  118. from a sort of innovator’s perspective
  119. where they’re like, well, you know,
  120. my responsibility is to create
  121. and the government’s responsibility is to regulate
  122. and we’ll meet somewhere in the middle or at some point.
  123. And I think what Tim Cook is saying in the speech
  124. which I thought was really interesting
  125. is this idea that maybe
  126. that actually shouldn’t be the mindset.
  127. Maybe there is some culpability
  128. maybe not legal but at least certainly emotional, moral,
  129. about the thing that you’re creating
  130. the impact it has on the world.
  131. And I think that raises a lot of other broader implications
  132. about other industries as well.
  133. And so, it’ll be quite,
  134. I’m curious to see
  135. if people will still continue talking about this
  136. and how he’s framed it
  137. a year, two, three, five years from now,
  138. or if it’ll be something
  139. that sounded nice in a graduation speech
  140. but people tend to forget in history.
  141. – Yeah, I really liked
  142. the way that he phrases the chaos factory.
  143. Personally I think that was a direct stab at Facebook.
  144. Because if you could look
  145. at the last five years of Facebook,
  146. it has created chaos in a whole host of ways,
  147. and I think that was kind of interesting.
  148. Okay, so, let me play devil’s advocate,
  149. that’s what I get paid for, that’s what I’m trained to do.
  150. Many of you don’t realise this
  151. but my law firm represented Apple
  152. and so I used to work directly
  153. with Apple’s legal counsel in Asia,
  154. and I think it’s very fair to point out
  155. that Apple has had a number of very significant scandals
  156. and problems attached to it.
  157. And, again,
  158. I’m not saying that this disassociates what he was saying
  159. or that it somehow negates what he was saying
  160. but I do find it a little bit interesting that Apple,
  161. which 10 years ago was the technology company
  162. that everyone was kind of throwing stones at,
  163. saying that the way that you’re driving your supply chain
  164. and kind of putting pressure on your suppliers
  165. is in some instances causing people to commit suicide
  166. by jumping off roofs and stuff,
  167. that was a very negative thing.
  168. They felt they weren’t on the human side things,
  169. they were pushing their suppliers
  170. to not treat the makers of their hardware very well.
  171. But I do think that Tim Cook has kind of steered the ship
  172. in a different direction,
  173. is kind of pushing for hopefully a more ethical company
  174. and a more ethical supply chain.
  175. At one point in his speech it directly relates to our course
  176. because it almost started turning into what I thought
  177. was a commercial or an advertisement for Apple
  178. because he really started doubling down on privacy.
  179. We’ve already talked about it in this course
  180. how Apple is actually kind of using this privacy mantra
  181. as a business model to a certain extent.
  182. They’re saying, “Hey, get on our platform, use our products,
  183. “because we are actually selling in part privacy.”
  184. If you’re on Android, if you’re on these other systems,
  185. then you’re potentially gonna be exposed.
  186. And even in the case with the San Bernardino shootings,
  187. they kinda use that as an example to say,
  188. “We not even gonna buckle to the pressure
  189. “from the federal government in the US, the FBI,
  190. “and we’re gonna make sure that your data is private.”
  191. I found that very interesting
  192. and he kind of talked about that a lot.
  193. Again, what is your take on I guess Apple’s position
  194. as one of the most valuable companies in the world,
  195. as kind of this really broad, almost cult-like following,
  196. what role can they play in steering other technology firms
  197. into what is perceived to be a better future?
  198. – Yeah, so, I think on the idea of privacy,
  199. to be honest, be it Apple,
  200. be it any other technology company out there,
  201. I don’t think there’s anywhere else they can go
  202. when it comes to privacy.
  203. I don’t think you can argue the other side of the coin
  204. from that perspective, at this point.
  205. – Give your data to everyone!
  206. – Yeah, right.
  207. It’s a very different,
  208. again, if we were in a different technological ecosystem
  209. like maybe in China
  210. this would be a different discussion perhaps.
  211. But I think given the political reality
  212. of the United States,
  213. given the kind of core values
  214. of a lot of users of certain products in the United States,
  215. I don’t think realistically
  216. a technology CEO can go the other way on privacy.
  217. – Certainly not publicly.
  218. – Not publicly.
  219. So, at some respect for Tim Cook’s speech it was great
  220. but it was to be expected in some aspect.
  221. – That’s fair.
  222. – Now, I think the broader question
  223. which I think is interesting is this idea of,
  224. can Apple or a similar technology
  225. kind of guide that discussion broadly?
  226. – Or even should they?
  227. – Yeah, I believe so.
  228. I think that ties back into the earlier quote
  229. about should you be responsible partly
  230. for the things that you create.
  231. And if we take that to its logical conclusion
  232. then certainly they should also be responsible and active
  233. in shaping norms.
  234. In effect, that’s what we’re talking about.
  235. Because I think at least both of us agree
  236. that law will never alone be enough,
  237. so it’s users who have to create norms
  238. or creators who have to kind of limit themselves
  239. in a certain way
  240. when it comes to these kinds of things.
  241. Until that kind of mindset is more pervasive
  242. then we’ll continue to have broader issues.
  243. So, I think it’s important in that sense
  244. for someone like Tim Cook
  245. to try to be a standard bearer
  246. when it comes to these kinds of issues.
  247. – Yeah, and I think it’s interesting.
  248. So, a lot of you over the course
  249. or actually several modules,
  250. when we talked about cultural lag
  251. and when we talked about kind of the negative ramifications,
  252. unintended consequences of the technology wave
  253. over the past 10 years,
  254. many of you pointed out for example smartphone addiction
  255. and how people were actually looking at their social network
  256. to the exclusion of their broader immediate network.
  257. And I think it’s interesting using Apple as an example,
  258. they have somewhat publicly identified
  259. their responsibility in that smartphone environment.
  260. They were the initial
  261. who once put out the smartphone in 2007
  262. and certainly one of the most popular brands out there.
  263. And they’re now I guess cautioning people
  264. and even putting tools in place to help–
  265. – Screen time. – Yeah, screen time,
  266. kind of back off the use of that.
  267. So, you could say that’s a direct application
  268. of kind of the moral values that they claim to prescribe
  269. that are being put into their business model
  270. and even onto their hardware platforms.
  271. Well, Tim Cook he also mentioned, he said, quote,
  272. “Technology doesn’t change who we are, it magnifies it,
  273. “the good and the bad.”
  274. End quote.
  275. And so I think this is another example
  276. that I think as we move forward
  277. the whole reason why we entertain this in the first place,
  278. again, we’re not from the finance sector,
  279. we’re not from the technology sector,
  280. we are business ethics teachers, we are lawyers at heart,
  281. we just care about the future of society
  282. and we care about the way these trends
  283. are gonna be shaping our communities going forward.
  284. And so I think this is really a concept
  285. that we wanna leave you with,
  286. it’s this idea
  287. that technology isn’t gonna make you good or bad
  288. but it certainly can magnify
  289. the good and bad aspects of humanity.
  290. And so social media can definitely bring us together,
  291. FinTech can make life more efficient,
  292. but it can also create opportunities for exclusion,
  293. it kind of creates a distance, lack of proximity,
  294. which means that there’s a psychological
  295. I guess predisposition to be meaner on the Internet.
  296. There’s cyber-bullying.
  297. There’s so many aspects of society now
  298. that are driving people towards mental health issues
  299. and depression and distance and loneliness and sadness
  300. that I think can definitely be alleviated or magnified
  301. using these technologies.
  302. So, as we kind of move forward
  303. I guess our call to arms for all those that are out there
  304. is to keep this conversation going
  305. and really think about how these things
  306. not only can impact society
  307. but how you choose to use them to impact society.
  308. – Thank you again for participating with us
  309. during the course.
  310. It’s been a great experience for both of us.
  311. Now, although we’ve come to the formal end of the course,
  312. this is definitely not the end of our learning journey.
  313. The course will roll over
  314. to what’s called a self-paced format
  315. starting from June 26th
  316. and will continue that way
  317. until May 14th of next year, 2020.
  318. Now, we’ll continue to share updates
  319. of recent fintech innovations
  320. as well as laws and regulations
  321. and other things that we feel might be relevant
  322. as part of our overall course learning journey.
  323. – Yeah, so please stay in touch with us
  324. through email, newsletter, and edX,
  325. on our social media channels,
  326. as well as personal LinkedIn accounts.
  327. We really look forward
  328. to maintaining and expanding this learning community
  329. and continuing the discussion of these important question.
  330. We wish you the very best in all that you’re doing
  331. and aspire to do.
  332. ~Thank you~
